reviewText:
Early Access Review

Intresting, stylish adventure awaits!
Storyline and setting make this game a very enjoyable expierence, concept of a card-driven rogue game add a rather plesant taste.

However, there are some problems with battle system. And this is actually the only problems I can think of.
Firstly, in a battle everything against you, even the camera. It is sort of fixed and how many times I got hit just because I can't see the enemy right in front of my character - I can't even count.
Secondly, slowmotion. It happens, yeah, cool stuff, but... It throw timing of the strike off balance so much, that it feels like your opponent DOES NOT GET AFFECTED by slow-mo. It can be just a feeling, though, but it leaves a bitter aftertaste.
And third problem is the time which your char needs to react to a pressed button. Even if you press counter at the moment an emblem of a throwing weapon appear above your head, it doesn't mean you will reflect it at all. Timings a bit of odd.

But! This game is great, seriously. And very good. Especially, the comments of your wizard opponent, so much soul put in this game... It rocks.

reviewText:
I usually never complete games. Even if I like a game, I play it for a few hours and rarely do I play them again.
I usually manage to play free to play or horde mode games more than 30 hours.

But this game...I am well over 20 hours already and not even beginning to feel like I should stop anytime soon.
Only just now am I nearing the end of the game content wise, but that does not mean that the game is over. It just means that I am almost ready to start playing Endless mode properly.

An unique game that is a wonderful combination of different genres you would not usually mix.  A collectible card game mixed with a third person arkham style brawler is something you would not expect to work this well, but it just does.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will first start off with, most of my hours in this game have been out of steam in offline mode.

Hand of Fate is by far one of the most original games i have come across in a very long time.
you construct you deck after you complete the first encounter with jack of dust.
your deck is the dungeon and the encounters you have along the way to the boss.
food is used for each move you make so the more food you have the more moves you can do.
upon an encounter with an enemy it goes into a world where you fight the monster cards drawn.
the fighting style is very much like the fluid fighting system from the arkham games where in you aim at your next target and your hero will zip accross to that enemy and proceed to beat em down. the counter system works similar to arkham too where an icon pops up above the offending enemies head and you hit Q if have a sheild block and counter with that.

in my personal opinion upon completion this game is going to start a new GENRE of dungeon crawling hack and slashes.
even though it is in early access it is still a pretty polished game given its current phase of completion.
10/10 give it a go i don't think you will be dissapointed.

reviewText: I'll start by saying that I want to love this game. The atmosphere is incredible, the pretense for the story delivered through a card based roguelike dungeon is genius in how it capitalises on the strengths of both card games and roguelikes. Even the ambitious combat scheme is generally pretty engaging (if flawed in a few small ways). I adore a lot of what the game is doing. That said, I can't recommend it in its current state.\n\nI originally wanted to say that the game is too difficult, but that's not true. The game is outright unfair. I'd be fine with the game being difficult, because difficulty implies a requirement for careful application of thought and skill. This is not what this game offers. Especially nearer towards the end of the game, there are an incredible amount of cards the dealer plays that may as well read Player loses game". For an example

reviewText:
- Short version: Truly an inspiring, creative, fun game. Beware though, this is not a card game. Yes the theme is about card games but the combat is the 50% of the gameplay and it is the ultimate deciding factor between the win or loss condition. Definately watch a gameplay video of Totalbiscuit or whatever before purchasing!!! aside from that, this is totally worth the purchase.

- Long version: Although the price seems a tad bit high, you will probably feel like the game deserves it in the first 30 minutes of gameplay. The theme is laid out elegantly, voice acting, soundtrack and the general atmosphere is just amazing.
You get to create your own deck of possibilities (cards are events). Your decisions and sometimes mere chance decides the outcome of that event. Events can sometimes turn into a battle ( AC style 3rd person combat style) .
Combat is the 50% of this game in the beginning. However in the later stages of the game, the strategy, deck-building and the choices made outside of the combat is the bigger deciding factor. So its safe to say that combat is probably around 25% of importance once you get better at it.
---------------

PROS:

*  TONS of replay value. (This is the part that deserves the full price);
*  Awesome presentation. Artwork just fits with the theme like a glove;
*  Great gameplay mechanics. Combats last as long as they should, no more or less;
*  Simple UI design is just relaxing, the game has almost no menu's or complicated screens;
*  Most importantly, The game makes you want to play again, and again, and again...
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CONS:

* Combat. This game would be PERFECT withouth combat (or at least with different styles) . I can't describe the exact reason but the game is just too perfect on the table" with the atmosphere

recommended: face to face with the dealer. Combat feels like a chore

reviewText:
Tabletop, roguelike, RPG, TCG, third person action RPG... Add it all up and what do you get?

A strange, yet extremely fitting merge of genres, with beautiful use of lighting, shading, art and music.
Not only does it look and sound amazing, but it plays even better, with an amazingly well designed deck building system that allows you to, in a sense, build your own adventure with equipment and encounters alike, all while the dealer throws his own tricks into the mix.
You can take on every challenge, blade in hand, with a battle cry as you rip through your foes, or you can lower your weapon and offer your food and gold to help villagers, and your actions change the outcome, and in some cases, the reward.

Hand of Fate isn't trying to do a lot of things, but what it does, it does well.
Easy to use deck building system, or an automatic option for those not interested in the deck building.
A very basic map" screen
recommended: yet with more than enough depth to keep you engaged and thinking about your actions

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a fantastic blend of Adventure, RNG, rouge-like and card games.

I picked this game up recently on sale for a steal and it was worth every cent. The introduction to the game is simple and easy to follow allowing you to pick up the game quickly and play at your own pace.

As you play the game you step from card to card in stages and deal with a number of random events including; battles, moral choices, ethical choices, gambling, quests and visiting shops while progressing through the stage towards the goal of a boss fight. The main story consists of 12 stages each with a boss of its own. All heading towards a final 13th stage that you will not be prepared for the first time. Around about the time you defeat the 4th boss you will unlock a game mode called endless".

Endless mode is never ending stages progressively getting harder until you can go no further. I suppose the goal is around stage 30 as this is the achievement awarding level. I personally was never able to beat my record of stage 26. It gets seriously rough. The addition of "endless" mode allows you to unlock more cards/ rewards as you complete each cards requirement which can then be used in both story mode and endless.

A great addition to the game is the ability to edit the "world" or "level" by using the deck builder which is available basically at the start of the game. Once you have an idea for the game
date: the events and items you have preference for you are able to open the deck builder before a main story level and adjust it to your specific liking. The game does offer an auto recommended deck which is fine but once you hit that final 13th level you will most likely need to adjust the deck to your specific play and equipment style.\n\nOverall I had a great time with this game
hoursPlayed: great narration/ music and a play style that was addictive
voteText: punishing and rewarding. If this sounds even remotely interesting to you I would suggest you pick it up and give it a try. I loved my time spent on Hand of Fate and I couldn't recommend it enough."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access - Things are subject to change!

REALLY interesting twist on rogue-lite genre that seems to be popular now with stuff like Magicite, Binding of Isaac (and Rebirth around the corner) and Nuclear Throne.

Hand of Fate mixes deckbuilding with 3rd person hack and slash combat and roguelite-elements. It still is kind of barebones and kinda unresponsive, but that's early access for you. As a game It really hooked me and I did really enjoy playing this. Deckbuilding is kind of stale until you actually get more cards by beating bosses and succeeding in events.

Fighting feels good and meaty and slow-mo-last-hit -effect feels amazing! Still, it isn't really too complex and mostly just spamming X to do damage, in my honest opinion the combat doesn't flow too well having quite long animations and a split-second stop-period" after them if there are no enemies nearby
recommended: especially if you do not have weapon with counter attacking-modifier and can cause you take lots of unnessecary damage.\n\nMy biggest gripe about the game is the random element. I see what they're trying to do as drawing cards from deck for random outcome really is the games namesake

reviewText:
Summary / Mechanics

- This is a randomized dungeon crawler in which your encounters are embodied by cards.
- For completing an encounter in a special way you can unlock its follow-up encounter and new equipment.
- This game has permanent progression in the way that you can enhance your card deck (encounters and equipment) with your new cards.
- Combat is real time slash/counter/dodge action (batman-like), with more depth once you have weapons and artifacts with special powers.


Characters / Quests

(Edit: The different Characters are part of the Wildcard-Addon, didn't know that because I bought in Early Access)

- There are several playable characters (visual differences only through equipment) that each have some pros and cons, and each adds special cards to your deck.
- 3 of them are the equivalents to easy/normal/hard modes, the other ones enable different play styles and offer unique challenges.
- Each character has his own questline that is linked to their profession and special abilities.
- Quests are successions of encounters (some branch out), you will complete them over several rounds of gameplay.
- Quest encounters have a coherent story and reward you equipment that was featured in the quest etc.


Game Modes

Story mode
- For every level" you have to clear a number of dungeon floors and fight a boss
- Each level will let you start with different gifts and curses
date:
so that there are varying challenges
- After every third level you will gain better starting equipment but enemies will get tougher
Endless mode
- Endless dungeon floors
recommended: highscore mode.\n- In this mode you don't build a deck
hoursPlayed:
it uses all cards.
- Every floor will add tougher cards to the enemy card deck and you will get a random punishment.
- You can use this mode to complete quests (and get better cards for your story deck) or play the character quests without the additional difficulty of the later story mode levels.


Recommendation:

If you are interested in game mechanics or like card and tabletop games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are looking for a fantastic Fantasy/RPG card game look no further. You get to customize your deck of cards to fit your playstyle. You play as a hero who is trying to make it through all of the trials and tribulations of a warrior, all that matters is defeating the next boss (and eventually the main boss a.k.a the dealer of cards). Every card you draw can either help you or hurt you, it is very random. Whatever you end up drawing will be the equipment you end up with. The randomness of what you can get is what makes this game so appealing.
There are small battles in which you can physically take controll of your hero to hack and slah the enemies to death. These battles help break the monotony of just playing a card game. You might draw a good set of armor and a decent sword or you could end up with a nasty group of gremlins to fight, either way you will still end up having a blast. Once you defeat a boss you will continue unto the next boss and set of challenges untill you get to the last boss.
You earn in-game gold through defeating mobs or completeing quests. There are shops in every set of cards in which you can use this gold to buy/ sell armor, weapons, or even cure curses and heal health. You can also completely customize your equipment/encounter decks to make sure you are having the most personal experience possible.
If you are a fan of strategey games or just a card game fanatic then this is a must buy. I am not in any way partial to these types of games, yet I can't help but have a blast playing this.
If you can find this on-sale I'd say grab it no questions asked. Even if this wasn't on sale I still believe it's worth 25$. There is an enormous ammount of replayability to be had. Buy and trust me you will not regret it.
-Casey

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great mixture of rogue-like, RPG, and card based elements makes this a terrific game.  It combines the combat of the Arkham series with the elements of any fantasy table top, pencil and paper RPG.  At the beginning of each story quest which culminates in a boss encounter, you build up an encounter and an equipment deck of cards that you have acquired previously.  The events of the story and the rewards of various adventures in that quest are randomized from these decks and a couple other decks the Dealer has at his disposal.  This gives the player more agency in the sequence of events and what equipment could be acquired during gameplay.  In addition, the game includes some resource management which presents obstacles to the player.

One downside is that, like all rogue-likes, there is the possibility of having a bad run."  You may not receive enough food and starve to death
date: not receive enough gold and be unable to purchase items or possibly be unable to complete encounter cards requiring gold
recommended: or have bad luck in general leading to the character's untimely demise.  However
hoursPlayed: the randomness that causes this problem also makes each iteration of a quest different than the previous ones and so
voteText: keeps the game interesting and alive.\n\nPresently
helpfulPercent: this game is in beta and the devs are still balancing it.  Even so
votesHelpful: I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys pencil and paper RPGs

reviewText: The care and attention which has gone into crafting this game - from music to voice over to the little touches in how the graphics are handled - show an incredible amount of love not normally encountered in modern games. With the addition of being bug free, it's an absolute pleasure to dip in and out of. The mechanics are interesting, the randomisation makes replayability a joy, and endless mode is an interesting challenge. One or two obtuse mechanics do exist, but there is strategy in the gameplay, and the combat, though essentially an arcade element, is also entertaining because it is fulfilled in short bursts. Not necessarily the kind of game that addicts you to play in long sessions, the game takes a different approach with enough intriguingness to make you come back. One for the library.

reviewText:
I have only played Hand of Fate for through about half of the Story mode decks but, I must say it is one of the greatest games I have ever played.

Combining the death and start over mechanic of a Rogue Like, with the addictive nature of a Deck Builder was an absolutely brilliant idea.  Having the encounters with monster cards be played out in a slightly Arkham Style (Attack/Counter/Dodge/Stun) was an even further brilliant idea.  Although the combat is the weakest part with a fixed camera, it is still manageable and fun.  Trap Rooms are also played out in this 3rd person camera style as you dodge your way through a trap maze.

Even if you complete all 12 of the storymode levels there is an Endless mode to see how far you can go.  The game starts out relatively simple, but starts to become challenging about 1/4 of the way through the Story decks.

Add to this the amazing way it's presented, the dealer is well voice acted and doesn't get annoying.

I cannot recommend this game enough.

It's reminds me of playing a game of Munchkin, but against a dealer instead of a group of friends.  Absolutely brilliant.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In-depth analytical video on Hand of Fate: (written review below)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=__o1V2zMrVs
The aesthetics of Hand of Fate are undoubtedly stellar. The high quality ranges from great sketches for every card, to beautiful 3D graphics as soon as the brawling starts. Most notably here are the lighting and special effects that manage to bring the whole scenery to life. Especially the fight against the Queen of Dust did impress me with its flying sand everywhere. Hand of Fate makes it abundantly clear that the overall aesthetics are not meant to be overlooked and it succeeds in creating a very appealing style overall.

Almost the same could be said about the sound design of Hand of Fate. The dungeon master for example is exquisitely voice acted, the effects give precise feedback and underline every nook and cranny. Sadly, all of the event texts are not voice acted and have to be read, which is understandable in terms of budget for voice acting, however sad due to the competent voice actor already in the game. Since the music is mainly meant to create an atmospheric background noise instead of carrying emotion or story, it is competent in what it tries to achieve, however forgettable. All in all, the sound design of Hand of Fate is very good, could however be improved in terms of the quantity of voice acting.

Let’s delve into the rather unique gameplay mixture of Hand of Fate. For every story adventure you start, not taking the endless mode into account, you prepare two deck of cards. On the left hand side the equipment that can be found during your dungeon crawling. Which consists not only of stronger weapons, but also of armour, helmets, gloves, rings, artefacts and trinkets. Ideally you would want to include cards specifically against a certain type of enemy that you suspect to encounter, however I mostly threw in new cards that I had not used before to keep the game experience fresh. On the right hand side of the decks, you can select the encounters that you want to possibly face during your adventure. Hereby it is important that some encounters cannot be removed until you fulfil certain conditions. The same procedures holds true as previously: I mainly selected encounters that I did either not face before to keep experiencing new content or that I did not manage to complete previously. As soon as you are satisfied with your decks, you start the story. Depending on the boss you plan to encounter at the end of the adventure, the card dealer adds some fixed cards into the mix, indicated by their purple tint and as soon as all decks are shuffled the game begins.

The dungeon master begins by laying down the encounters face down in a randomly selected pattern. Now you strife to reveal the final boss and defeat said enemy to claim victory of this part of the story. Your character is indicated as golden statue and you always move by one card either horizontally or vertically hereby consuming one food, healing a bit and revealing the encounter you step on. One possible card is the choose-your-own-adventure style encounters, whereby you select an option and more often than not the final result is determined by your selection of one of four cards, ranging from huge success to huge failure and thus affecting the outcome rather randomly. While the encounters themselves are fun at their core, I do see a problem in the random nature of selection as there is no skill or learning involved from the player’s side and thus it fails to feel rewarding when selecting success and at the same time also unreasonably punishing when you hit that huge failure card, especially when this ends up costing you your weapon just before facing the final boss. I would have preferred a system similar to how FTL manages random encounters by which certain abilities or other pre-collected items can affect the outcome positively.

Another possible encounter is one of the multiple combat scenarios. This is where the third person brawling comes into play and the graphical fidelity turns up several notches. Depending on the encounter or just by random selection you will be spawned into one of several arenas together with a bunch of enemies and possibly even traps. These short brawling segments are highly reminiscent of the Batman Arkham series without being as fluent and as responsive. Make no mistake, the brawling in itself is good, however the animations are not quite as top notch as the basically perfect ones of the Arkham games. Also, at least in the first three hours, the combat is not as strategic and as deep as the inspiration. Hand of Fate mainly relies on counter-attacking on green indicators and dodging on red indicators, while there are only very few special moves or strategic approaches to the combat in itself. This problem obviously arises as the game relies on random generation and thus you are always dependent to create enemies that could be faced with the basic equipment, while other story-driven games can later on throw enemies into your way that require you to use the latest acquired item or special move and the like. To summarise, the brawling is competent and refreshing, however does feel repetitive after a while. A perfect example for this is the spawning animation. While it is highly enjoyable the first few times your character spawns and gets all his equipment step by step and lastly your huge hammer falls from the sky just before you charge the flabbergasted and underpowered bandits, after a couple of hours game time though, I wished this animation could be skipped or disabled entirely, as it eats up so much time, especially when going from combat to combat encounter and thus this delay turns to be obnoxious rather quickly. Oh, and speaking of annoying, the camera cannot be rotated while in the combat arena, which can lead to some weird angles and fighting directions. Hopefully that will be fixed in the future.

After defeating the final boss at the end of the adventure or by dying in between due to combat or starvation, the tokens you collected along the way are opened and thus new cards are unlocked, keeping the encounters fresh and empowering your equipment for future approaches. With these new cards you start the cycle over again, selecting a new boss, adapting your decks and facing the latest random encounters you selected beforehand.

All in all, Hand of Fate is a beautiful, very competent mixture of dungeon crawling choose-your-own-adventure, third person brawling and deck building, with a few flaws in between. Nonetheless, Hand of Fate is one of the best Steam Early Access games I have played and I am very much looking forward to future improvements, which in my opinion should mainly target the repetitive combat, possibly granting you permanent special moves every few defeated bosses and thus creating more depth and tactical approaches overall.

UPDATE
As I now played a little more and stand before the Queen of Skulls, I must say that the further the game progresses, the more infuriating the random nature becomes. There are several encounters with three failure cards resulting in severe penalties like losing 50 health and 30 permanent health, basically rendering the whole remaining adventure impossible. Also, due to the entirely random nature of encounters, it happened multiple times that I died on the first floor. If the brawling would be a bit tighter and more fluent overall, I am rather sure that you could go through these encounters with ease, however for example a ranged attack from close up is impossible to block and if enemies swarm you, there is a good chance that an unblockable attack will it you while you are countering another one. All in all, Hand of Fate is still a good game, however the further I progress (now over 4 hours played) the less fun I have, thus I now doubt the longevity of this dungeon crawler.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a wonderfull strangeness about it. You go through a dungeon, gaining equipment, and fighting random encounters, much akin to a Roguelike. It's a deckbuilding game, wherein your decks, are built, by you to choose what encounters and equipment you are going to encounter. Simple Batman like controls, and you have yourself something that plays rather smooth, and is kinda neat. Later dungeons add elements such as curses and blessings that can change the way you handle it, giving you a much different way of approaching things. For instance, one of the games, in which I lost gold based on health remaining.  Do I forsake food, so that I can lower my health, as to not lose gold to buy things? Do I rely on my combat mastery to survive? Should I sell this item now, knowing I may well lose the excess gold left over from what I want to buy?  A simple thing can change it up quite a bit.

But then there's the atmosphere. This game has a wonderful sense of mystery to it. It's dark, illuminated by candles, told in a haze. It is you vs. a mage who is playing cards that are symbolic of encounters from your past. The narration for him sells it very hard. His comments about what you do, the achievements you just got, how he feels about the cards,  and if you can handle them. As the sole talking bit of the game, he is fantastic, and his voice fits perfectly.

With a large amount of card unlocks, variable outcomes, and an atmosphere that I cannot emphasize enough, this game is something else. It was well worth breaking my Early Access embargo on it.

reviewText: Buy this!! If your're on the fence about this game (and especially if it is on sale) BUY IT!!! It is well worth the investment. It's kind of one of those easy to learn hard to master kind of games so I got sucked into it pretty fast. A good sign is that the developers are responsive to the game community. And the Dealer has a lot of dialogue (especially as you get to newer levels). Plus he's not just a bad guy - he has a complex character that you get to know. Their is a certain amount of random chance to the game (but their is too in life) and it can get a little maddening trying to get the right cards in sequence. But overall this is a good investment even if you don't like active fighting games. I didn't but now I do thanks to this game. Plus if you get stuck just go to the community board and ask. It can be very satisfying to kill a monster you had thought was unbeatable.\n\nAnother nice thing is that if you really hate a card you can often just not select it. Don't always go by the Recommended deck (although I would advise that you do at first until you get a feel for the ropes" and what you like). This is game is very customizable."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very interesting. As a deck-building game, it starts off somewhat bland with few cards... but that's all a part of it as you learn basic mechanics and how the game is played. As you progress, you build your deck full of new interesting encounters and gear that you can find during your adventure. The gameplay itself reminds me of the Batman games, though a little clunkier. As an Early Access game, I am not too worried about that.
This has a lot of potential and I recommend it if you enjoyed the combat in the Batman Arkham series. This is scratching my 'action-rpg-loot' itch for the moment. The voice acting of the card dealer is also very well done.
However, you should use a controller. The menus aren't all that well-done and the combat needs a bit of tweaking.

Overall, though, I recommend it.

reviewText:
I have to say this a strange concept for a game and one I was hesitant to try at first but I am pleased to say it was excuted well. I would be wary if you get frustrated easily as this game is VERY dependent on the old RNG. For a hybrid action title this can be frustrating. I was stuck on one of the decks for a few days without coming anywhere close to completeing it when BAM I hit a couple lucky cards and breezed past the boss battle in about 40 seconds. I do not see this necessarily as a knock on the game as I feel it was really designed as a card game of choice and chance (with some deckbuilding elements mixed in) first and an action title second. I would

Atmposphere is where this game really excels and has to be my #1 reason for giving this the thumbs up. From the narrator to the combat level layout and on to the basic but very fitting card art I get drawn in every playthrough. I strongly feel this is a title best played in the one or two runs per session.

I am enjoying this title and recommend it to anyone who wants to try something different. There are some RNG frustrations that would make it a tough sell to some and Mechanically the combat gets a bit repetitive.

7/10

reviewText:
Introduction:
Hand of Fate is a mix between a tabletop card game and an action/RPG video game, with some added tarot, fantasy and roguelike inspiration thrown in.  Featuring hundreds of items, armor, weapons, artifacts, curses, blessings, encounters and quests, every single playthrough is unique.  On top of that, the deck-building mechanic adds even more variety as you customize your deck to suit your needs and playstyle.  All of this across two modes of gameplay.  Whew, someone deal the cards already!

TLDR Highlights:
++ Playthrough Randomness
++ Quest Cards
++ Deckbuilding System
++ Voice Acting
+ Action Combat
+ Visuals/Graphics

- Frustrating Chance and Luck of the Draw
- Single Player Only

= Truly an amazing game!  I wish I had thought of it.  Highly recommended!

Review:
PROS -- At the top of my list is the randomness of each playthrough.  Sure, you'll see the same cards a lot, but no two hands will ever be the same.  There are so many factors and variables at work that each time you play will be a different experience.  This is huge for me, because it's what will keep me coming back for more.

One of the most fun features I've found in Hand of Fate are the quest cards.  These often have interesting situations, stories and adventures, that you get to see unfold right then or spread across several games if the quest has multiple parts.  Fun stuff and, again, keeps me coming back for more!

Which brings me to the deckbuilding system.  By completing quest cards, defeating bosses, and other such things, you'll recieve tokens (which work similar to booster packs in a TCG) giving you more cards to add to your deck.  You can let the game recommend and build your deck for you, or you can hand select individual cards to build your own deck.  Granted, this system may seem pretty standard, but there was something about winning tokens and unlocking new cards that consistently gets me excited throughout the game.  Not to mention that it adds variety to my deck, which -- you guessed it! -- keeps me coming back for more.

When it comes to voice acting, the dealer character is the only one that has any dialogue.  That being said, I don't think they could have found a better voice actor for the job.  It's done extremely well, and fits perfectly with the theme.  Not only that, but the script is excellent, because his idle chat and card/situation specific dialogue never seems to get old and has a genuine feel to it.

Mixing action RPG (Batman/Shadow of Mordor-esque) combat might have been a risking move on the developers part, but it was executed very well.  Combat starts out ridiculously easy as it teaches game mechanics, but as your deck gets stronger the enemies do too, thus making the fights more challenging.  A lot of reviewers say it's too easy all the way through, but I guarantee they died in combat plenty of times, and if they didn't then they didn't play very far into the game.  I will agree that combat might not be very complex, but it's fun and satisfying, and just challenging enough to mesh well with card game without drowning it out.

The last pro" I have to add is that the visuals and graphics
recommended: are really quite good.  It's all very pleasing to look at
hoursPlayed: and I was particularly impressed with the combat scenery.  The card artwork was well done too
voteText: and the theme fit perfectly.\n\nCONS --  Not much to add here
helpfulPercent: but like any card game
votesHelpful: sometimes it comes down to the luck of the draw
votesTotal: which I can attest does not always go your way.  And it can be frustrating at times
votesFunny: especially later in the game when a single misstep can be very dangerous and potentially cost you the game.  Some people find this intolerable
commentsCount: but I don't really mind it that much.  It's a card game
column16: after all
column17: and chance is part of the territory.  Besides
column18: there are blessing cards to help tip things it your favor (curse cards to make it worse too
column19: so watch out).  And when you have to pick a card to determine success or failure
column20: it's made so that you can try to follow movement of the card you want during the shuffle.  Still
column21: it can be quite punishing at times
column22: which turns some people off.\n\nFinally
column23: I'm disappointed that there's no multiplayer.  Not entirely sure how it would work in this game
column24: but I'd love to play a card game like this with friends!\n\nOVERALL --  There's so much to like about Hand of Fate
column25: and very little to complain about. Without a doubt
column26: this is one of the best games in my steam library.  I can't believe I never even heard of it until recently

I've started to notice this game because of TheReformist, therefore huge shoutout to him! https://www.youtube.com/user/ReformistTM
Go check him out. Impressive Voice, enjoyable Pace of the presented content.

If you played Binding of Isaac and really liked the increasing difficulty and the randomised Worlds you can discover, but felt that there was a story shortage or the story setting wasn't yours, Hand of Fate takes you into its medieval, fantasy world.
My personal experience with the huge amount of Early Access games that are out there is: They have Content and Gameplay, which more often than not is tossed into your face, Do or Die!". Hand of Fate is also in Early Access
date: but does an amazing job at introducing the Player to its mechanics in an enjoyable way.\n\nFacing The Dealer you journey through an ever changing deck of cards
hoursPlayed: gaining treasures and surpassing hurdles or... not. But don't falter! For each surpassed challenge your fate shuffles again and may change to your likings. For each Boss beaten the challenge increases and the world expands. Who knows what The Dealer holds for You?"

reviewText:
Worth its price and more.
Excellent concept, incredible replayability, wonderful voice acting (The Dealer is the only person speaking), cool fusion between a card game and a hack-and-slash, where the meta card game sets your abilities, equipment, blessings, curses, and challenges in the short hack-and-slash battles in closed rooms.
Great variety of cards and stories.

The downsides - can't customize your character, big discrepancy between very easy and very hard cards, the Dealer's voice actor is so good you'll wish they recorded more lines for him. Really, I'd pay more for a DLC where he talks more.

Overall, very satisfied, an 8 or 9 out of 10 (5 being an average game, so that's pretty high score).

Worth up to $40 in my opinion. DLC is worthwhile as well, but I would play the main story first and see if you like it. You'll love it or hate it. If you love it, buy the DLC before continuing.

reviewText:
I find myself moving down this dusty corridor, dodging flame traps and a spike ceiling trying to crush me.  I catch my breath for a moment, roll past some arrow traps, and grab a chest!

And my reward is some cards.  And the man across the table from me makes some cryptic statements about my past, or the history of that card, or something vague and menacing.

This is the sort of thing that happens in this game, and its amazing.

Hand of Fate can be best described as a Deck Building Action RPG hybrid.  You are a nameless someone, who has decided to play a game of life and death against a mysterious Dealer.  Your goal is to defeat the 12 members of the Dealers Card Court.  Your weapons, tools, and even dungeons are the very cards being used in the game.

I have not played for very long as I don't want to spoil the game for when I do a video playthrough of it, but suffice to say what I have played has my interest piqued.  I want to know who I am, where I came from, how I got to this place, and why this Dealer is such a snarky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Recently, the devs put out a Free content expansion, which adds another little mini story to the game.

The basic gameplay is that you have a deck of cards that you have built.  Well 2 actually: Equipment and Encounters.  The dealer then spices things up by adding cards to them, cards you have no knowledge of.  He then lays out a dungeon face down on the table, made up of cards.  You then move a token around from card to card, and experience a variety of things.  One card might be an Ambush of Skeletons, another might be meeting an Elf Lass, another might be a dangerous ravine, or a trap room.

In the case of combat, or trap rooms, the game switches to an Action RPG setup, using a combat system very similar to the new Batman Arkham games.  You can dodge, roll, attack, and eventually should you find the gear cast spells or special powers.  One power I had early on let me cause all my attacks to generate cash on the ground that I could pick up.

The devs have said the main campaign takes about 12 hours to get through, so about an hour per court member.  There is also Endless mode, which is of course Endless.

Hopefully more content updates come down the pipe as I can see myself playing this for quite a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brilliant Concept!
Interesting combination of:
-Choose your own adventure (Like those books) :: Every card in your encounter deck is like single page in that kind of book. You build your own deck from the cards you have unlocked.
-Action Adventure Game (god of war) :: While the combat is not impressive looking and visceral as those games tend to be, the combat has strategic and dynamic elements to keep you on your toes.
-Rogue Like :: Rogue likes have always been about exploration and resource management. This game offers that in spades.


When I played this for first few runs, I thought that Soon I've seen all the encounters and items so it will lose it's charm" but I discovered that some of the encounter cards are not set in stone. They have multiple "forms". For example encounter called "Rock Fall" had very different conclusion.
Also when player is given "random" positive or negative conclusion to encounter the player draws from Four different cards.
Cards can be any combination of Fail
hoursPlayed:
Greater Success.
The fact that player is physically show the shuffle of these cards gives him opportunity to follow how the cards move and can eliminate possibilities.

Also every encounter with "red spot" on it
voteText:
is part of a quest of sorts. When dealt with correctly will unlock the next part of the quest available for your encounter deck. This is very neat way of not making the game all about getting to the boss but the path to the boss is also important.

So that this review would not be complete hype lets bring up few issues:
-Combat is every now and then very easy. When there are 1-4 opponents you can overwhelm the enemy quickly because your "auto targeting" attacks send you flying across the map. You feel like juggernaut from Dota 2
-Block / Counter animations are too slow compared to your normal ones. You feel like everyone in the game stops for your to do your animation.
-Enemies NEVER attack at same time. There is always only single enemy swinging a sword + one ranged enemy ready to fire.
-Block / Counter "quick-time" prompts show for too long. I feel like being babied into the game. I wish there was some difficulty settings about this.
-Blood. Game really needs blood right now the swings rarely give me that satisfaction. I barely get any feedback from hitting the enemy. Its even harder to discern how much damage I've done or have I actually killed one of my enemies without any blood splatters.

As you can see Most gripes I have are in the combat of the game. Thankfully the combat still feels fun but could be more.
And HEY! It's not all about the combat anyway. :3"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCurrently frustration outweighing fun for me personally.  Needs more balancing.  Certain cards produce encounters that are laughably easy and others that are pure hell.  You are literally at the mercy of total randomness in this game.  Queen of Dust fight brought realization as to how wierd and sluggish combat can be.  Combat tries to be like Batman Arkham games yet more linear and slow with one to two combat animations and no exciting combos to my knowledge.   Spent entire QoD fight lunge diving to evade and waiting to strike someone and thought to myself how ridiculous this mechanic is and has been in past fighting games.  If shield cards or blessings rolled may have been easier fight yet in my experience this is fith time fighting her and found nothing useful on my way to her so far.  Player seems to have enormous hitbox and compared to enemies and because of the stationary camera during fights it is easy to misjudge distance at a critical time.  Don't feel as if I am making any substantial progress in the game.  You unlock new cards but may never see them in a playthrough and more often than not they wont help you anyway (and can also possibly hurt you).  Once a new act is started you lose all equipment and have to pull from the deck all over again to gain items.  Mixed feelings about the game overall so far.

reviewText:
My overall rating for Hand of Fate: 100/100

Hand of Fate is something I was missing for a long time. Card deckbuidling game mixed with RPG-games, all hidden in a rogue-like coat. The game is hard, shows no mercy, yet is enjoyable as hell. Let's see why.

GAMEPLAY

+ Card game base
+ Real-time fights
+ Roguelike board game
+ Various encounters
+ Cards are changing and getting more difficult
+ Strategy needs to be changed a lot
+ Well made DLCs!
o Sometimes clunky controls (training is needed :-D )
- Luck is needed (lack of it can be potential game-ender)

Gameplay is based on solving cards, either through choices, or you have to deal with threat personally in combat. As you progress further, game becomes more and more difficult, but there is one thing that has to be cleared. Game is rogue-like, so if it seems unfair to you, then it is right and you have to try your luck.

That can be frustrating sometimes, because hardly defeatable encounter with full gear can be your first card in dungeon! Anyway, both DLCs added some cards and new strategies to defeat upcoming challenges. Still, with all possibilities, the game is a step ahead. Bugged achievements got fixed, so good luck!

VISUALS

+ Marvelous art style
+ Formidable combat
+ Backgrounds and battlefields
- Minor bugs and glitches

There is nothing I can complain about visual style. Cards are stylish, they are looking like an old card game played in some mysterious temple. The atmosphere is mystical and full of tension and expectations. Combat is also perfectly created, though, some creatures might get bugged after hits, but that seems more funny than annoying to me.

CHARACTERS

+ Dealer and Warrior
+ Story

It is a game of life and death. Just the Dealer and unknown Warrior. Nothing more or less. Perfect.

SOUNDTRACK

+ Arabic-style songs
+ Credit song

Jeff van Dyck showed us many excellent performances and this music belongs to one of his best. Arabic-themed songs are adding its piece to whole impression of this mystical game. My favourites - Life and Death, Welcome to the Game, Deal of the Millenia, Dead Skin, Dune Storm, Hand of Fate (Instrumental) and Hand of Fate.

SUMMARY

Card game with real fights, what more can be desired? With music of that kind and perfect voice-acting it was a pleasure to play and discover the secrets of this game. And also to return to it again. Many mysteries were revealed and more are awaiting to be. But is it possible? Let's find out. Perhaps ;-)

reviewText:
I got attached to Hand of Fate pretty quick.  It's a real fun RPG card game.  Basically you're sitting across the table of a card dealer.  He deals you cards and that determines what enemies you fight, where you fight and items you get.  You also gain loot by chance by flipping cards or winning fights.  Sometimes there's a character on a card and you can select answers when they speak.  Unlike other card games, when the level and enemies have been drawn you're character is warped into that world and you really fight them!  I've found that the controls are just like the Batman Arkham series when using Xbox controller.  The game is fun right from the start and easy to figure out.

Pros
Card game and battle adventure game
Easy to learn
Game outcome depends on cards drawn and player choice
Graphics
Controls

Cons
Lack of game info.  While the game is easy to learn I wish it had an info page to give a breakdown on what everything does to serve as a reminder.  Like what cards do what, the rules on food, buying and selling, etc.

reviewText:
The game's not bad, but maybe not for full price. For 5$ - definitely worth it, for 10$ - worth it if you're into roguelike games.
18 hours was enough to finish story mode and endless mode to wave 30 (on medium difficulty), and it doesn't feel like there is much replayability beyond this unless you're really into getting all the achievements.
Combat is way more responsive than i thought it would be, so that's a plus. The type of battle is about on shadow of mordor/batman level (more simplified of course, but similar idea with hits/counters/finishes). Game has controller support too, which can make battle better/easier.
Luck is a huge factor. Yes, you can get really bad runs with horrible loot and overpowered monsters, but you can also get great runs where everything goes super smooth. Skill also counts, if you're really good - you do have a chance of defeating toughest enemies with starting equipment, you just gotta pay attention and fight hard!

reviewText: This game is one of those rare gems that exceeds expectations. The game combines and rpg with a card game quite well, the gameplay switches between going through a board made of cards into live action combat and back again. It is quite clear the developers put a lot of work into making this game. The dealer and your antagonist makes the game feel quite interactive as he narrarates your story. reviewText:
Stop reading reviews and just buy this game! It's absolutely worth the full price, and being on sale makes it a no-brainer!

This is an amazing game to keep you busy between larger games, or just as something to play to unwind before bed. There's not a ton of over-arching story, which makes it ideal for dipping into for a few minutes at a time, even if you let weeks pass between play sessions.

The general mechanic is that you've died, and are playing a card game against death. Death deals a set of cards that create a dungeon for your character to play through. Each card is a different room or event for you to play through, with everything from gambling events to stores to story-driven events to combat. Each dungeon you play through unlocks new cards -- both equipment for your adventurer as well as rooms and events to play through.  The next time Death deals a dungeon, it will be slightly longer than the last one you played through.

One of the best mechanics is that when you hit a combat" room
date: you actually "dive into" the card and control your adventurer as he fights the minions from the card. The combat mechanics are simple
recommended: but surprisingly fun. The minions have enough variation in attacks and style that combat never becomes dull
hoursPlayed: even though you have to fight several mobs per dungeon.\n\nThe devs are also great people. They've added a ton of new contenet since the games release
voteText: and as you play through you'll notice their little DLC expansions peppered through -- you always have the option to dive into DLC from the main game. I hope they keep releasing these expansions!\n\nSo all in all
helpfulPercent: this game is a no-brainer. It isn't likely to be one that you sit down an play through entirely without breaks
votesHelpful: but it makes a perfect distraction between larger games or just for a short session at night. Add it to your collection now!"

reviewText:
- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -

Rating Must Play

- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------
Play time needed (perfect) About 60 hours.
Gaming level from Casual to Gamer
Achievement level between Casual and Gamer
Game style Role-Playing-Game (choices, encounter); Card game (deck building, encounters, equipment); Fighting; Rogue-like (treasure vault)
Game modes Story mode; Endless mode
Story Throught the role-play.
Playthrough One (story), One (endless)
Voice Only the dealer, very good !
Music Good too !
Camera Not bad !
Controls Keyboard or Controller (#)
Tutorial Yes !
Unmissable / backtracking content Yes !
Customization Yeah, cards and character.
Download contents DLC Yes, one additional needed, the other is the soundtrack.
Glitches / bugs Good one. (*)
Worth price It definitely worth its price ($28) even if it can be hard to get through some encounters or achievements.

- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------
Such an awesome game indeed ! The music is good, the dealer's voice is great with his speeches, the deck of card is really wide and so the choices too !

The story mode let you beat each Jack, Queen and King of each 4 series through chapters. At the end of each chapter you have to deal with the Jack or Queen or King with a battle, a kind of small boss ! When you beated 3 or 4 of them you unlock a starting bonus and malus. When you succeed any encounter you unlock more cards by acquiring its token. Also each chapter have their own encounters, curses, blessings and shop that are added to the deck.

The battle are played in real time with the stuff you got, the highest combo you make the heavier you attack. You need to manage your health and many items can help you like shields (reflect projectiles, counter attack, stun), artifacts (magical spells) and others ! You can also discover some vault to steal some gold if you dare avoiding all the traps ! There are also many ennemies you can defeat, many encounters and lot of gold to gain and spend but do not forget to buy food before starving to death ! Don't worry you can still continue your journey while starving, but you'll soon need to find supplies before your last breath.

In this game there is also a part of luck, you can still see the shuffle to guess where the card will be if you are able good enough or you can also have some equipments or blessing that will help you a lot. Also some fight can be really tough but you can easily get the strongest equipment you can to succeed every battle.

(#):
There is at least one little annoying thing with the controller, you can be really precise that much while you're moving. Indeed, when you're facing north and want to get south you'll need to go in circles instead of turning back. So that may be a little tougher to avoid traps.

(*):
The good thing is you can quit the game whenever you want and resume it before you reached the previous encounter. So you can use that to avoid death or avoid some encounters failures whenever you want.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will not comment on game play, since that has probably been explained a million times over in other reviews and videos. But this I will say:

The Dealer is your Narrator, as well as your Savior and your Opponent. He has offered you the chance to play his Game. As the Player, you are in charge of a pawn - a nondescript adventurer. You are given cards upon which the Game is played. You build the pawn's equipment deck, and the story's encounter deck. The Dealer will deal out the cards and lead you on an incredible tale of greed, hubris and honor. Your pawn will face endless, faceless foes as well as specific boss villains. There will be violence, traps, treasure and horror. The Dealer will attempt to entice you to send your pawn into situations most peril for the offer of a few tokens. These tokens unlock more cards, which unlock more adventure and equipment/treasure.

And as you defeat each boss villain, the Dealer will put the card into his cabinet, where you will be able to choose the next villain. Defeat a row of villains, gain a special item. But beware, every Game, every card, every victory will add to the complexity and danger that your pawn will face as you struggle to reach and win the final Game. Your pawns will die, but never fear - there are countless pawns waiting for you to guide them.

Who is this man in the robe, who created these cards that influence a world, individuals and items? Who are you, Player? Are we Gods who are meant to play with the lives of mortals? Maybe.

You'll have play to experience it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite an interesting game that is part deckbuilding TCG and part Arkham City's combat engine. The random nature of the game and path toward your goal, along with building your deck to make that journey easier on you, makes the replay value surprisingly high. As you progress you unlock more enemies to fight, dangers to face, and equipment to find or purchase from vendors.

As Early Access games go, I'm not even sure why it's considered Early Access, this already seems like a full fledged game worth it's pricetag. Highly recommended for those that want to take a risk on something fun and interesting.

reviewText:
This is a great game, and definitely worth the money, although getting it on sale makes it a no-brainer.

It's essentially a dungeon crawler where your equipment and encounters are determined at random by the cards you put in your deck.  The challenges get progressively harder but are relatively easy until about 2/3 of the way through, when the difficulty ramps up considerably.  The combat is akin to a slightly less polished Batman-esque attack, doge, shield bash type affair, it's still quite fun.  Voices, music, and sound are all pretty good, but is that really the reason you're buying this thing?  The game is probably good for about 15 hours for a playthrough.

The negatives have been touched on in other reviews but those that stand out to me are the fate" based challenges you'll encounter here or there.  It's true that
recommended: getting the right card (success or fail) becomes a complete guessing game.  This negative in no way detracts from an otherwise awesome game.  While the randomness may bother some people

reviewText:
TL;DR: Excellent visualization of what's happening in your head, when you play board-game IRL
We all love board-games, don't we? The only problem with them is that there's too much left for the imagination. If only there'd be a game with board-game rules and visualization of, say, Diablo III or Torchlight, or something similar... If you ever had a thought like that (and I know that I did), you're welcome to buy Hand of Fate as soon as you'll finish reading this review.

Hand of Fate is a game that's very simple to play, yet very complex to explain: basically, it's a card game, where you move your token from card to card, encounter monsters, treasures and various obstacles. At the end of each scenario, you fight a boss. Though, the complex thing is that when you encounter an enemy, the game turns in something or an action-RPG with you controlling your hero, using skills and items to actually fight your enemies in real time.

Graphics are good, I did enjoy both hacking and slashing, and browsing through on-board adventures (not all of the cards include you teleporting to the arena and fighting monsters, obviously enough). The dealer is a nifty masked dude with creepy yet charismatic voice (you might expect a new announcer with it in Dota 2, though), which follows his own rules and easily admits defeat if you slay his henchmen.

As you progress through the storyline, you encounter more powerful enemies and gather a stronger loot. Every scenario is unique, thanks to the randomizer -- you can even call these levels procedurally generated, rogue-like style: every time you start over, both scenario decks (yours and dealer's) are shuffled, and you're getting a new adventure each time you start over.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

I'd strongly recommend this game to all of the RPG fans out there -- it's a breath of refreshing air on the modern RPG scene, really. If you're not into RPG, you might want to check the game out anyway -- it's well-done and interesting to play overall.

Rating: 8.9 out of 10.0

reviewText:
I feel like I could sit around and play this game forever. The Game Master is your opponent. He sits across from you. Antagonizing, and narrating your every move. You best him and his cards/minions through puzzles, combat, and games of chance laid out before in a free to explore maze of face down cards.

Success brings you gold, supplies, and equipment to brave his more challenging tricks, and traps. Each victory brings you better, stronger cards. Magical swords and armor. But, each success also gives him more cards to use against you. More traps and dangers for you to stumble into.

Truly a great game, and a must have for your steam library.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Roguelike collectible card game dungeon delver brawler roleplaying game
+ The dealer's narration is spot-on and immersive; some of the best voice-acting I've heard
+ Graphics and ambient sounds are amazingly detailed
+ Customizable decks allow you to play like you want
+ Fun side-adventures that have unexpected consequences
+ Collecting cards through gameplay allows for deeper and varied customization of your deck to fit whatever is needed
+ Manages to stay fun, fresh and challenging the whole way through
+ Enemies grow stronger with you, challenges get harder, random chance gets stacked against you... it's great
+ Rewards skill while still utilizing luck of the draw
+ Overall polished final product - and it shows
+ I have never felt this conflicted about beating a final boss
+ Developers are invested and involved with the community; are releasing more new content to continue spicing up the game

Cons:
- Typical repetitiveness that comes with any roguelike game (Mr. Lionel, hello, give me my shield please and I'll be on my way)
- Typical aggravation associated with chance-only games (that treasure chest cost me half my health with nothing to show for it)

Overall:  This is a game that seems strange at first, but then after the first game, I realized I was playing something inspired.  You make your deck, then the dealer adds his own cards to it.  These cards make up the dungeon" and are placed face down (mostly) randomly.  You move your avatar from one card to the next to explore each dungeon

reviewText:
Hand of Fate began as a Kickstarter campaign that was successfully funded on Dec. 13, 2013. Defiant Development asked for a modest amount of $50K, but what is Hand of Fate? Well, it is a table top card game with deck building mechanics that also has rogue-like elements, RPG elements, and a combat system similar to Batman: Arkham City or Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor.


30 Second Review
+ Unlock new cards by playing the game

+ Lots of replayability

+ Cards add a new dimension to procedurally generated content

– Cards are stylized after Tarot cards

– The game’s difficulty increases quickly and may discourage casual gamers

I am normally HORRIBLE at games like this but I've been having a blast so far!!

I am really enjoying the way the cards work, the story, and the voice acting is spot on as well. Many games neglect the voice acting so it is always very refreshing when it is done well in an Indie title such as this. :)

My only gripe is that I feel like the combat is a little awkward with the camera angles. I've learned to adapt and can still play just fine but sometimes it gets a little frustrating trying to block incommng blows if you get a poor angle on your hero. That is really my only complaint though which is really just a tiny nit pick more than a game breaking problem. :P

Other than that, I just love everything. Even playing with the cards that the computer recommends haha.

Honestly this game is worth the full price of $24.99 so I wouldn't hesitate in grabbing it along with the wildcard DLC. Supporting the devs of well made Indie games helps them to grow and make more treasures for us to play. Cheers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Beta First Impressions.

http://youtu.be/TFnNYpJ6DGQ

The game is extremely fascinating, combing a trading card game, with action rpg and rogue like. Many would have failed and given the public a hobbled mess of slapped on features. Instead Defiant have wonderfully crafted the game and mechanics, so as to make you feel like you're being guided by a Poker dealing Dungeon Master.

I was pleasantly surprised by how well the it all blends together and plays. The game is still in development, and I have never liked the idea of Early Access, but Hand of Fate certainly has amazing promise. The music is good, although not finished, and the graphics despite using the unity engine runs and looks really well. Although sadly the maximum resolution was only 1920x1080. Something easily forgiven due to the game still actively being worked on.

I certainly enjoy it, and I look forward to playing more as it develops.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When I think about fantasy RPGs they tend to involve a whole lot of fighting and the occasional tavern break to play some dice or card games against the locals. In Hand of Fate you play cards with the occasional break for fighting. The combat is a little repetitive but encounters never last very long and is still fairly enjoyable.

The card game itself, though, is great - a sort of progressive deck-builder with dealer-supplied cards thrown in to shake things up. You move across a randomised map of location cards, resolving the conflicts on each as you pass them, and gaining (or losing!) loot and resources as you make your way to the boss for the level. Then you start again for the next level... but with a couple new cards, a few new story items and a new item or two up for grabs.

The style, story and narration are also quite charming and really add to the overall feeling and aesthetic of the game.

reviewText:
I didn't really expect much when I bought this, but it looked intruiging so I gave it a try. And I'm happy I did so, because this game is pretty great. It's not easy to describe. You play cards like in a mixture of a collectible card game and a board game, but it has also RPG-mechanics, a little bit of story, quests, descisions and an action based combat system. At first I thought that the latter was a bit too simple but I gotta admit - it's a lot of fun. Very fast paced, reaction based and dependent on what cards you already got, concerning equipment and abilities.

And then there's the dealer of course. And this guy .. he really doesn't want you to win. It's great how he tells you little stories about what's happening and next thing you know, he throws you one of his own cards in your way and all goes to hell.

I really, really like this game and I'm looking forward to playing more of it.

To say this game is ingenious would possibly be the understatement of the year.

If this game were a woman, I would want her as my girlfriend, and I would stroll with her through the town square and feel my chest swell with immense pride and pleasure at the envying glances of others. I would thank the grace of fortune for having stumbled upon her and won her to my side. She'd be a woman of elegant beauty and subtle wit, possessed of a personality combining old-school sensibilities with modern flair. She'd be open to endless possibilities of adventure, unpredictable in her actions but kind enough to warn me ahead of time as to what she might have planned for me, allowing me time to prepare myself accordingly. Sure, she might try to knife me in the back from time to time, but she'd also have a fondness for surprising me with mind-blowing wakeup sex.

Even after time bred more familiarity with her mercurial nature, I'd still find her to be a walking Wand of Wonder, and every day with her would be an awesome exercise of What's Next?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was a pleasant surprise!
It’s a bit or RPG Strategy mixed into a dungeon crawling type of story with some hack and slash combat. You interact with, use, or equip cards for the main aspects of the game, and gain more cards as time goes on (depending on your success/failure). If you don’t like a card, you can remove it from the deck and not play with it again later (as long as you have enough cards required for the play through).  This deck building aspect allows you to choose what possible events you encounter in your adventure.

It’s hard to summarize this game without going in depth since there are so many different things from so many different genres here; however, you’re pretty likely to find something you like about the game. I will admit that it can become repetitive depending on how you arrange your deck, and the combat might turn into button spamming, but you don’t have to let it...you can play the game as you choose.

What is nice about this game is that you can either go “endless”, or use the “story mode” which gives you “break points” as you finish each piece once you beat the boss at the end of the dungeon. Like I said, it’s hard to explain...but you’re bound to like at least a couple aspects of this games layout. I enjoy the dialogue from the card master quite a bit and it really adds character to the game.


The Bad News:  This game is a currently an unoptimized resource hog. It has memory leak issues. After about 30 minutes of play today, Windows was asking me to close the program because it had nearly 3 GB of RAM in use and was eating resources like crazy. (It didn’t crash, but Windows noted the issue, and presented the event to me for action.)

Once this game is optimized, I think it will become very popular with the gaming community.

reviewText: I overwhelmingly encourage anyone who enjoys 3rd person combat and dungeon crawling to pick up this game.  It's not a card game.  Not at all. It's all about the dungeon crawl, planning your resource usage, and then good old fashioned 3rd person action hack and slash.  Amazingly well thought out game.  Worth every penny.

reviewText:
this game is the definition of wasted potential. sure it's fun for the first couple hours. you'll breeze past the first half of the content in about 2-4 hours, but once you get about two thirds of the way through, the game takes a massive difficulty spike. the game starts reusing old boss fights, but they use them along side other groups of enemies, in addition to the ones that that the boss comes bundled with. see every time you fight a boss they summon 2-4 enemies to fight along side them at the start of the battle. it's impossible to fight *just* a boss. this wouldn't be a huge problem, except that in addition to fighting the bosses again, with more enemies this time, the bosses and their mooks are all powered up, they have more health, and more (and more powerful) moves. now all of theses things combine would be challenging, but managable if not for one major flaw: the arenas in which you fight get smaller and smaller as the game progresses. at the start of the game you fight 1 boss and about 2-3 enemies in a REALLY big arena making it possible to divide and conquer, and avoid attacks. by the end of the game, you can wind up facing about 10+ enemies including 2 bosses in an arena about a quarter of the size in which you found the original boss encounter. oh by the way the second to last boss is in one of the smallest arenas in the game, spawns with 4 ranged units with shields, has undblockable attacks, can block attacks himself, AAAANNNNNDDDDD his minions can't be killed until AFTER you kill the boss. oh and his unkillable minions (seemingly intentionally) position themselves between you and the big guy, and even when they aren't in your way, sometimes your character just seems to ignore him. the autoaim on your attacks seem to prioritize his unkillable minions for some reason, and even when he's alone, it will just ignore him entirely.


all of this only outlines the problems with the combat encounters. most of the other encouters in the game are strictly luck based, and rely entirely on you winning a 25% roll, or you lose most of your equipment/health/provisions.

all I can say is, I hope the devs look at this game, figure out all the stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they got wrong, and make an awesome sequel, because if not for its compeletly unforgivable, unignorable, experience ruining flaws, this game would be in the running for the greatest game I've ever played. that said, don't buy it. it's not worth you money because you'll never be able to actually beat it without getting incredibly lucky and I mean that literally, no matter how well you play, no matter how clever you are, most of the game comes down to situations where you have a 75-100% chanace of immediately dying a completely unvoidable death.


--------------------------------------------------------------------
Response to developer's comment:

the graveyard deals a ton of damage (I think I lost like 45 health most of it in max health reduction) to you if you are cursed, and you are always cursed passed the first wing if I'm not mistaken (100% chance for a negative, potentially run ruinning outcome especially on levels like the king of scales where you lose health/food/gold randomly and can easily starve). also the treasure chest goes from being a nearly garunteed free gain to a nearly garunteed chance to lose most of your health to gas and a mimick (again, often in permanent health reduction). those are the ones that come to mind right now, but I know there are others.

basically some cards like the graveyard have a garunteed negative outcome if you don't know what they do ahead of time and put them in your deck at the wrong time, and others go from being really good during the early stages of the game to just being a death sentence later like treasure chest.

now don't get me wrong, I don't mind that the cards change as the game progresses, I mind that they change completely *without any warning.* if the game told you ahead of time that certain encounters where going to get more difficult that would be one thing, but when an important part of my strategy for getting a good run going with decent gear arbitrarily decides to kill me with out warning... that's when I get a bit upset.

my reccomendation would be to put a level indicator on encouters similar to the monster cards to warn you hey this has a much bigger chance to go south
date: you sure you still want it in your deck?" but instead you have to learn that it can screw over your entire run by having it screw over your entire run
recommended: and that really sucks.\n\nall that said
hoursPlayed: I love the ideas you guys put into the game
voteText: it's really REALLY cool
helpfulPercent: it's just that the luck vs. skill could use a little bit of balancing more towards skill --or at least informed deck building-- and the arenas just get way to small and crowded to fight in later on and both those things really ruin an otherwise ingenious game.\n\noh and btw

reviewText:
A really strange mix between a beat'em all and an RPG.
The narrative part is very well done and you unlock differents parts of various stories as you complete challenges given by cards.
Each card presents an event or an equipement, and each game shuffle your deck of events randomly to give you a challenge.
The battle system is inspired by the Batman Arkham series and if not perfect (because it stays pretty basic), does its job.
The RNG is present and sometimes can be a ♥♥♥♥♥. (Davy Jones, give me back my soul !).
But the more vicious challenges tends to give the more interesting rewards (and if it's too hard, don't keep them in the deck).

Several challenges are kept in the deck in order to unlock others events so you end up by keeping the difficult one only to complete them once.

For an indie game, graphics are also really great and animations well executed. Presentation is top notch. The amount of work in this gem should have been huge.

Reminds me the books where you are the hero.
The result is original, well refined, and gives a game that you actually want to complete.

Early Access Review

This game is loads of fun, and really addictive. It combines a simple-to-learn (but challenging) combat system with the randomness of an old-school story-telling collectible card game (such as Mythos).

In short, each session you navigate your character through a serious of cards (that represent scenarios) in a game. Each card is effectively a random chance for loot, health, upgrades or monsters. When a monster card is drawn, you fight the monster(s) in a third-person view and gain treasure. At the end of a game"
date: you fight a boss monster. If you win
recommended: you gain new scenario cards and bosses to add to your deck. Each time you play
hoursPlayed: the cards are shuffled - so your scenarios are randomised as well!\n\nEach session is quick
voteText: and exciting. I recommend this to fans of the boardgame Talisman

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing mix of rogue-lite with good old choose your own adventure" books (here cards). Dressed up in nice visuals and great atmosphere thanks to awesome narrator.

-> You build decks from collected cards as a base for your journey and means to enhance your character
-> You travel through randomly generated levels (based on the cards you picked) with various events
date:
decisions and encounters
-> All battles are resolved via good old hack'n'slash 3rd person action

8 hrs of fun to complete the main story and then the Endless Mode awaits. Well worth your money.

PROS:
+ Unique and interesting gameplay
+ Great atmosphere and narration
+ Good graphics and varied environments (for encounters)
+ Fluent and responsive combat
+ Varied enemies and interesting bosses
+ Lot of replay value

CONS:
- Static camera sometimes sucks
- RNGesus may screw you over

BONUS PRO: First game ever where I stayed in the main menu on purpose just to watch and enjoy the atmosphere. ^_^"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hand of Fate isn't done yet at the time of writing, but it is in beta, and it is pretty close to done. As such, I'm just going to punch out a quick little note about it:

This game is actually close to done, unlike most early access titles. If the idea of a roguelike game where you control the things you encounter to some extent, with combat vaguely based on the Arkham series, then this game might interest you. If you don't think that sounds interesting, don't buy it.

I would recommend holding off on buying it and playing it until after it is finished, as in its present state it still needs some balancing tweaks, but the core of the game really is there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hands of Fate is, usurprisingly, the hidden pearl of the new EC Humble Bundle. Hidden behind the $15 dollar paywall, it's most likely the one game people won't bother paying the extra few bucks to check out.

Shame on them.

The game is, hands down (ba dum tsh), awesome. For those of you living under a rock and that have never any of the Extra Credits reviews of this game (they actually did it twice), lemme summurize it for ya:

The game is a cross between card game, Arkham City arena battles, and choose-your-adventure book. Basically you have a table with face-down cards and a character token that moves through those cards. Each card is an Event card, which can range from You have been ambushed by Goblins who took your stuff" stage
date: made classic by the Golden Axe games
recommended: a maze stage filled with traps
hoursPlayed: or a plain-text event where you have to use your wits to avoid being on the receiving end of a prostate exam. The It's Toasted of the game is that during combat events the game zooms in and you control your character (with customizable gear!) to fight the hordes of enemies in the aforementioned Arkham City arena battles. It's pretty neat

You "improve" (as much as adding harder challenges is an improvement) by acquiring cards after beating the dealer's challenges along stages. So no way this is gonna be monetised in the future. Yey!\n\nThe game is still in Early Access
