reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short:
Hand of Fate is a weird concept that plays out surprisingly well. Very much unfinished and unpolished as of now, but the core concept is well done and people that enjoy games like FTL will probably get some fun out of this too. Fun, but there are caveats.


Long:
The Good:

The strange genre mix plays out surprisingly well, with the ability to influence your dungeon and the RNG parts by careful considerations. The fighting system is heavily influenced by batmans free flow. The voiceover and presentation is atmospheric and the unlock system itself is telling a story. There are many interesting items and effects that keep runs fresh even after failing coupled with the unlocks.

The Bad:

The combat is at times clunky, sometimes bordering unfair and the camera can get into weird angles. Some items and effects are poorly balanced and the RNG can really screw you over sometimes. The aesthetics are ok, but it's no AAA title of course. Restarting a run does takes 30 seconds because of the presentation, that should really be skippable (and sometimes the token animation). For some token encounters, you have not the slightest clue how to get them.

The Ugly:

Terrible optimization (as of now): some rooms and angles can make your framerate dip very significantly but it doesn't offer a proper graphics options menu, only presets. Also, for some reason it is a big memory hog (in excess of 2GB).  I was unable to play the combat with KB+mouse as it didn't register the mouse buttons. Works fine with a controller, but that should work anyway. The key rebinding in the launcher is bad, listing controls for 9 gamepads (wtf?) and binding for attacks on KB+mouse didn't work for me.

reviewText: I played this game first at the first PSX, 2014 in Las Vegas. Some how I missed this games kickstarter, and man was I mad that I missed it. I was extremely happy and lucky to be given one of their printed cards regardless, becuase I was attending PSX. Getting to chat with some of the developers was really neat, and I expressed how much I liked the game there, as I am here. The idea of taking a deck-building/shuffling game, and stuffing RPG, brawling, rogue-lite dungeon crawler all into one package seemed so inovative to me, and appealed to a lot of the game types I like. I was very surprsied when I was sitting down playing and the combat opened up for the first time, but I had loads of fun with the two boss fights they let me play through. I'm happy to have finally gotten a copy of this game, and love it.

reviewText:
This game lives or dies by its atmosphere and presentation. Lucky for it, Hand of Fate nails both. The voice-acting for the dealer is spectacular and easily on-par with Triple-A developers. The card dealing mechanic is well-delivered and helps keep the game feeling quite different with each runthrough. Missing a chance to earn a token is heartbreaking, mostly because you don't know what little nugget of the game was just pulled out of your grasp and how you could have used or played it in a future game run.

The game isn't without its issues, and most of them are related to combat. Using a controller just isn't an option for me personally. It doesn't feel right. But nor is the mouse-and-keyboard combo ideal, given you're restricted to just the eight cardinal directions. But pulling off a serious combo is still satisfying, and ultimately, the combat system is just a vessel for the greater card-dealing system, which is the meat of this game. Combat, ultimately, is passable. It doesn't bog the game down.

Oh. And the music. Yes, that music.

reviewText:
Fun game so far. Not finished but:

Combat might or might not get deeper than it is - counter/reflect projectiles, dodge roll, stun, and combo multipliers.

In many encounters the difficulty seems to be mainly from managing both the actual enemies and the arena itself which can be laden down with traps. Even at the start I find it taxing to manage both, but the game doesn't seem to expect you to be able to come out unscathed. The other part of the difficulty is managing resources as you move through grid dungeons.

The story itself is deliberately vague so far, it fits the setting and the delivery from the deckmaster really sells it. The game might be hinting at a deeper story involving the character's past, or it might just be dressing for the nature of the game, it's hard to tell. I'd condiser it a bonus if there's a payoff, but what's already here definitely nails the atmosphere.

I'd say the atmosphere is definitely the game's strong suit, and the developers did a really good job with the little details such as using expanding lighting on load, sound effects for things like the opening of the token bowl and dropping of items. The game also knows its exact limits in terms of graphics and animation, and utilizes those things very well.

If I have a complaint so far it's mainly just that the use of the game world load for merchant visits is a little bit pointless, though the location and appearance of the shop does change with respect to what kind of shop it is and (I'm guessing) what kind of dungeon you are running.

All in all an excellent game especially at the sale price.

reviewText: Most of my time playing this game was in early access, but I recently went back and finished it. If you hate leaving a game unfinished then you may want to steer clear, but otherwise buy it  and enjoy many hours of fun!

reviewText:
To summarise - an atmospheric, rewarding and compelling game. There are other sources to explain how the game works so I won't re-explain that but I will highlight its key points.

You build a deck of equipment and encounters, then run the level with that deck of cards, making progress towards expanding your deck (and thus your options), and in the middle of all that you engage in short third-person fights with creatures/enemies. And in the middle of ALL of that, you are continually listening to the comments of the dealer, the writing for which is superb and the voice acting for which really sets a very mysterious and compelling tone to the game. Added to that the animation as all this takes place, the atmosphere of the game is extremely enticing, full of exploration, mystery and intrigue.

The deck building is compelling as it has a real impact on how you will play the level and has more depth that 'best equipment in, worst equipment out', actually requiring thought to get cards which may work well with your building of the encounters. Speaking of which, you also choose what the encounters are going to be during the level, mainly focusing on ones which you have not completed yet which in turn will expand your available cards. A very rewarding and compelling loop with surprising depth.

The little battles are not too long or onerous and as they are very short and there is a lot of variety (some variety in enemies and variety in how you play based on what equipment you've managed to acquire, completely changing your abilities) they do not get repetitive quickly.

The campaign is, as I have said, very atmospheric. It is all about exploring the encounters around you (as you don't know which ones they are), with success leading to rewards expanding your deck for the next run. There is a fair element of luck involved, which would be annoying if it weren't for the fact that you make permanent progress on each run even if you die, which means that you still feel like something was achieved.

Overall, these factors combine to make a very compelling and enjoyable experience which is highly recommended for just about everyone, since it isn't really just a 'brawler' or a 'card building game' or any of those, but a great hybrid which takes the best elements from everything in my opinion. Add to that the updates by the developers, it is one to pick up and keep playing. (And the DLC also comes highly recommended as it adds yet another element to this great game!)

reviewText:
9.5/10 (Only because player combat is a wee bit wonky)

Other then that, this game is AMAZING.  Ive only played 2 hours or so but honestly, theres so much luck, skill, and storyline, i found it hard to stop at the end of a level.  The player controlled combat is really well defined to the point where its actual skill (further than the extent of earlygame where you spam mouse 1) and could use a touch up on how you teleport/slide to counter enemies but great integration of 3rd person combat into a deckbuilding rougelike.

The decks you build are unique and you can partially decide your fate through random encounters.  You may start the game with the best weapon you shuffled into your weapon deck but next turn be held up by an angry mob that steals most your food, leaving you desperate to take any advance towards combat to earn gold to hopefully stumble across a shop to scrape by until you gather enough food to make it to the next shop, until fate decides you either run out of food and die, scrape by until the boss and have no weapon or skill advantage because youve spent no gold on gear, or by stroke of luck stumble into plentiful amounts of food. This game is tense sometimes and has seemingly infinite replayability due to custom deckbuilding and random level generation.

9.5/10 - would rate 8/8 but m8, it's too l8 to h8 your f8

reviewText: I played this game first at the first PSX, 2014 in Las Vegas. Some how I missed this games kickstarter, and man was I mad that I missed it. I was extremely happy and lucky to be given one of their printed cards regardless, becuase I was attending PSX. reviewText:
This is a really, really great game. I am so happy I found it.

First of all, the dialogue is just outstanding. Not only is it well written and well spoken, it also makes the game very easy to understand. Unlike most other cards games, you don't need to learn all cards by hand, as all of these are explained in detail whenever you draw them.

Furthermore, I am deeply a fan of the rogue-like aspect, which I never thought a card game could have. The gameplay is very original; there is no other game even close to this. Everytime you draw a card, you either gain resources, equipment, or you will enter a combat. I am still astonished at how one can combine so many different gaming aspects, whilst yet creating a wonderful game.

With no doubt, from the old RTS games I've played to the FPS games that have been dominating the planet, this is one of the best single-player games ever made.

reviewText:
This game is one of the greatest I've ever played. That's not an easy thing for me to say. Everything about this game is unique. It gets a perfect score in my book. Also, it has the all time greatest boss fight at the end of the game, hands down. I love this game to death.

The gameplay is the best part of this game, the game can twist and turn any which way when your progress is lead by pure luck. The way the card system works is very simple and easy to wrap your mind around. The combat is excellent and fluid, it's awesome to watch. The combat isn't just hacking and slashing, it's about timing blocks and dodging opponents you can't fight all at once. The combat is reminscent to the first Fable, in fact, much of this game really is a Fable game without the brand name, but the combat is so much more interesting here than in any Fable.

The graphics are lush and colourful. It has that wonderful atmospheric fantasy mood that Fable set so perfectly.

The sound quality is top notch for the most part. There is a few times when the sound does cut out but a simple restart fixes that immediately. The soundtrack is awesome and really has an epic vibe to it. I was even thinking of buying it if it's sold on Steam. It's one of those soundtracks that'll take me back years from now. I love the clanging of the swords and the thumping of swords against shields. The voice actor behind the Dealer is on the same level of deep and mesmerizing as Morgan Freeman. He's like an English Morgan Freeman, I can't stress enough how good of a voice actor he is.

The story line is interesting, it's not a normal storyline. You enter at the end of the adventurer's story. This is a retelling of all his adventures. So it's a game about retrospective and reflection. The Dealer makes very interesting remarks and ponderings that make me think on a philosophical level. What kind of game does that?

I love a game that I can put hundreds and hundreds of hours into. A game that has endless replayability and isn't limited by just having a storyline. This is one of those games. It doesn't ever have to end. There's an endless mode. There's also 200+ cards to collect. Each card is an encounter. Every game randomizes these encounters and even throws in some that benefit you and some that debilitate you to a certain extent. This game definitely earns its pay and has lot of bang for very little buck.

If you're on the fence about getting it, don't be. This game isn't hard to fall in love with. I'd recommend this game to absolutely anyone.

So far I'm loving every second of Hand Of Fate, the progression through each section is beautifully done with a great voice actor for the game master and animation of the board and cards. Each card changes you path for greater or for worse, offering you chances of possibly great loot but could also take items or health from you just as fast. It works but it does still feel like it needs a bit more polish to make it feel more responsive. Ultimately a great game for building adventures feeling like a classic adventure book/card game. Love it!

reviewText:
Do you want to make your own dungeon? And then complete it? And then fail because you were meant to complete it this time? Well then ... welcome to the RNG heaven and hell

Hand of Fate is a mix of roguelike, dungeon-crawler and deckbuilding game. While you play, the dealer will narrate what is happening on the board and you will obey while you fight your way to the dealer.

GAMEPLAY
The gameplay in Hand of Fate can be separated in several categories starting with the Deckbuilding ,Card unlocking, Dungeons"
recommended:
Encounters/Enemies and Combat. Let's get it started.

Deckbuilding

Deckbuilding is the neatest of the features I liked in the game because as said it let you make your own Dungeon. While in Endless Mode you dont have deckbuilding because you use all unlocked cards
hoursPlayed: in Story you have to build your deck
voteText: matching the required number of cards for Encounters and Equipment. While you have complete freedom in your Equipment deck
helpfulPercent:
in the Encounters one you will  see locked cards ( one of them is the end boss of the dungeon). Some of the locked cards can be removed by completing them but often leads to new locked cards.

Card Unlocking

Cards are being unlocked by receiving card tokens. And you receive card tokens when you complete an encounter for first time. And you harvest the rewards at the end of the dungeon ... or after you die( its cool that you arent being punished for dying since a lot of card unlocks can end up terribly for you) . Different cards got different requirments to be completed and gest the best of RNG doesnt mean you will get the token. Once you get to the part where token breaks to reveal cards you will be welcomed with a neat animation. From the token you can get new equipment
votesHelpful:
encounter cards or gain cards. There are several "quest" chains that are worth doing. The newly obtained cards contain no information until you encounter them in-game so you can only guess what may happen.

Dungeons

Once your deck is ready  the party starts. Dealer will setup the board with separating the different decks in piles and then he starts drawing encounter cards to form dungeon levels. Once everything is setuped you start hoping from card to card till you reach the end... your end or dungeon's end. During story every dungeon comes up with bonus ... curses which will improve your game experience(or make you rage) . Every dungeon in story mode ends up with a boss fight(if you find it before you die) that will unlocks new cards
votesTotal:
including the next level. At the end you will unlock new cards(hopefully) and will be able to increase your deck variety. While in the dungeon you have to take care of your supplies: Gold and Food. Food is beiung used on every turn and heals you.

Items/Equipment

One of your deck is filled with equipment that you can use during your adventures
votesFunny: if you get lucky to find it. You have Weapons
commentsCount: Armored
column16: Gloves
column17: Helmets
column18: Rings
column19: Artifacts(skills) and Blesses/Curses. While you can hoard all the equipments
column20:
you can change your active items before fights so you have to be picky and hope for the best. You can have only 1 active item from each category apart from Rings and Blesses/Curses. Encounters can remove any kind of item without blessing/curses(unless its stated otherwise). There are a lot of different items with their own pros and cons.

Encounters and Enemies

Ah the Encounter Deck
column21: no matter how many good encounters you put in it
column22: there will be always some that will screw everything. There are different kind of Encounters
column23: from straight fights to short text-based adventures. Almost every encounter comes with a lovely RNG that features cards and there are 2 kinds of RNG : Success/failure that are represented with Huge Success
column24: Success
column25: Failure and Huge Failure cards. The amount of cards you can pick is 4 but they depends on the encounter themselves but you always have at least 1 success/failure card and the amount of cards you have to pick from is 4 ; Enemies are also represented by cards . You have the 4 basic enemies Skulls(skeletons)
column26: Dust(bandits)
column27: Plague(rats) and Scales(Lizardmen) . Each of them got melee and range model which puts the enemy count to 8. While playing you can unlock additional enemies( I got so far Mages
column28:
Liches and Lava Golems) which put the enemy count up to 11 . And the Iceing on the cake is the boss cards. Once you beat the boss its being unlocked in the monster deck and with 12 bosses to unlock you put the enemy count up to 23. So enemy variety is quite big for this kind of Game.

Combat

Last but not least
column29: the Combat. Combat is pretty straightforward. You have Melee attack
column30: Weapon Skill
column31: Artefact Skill
column32: Counter
column33:
Stun and Dodge. So you can say that the combat is similiar to Batman or Kingdoms of Amalur but with lower budget. Enemies attack are slowed most of the time so you can react accordingly. If you have shield you can counter melee attacks or reflect projectiles but thats only if the prompt for attack glows green... if its red you better get the f* out of there.  There is a friendlyfire so you can use this to your advantage with good positioning so you can let enemies tank the range attacks. Now.. one thing that I noticed is often so long leaps when you counter enemies at distance or being stuck in animation with no time to react. My main issue with the combat is the camera. You cant rotate it so at times you have no idea what are you gonna face or where exactly the enemy is. Apart from that combat is fine.
Story and Narration

Story is pretty simple : you are an adventurer who stumbled upon Dealer's home and you are invited for a game but you are free to leave whenever you want. In the said game you have to defeat the Dealer but before that you must defeat his strongest warriors(on every warrior's level you will meet new challenges so GL). Simple yet well presented thanks to the strong Narration. Voice actor did his job superb but there is still something more to be desired from the writing. Still even when Dealer repeats himself is often in the mood of the situation and there are just a view occassions when the line will not be fitting the situation.

Difficulty/Fates

Now this is more about the DLC "Wildcards" . Fates lets you change your playstyle. In base game you have 3 fates that serve as Easy/Normal/Hard difficulty in other games but if you have the DLC you get access to 9 more fates with different stats that affect your playstyle. It's a neat addition but there is still room for improvment.

Endless Mode

Once you are done with the story
column34:
Endless mode seems best option to play it .. but I personally didnt like it since it kills Deckbuilding. In Endless Mode you play with all the unlocked cards you have and on every floor the Dealer gets stronger and stronger.


Overall
Its a neat roguelike with forgiving RNG and superb quest design and narration. Its good for short playsession and for people who like to unlock all cards."

reviewText:
tl;dr: good game, but expensive. 8/10

I have to give Hand of Fate credit. The presentation and style, as minimal as it is, is impressive. The game itself offers a unique and potentially engaging experience. The mysterious dealer sets the perfect mood with his appearance and narration. The only problem is HoF is one of those style over substance sorts of games. The flow of the game is entirely determined through cards as they're flipped over, and its this.... hand... that determines your fate. (eh? eh? that's the pun in the game's title)

Most of the time the game itself never goes beyond making a choice based on the card flipped and then selecting a shuffled card to determine if your action is successful or not. This in of itself isn't bad, but if you're looking for an action-y graphically intense RPG experience with deep lore, you won't find it here.

Infrequently, there are action-y bits. Usually in the form of a fight. Sometimes as an obstacle course. They're good place holders and don't do anything particularly wrong, but the AI is typically predictable and easy to overcome if you're a well seasoned gamer even on the harder mode. The action areas are also cramped looking and claustrophobic feeling.

Playing off its card based mechanics, the more you play and beat the game, the more and different cards you unlock, and the longer the new games you start become. Longer games translate into higher difficulty. This is one of those games where moves are a resource represented as food. Running out of food typically means you lose HP until you die and starving is typically how you fail in Hand of Fate.

Hand of Fate does come together very well though. It works as a game and, most importantly, is enjoyable and fun. The only major complaint I have is there isn't enough content or variety to justify the $25 price IMHO.

reviewText:
I can only agree with the many that this game has certain charm. The cards makes the game and while the combat isn't the best, and it might have served them better not to attempt something similar to the Batman Arkham games, it does fulfill its purpose.

So join the fun and buy the game.

reviewText:
Hand of Fate, I recommend this game.

Hand of Fate offers a controlled rogue-like experince.
You build your own deck of possible encounters, some are more diffacult than others, but can offer a great reward.
Something about earning new cards excited me greatly.
As I played through I've found that the randomness tends to fade away; not that it's still there, but more, if you leave the same encounter card in your deck you start to realize what options to choose in order to get the greatest reward. But it's all in your control for the most part so really that's up to the player.

Also, the wizard man gets his own deck. This will add cards to ♥♥♥♥ up your day. Rediculous cards that will make you want to cry. But without the wizard man there is no point in building your own deck to make you as powerfull as you can.

That's when luck starts to take effect. When it seems like all you do is run into the wizard man's cards, you won't be able to build up equipment on your character as easily, or at all. I've made it a few floors without gaining any gear.

However in the end the wizard man's cards, your cards, and the choices you make as you crawl and battle your way thrtough the floors creates a very rewarding experince.

8/10.

Also they seem to add some free stories/cards to play from time to time. So it's hard to complain about lack of content. Good on the developers, eh?

reviewText:
Clever game. Highly suggest acquiring and playing it.

It's difficult to describe -- you follow the game as if you'd be playing a tabletop RPG using cards for encounters, while the fights are classic 3rd person view battles in 3D. It includes inventory management (scaling your character) and resource management (health, food, gold). There some cards which represent skill check - pick one of four face-down cards to see the outcome (success or fail) -- it may appear like luck, but you can actually trace the cards while they are being shuffled.

Also manages to do a decent amount of story telling in this odd format.

9/10 would draw again

reviewText: An excellent rendition of roleplaying in the video game genre. You play as an adventurer, playing for a game of his life against the Mysterious dealer who prepares his black deck against you. Drawn from events of your own life, you have to rekindle the past, fight old enemies, and survive.\n\nTense, challenging, and very satisfying to earn new tokens. My only complaints are that eventually Endless mode simply becomes improbably fair, making it next to impossible in order to progress. However, that pales in comparison to the rest of this gem.

reviewText:
This game is super AWESOME and fun!

And it gets increasingly better value for money as time goes on!
How is that even possible? you may ask: well this already fleshed out fully immersive game, keeps having more content added into it every month or so:
I stopped playing for a couple months, come back and start playing, die in a dungeon yet again and am rewarded by unlocking 2 new DLC that got added without my knowing, Fantastic!

The narrator/dealer of the game makes it such an awesomly immersive experiance, each step has a chance to get further dialogue.

GAMEPLAY:
Before statring a run;
You have 2 decks of cards you can change up with your unlocked cards: 1st your equipment, 2nd your exploration/encounters. The dealer adds further encounter cards based on the level, of which there are 12.
3rd deck option if you paid for it (which is a must, so worth, so good): is picking a class/difficulty for you character, that can affect combat and exploration, including unlocking more encounter cards.

Each run attempt you can select different things for those 3 options, and each attempt will unlock more cards for your main 2 mentioned decks.

3 resorces that needs various degrees of management and affect you are; HEALTH, FOOD, GOLD.

Exploration:
the cards are aranged face down in a path, you move 1 card at a time, flippping it over and selecting options to get through it. could be a fight, merchant, chance, or choice based options.
The results can be anything from many of these cards, most of them have a chance to unlock further cards for future attempts, if you select correctly/choose well. Through these is the main way of drawing from your equipment deck and affecting your 3 resorces.

The whole time the dealer has awesome dialogue based on the cards and your options as well as banter, this makes the atmospher of the game awesome.

Combat:
Is fairly simple but fun and can be heavily affected by equpitment, blessings and curses you have got hold of during that run. You have attack, combo damage, block,counter, stun, dodge roll, weapon ability, artifact ability.

This from an overall perspective is a very unique and fun game, plenty of loot and replayablity, and you gain more options even on failing a run, so your time never feels completely wasted.

VERDICT:
There's nothing about the game I dislike or feel is badly done, so a full recommendation from me :)
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent game with an incredibly interesting concept, and solid execution. Cards become your gear, encounters, everything, and many of them have tokens. By succeeding at that card's encounter, you get the token, which create new cards for future games. I'm playing the Story mode, and it's fantastic. I've progressively unlocked a bunch of different new stories that I'm encountering in future games.
You choose your equipment and some of the encounter cards to build each match, and then the story setup you've selected adds cards. It's clever and works well.
Most cards are choices rather than combat, with semi-random success, others are static choices that you can learn and rely on in future games. This creates a great mix of surprise and predictability.
Combat is fairly basic but engaging - not the highlight of the game, but it doesn't hurt it either.
Story mode (Guessing 6-8 hours playtime), endless-play mode, and then modifiers that change the way some things work.

reviewText:
For those of you who would rather watch my video review, here ya go: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zcdq-eYCgXE

What this game did well was make a very replayable game with an interesting story that makes you want to keep replaying it. It does this through the side stories in the game. For a lot of cards, when you land on them they will give you a side quest that you can complete. If you do complete it then it will unlock another card that keeps driving this side story into multiple play throughs. This really helps in making the game not stagnate the more you play it, because it is constantly adding new cards for you to interact with and furthering the stories at the same time.

On the subject of RNG, this game is not always fair because a lot of it comes down to RNG. Most of the time you can handle what the game throws at you, but sometimes you will have a game where literally nothing goes your way. If you do not enjoy games that have RNG elements like this, then you will probably not enjoy this game. However, I feel like for the most part the RNG is not that bad.

The main problem that this game has is the combat. The combat is fairly simplistic, where you mainly just dodge and counter enemy attacks, similar to the Batman Arkham games, but less polished. Something about the combat just isn’t very satisfying. The enemies usually take a good bit of hits before they go down and when they do go down they don’t really have any kind of death animation, they just go full ragdoll which isn’t very gratify.

But, this game is still very enjoyable to play and I recommend checking it out.

reviewText:
This game is some kind of wierd amalgation of FTL's rogue-like runs, Batman's free flow combat, D&D's RPG mechanics (and setting... somewhat), as well as a good helping of tarot card and fortune teller theming. The difficulty is fairly easy at first, with the challenge becoming greater as you progress. Those who are at least adequate with the kind of combat described should be able to get right up to the end without too much difficulty, but the last encounter is an absolute nightmare that will take a lot of skill to get past.

The game at first is only 16-ish levels long, which can easily take up at least an hour each. The story is very intriquing, delivered mostly through the narration of the dealer, your constant enemy and companion. This, in my opinion, is far more preferable than them just right out telling you everything at the beginning, and the mystic behind the game only fits with the theme of it all. There is also several stories hidden within the cards you will begin to collect as you progress through the game.

Initially, I'd say this game is slightly overpriced, with a cost of $20 being more appropriate. However, the developers of the game have started releasing DLC for the game for absolutely nothing, which more than makes this game worth the price.

Hand of Fate is a true gem on Steam, with an interesting take on the RPG genre.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A great game! Very well thought of game with a mixture of cards and action. This game has good narrative storyline, very polished gameplay, good bgm and sound effects. The game can also be quickly entertaining without having to spend alot of hours into it. It is easy to learn and pickup even with the lack of a subtle tutorial.

In general this game allows you finish something like a quest given to you, and you gain a card token. After the end of each session, you open the card tokens revealing new adventures, new equipments that can be added into ur encounter deck, equipment deck and etc. This game is very well thought of because it uses a card interaction of allowing players to create their own encounters with a mixture of the dealers encounter cards. Very interactive gameplay. Players are required to do some sort of resource management from obtaining food resources, consuming food as each step taken requires you to consume one food resource. Sometimes you might think you will not gain anymore food, prompting you to quickly move on to the next level.

One downside to this game is that by the time you are 80% completing this game. You realize that there are no new monsters and the background setting are always the same. But it's not a problem because the developers can choose to release new DLC's that feature new monsters and bosses in the near future.

Overall, this is a great game that any gamer should add into their collection.

reviewText: I played this game first at the first PSX, 2014 in Las Vegas. Some how I missed this games kickstarter, and man was I mad that I missed it. I was extremely happy and lucky to be given one of their printed cards regardless, becuase I was attending PSX. Getting to chat with some of the developers was really neat, and I expressed how much I liked the game there, as I am here. The idea of taking a deck-building/shuffling game, and stuffing RPG, brawling, rogue-lite dungeon crawler all into one package seemed so inovative to me, and appealed to a lot of the game types I like. I was very surprsied when I was sitting down playing and the combat opened up for the first time, but I had loads of fun with the two boss fights they let me play through. I'm happy to have finally gotten a copy of this game, and love it.

reviewText: Bought this game early in 2015, and have really enjoyed it since. Currently have 50 hours into it (due to a lot of on-and-off gameplay), and still have quests to finish and things to unlock. Combat is simple (swing, counter, stun, and dodge), game of chance is fun (Four cards shown, then flipped and mixed up. Follow a card, if you can, and pick one.), and Endless mode keeps the game going after you've beaten the story mode, or even if you decide you don't like the story mode for someodd reason.\n\nCannot recommend this game enough!

reviewText: Just 100%ed the game and it's dlc wildcards. I'll focus on the main game in this review. This game is well worth the price(although I got it during the winter sale). The replayablity is really high and there are tons of new cards to unlock everytime you play a stage or endless. The main game let's you select the boss for the stage and each one comes with seperate rules(in the form of curses) and encounters to make getting to each boss it's own challenge. You can make your own deck to suit your playstyle or to adapt to certain stages, the cards that make up the equipment and encounter deck are cards you unlock from bosses, tokens, and from the easy and hard mode fates(you also unlock new gain cards from tokens). Equipment explains it's self, but encounter cards make up the floors in the stages, so you are in charge of the events that occur on each floor, it's a really awesome feature of this game. There are three main ways to die, one is from combat, another is from failing chance cards that make you draw pain cards, and last is from starvation.\nThe combat in the game isn't the best part, but it at least provides a good amount of challenge to the game, this is even more so if you're stuck in basic gear. Some negative things I could say about the game would be some chance cards are really hard to succeed at or survive(looking at you Petward ;c) and some of the most annoying encounters are locked in your deck and can ruin a playthrough. I'll briefly go over endless which is a mode where you select which fate you'll use and every card you unlocked will be in the mode(so no deck building), it's pretty much a mode where you need to survive as long as possible to get a highscore. Endless can be fun, but if you have encounters like Petward still up it could be all for naught. So I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes rogue-likes and action rpgs that have a twist to make it feel like a completely different experience. :)

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a card game.
Hand of Fate is an action adventure.
Hand of Fate is a board game.

All of the above is true and executed remarkably well for a small unknown studio. The trinity of those three games might appear to suggest that Hand of Fate is a casual game. It is not. Actually it is quite hardcore on the higher difficulty levels, which one will need to play at to unlock all cards and events. Don't deprive yourself of 80% of the game by just playing it on easy. It's not just more difficult, the game plays very differently with different decks".

reviewText:
This game is very interesting, it would be the best word to describe it with.

Hand of fate uses cards to basically tell a story of what happened in an adventure. With a lot of cards representing equipment, encounters and fights. It's usually up to the player to fill in the blanks in the story.

Your only real contact is the Dealer. A mysterious man, sitting in a locale controlling the ''game'', which are shown through the cards. He is the person that sets it all in motion. Yet, you do not know what purpose he fulfills otherwise.

The game is for the most time in the adventure on the cards. The encounter cards are laid out in a pattern, sometimes a linear path, other times a maze-like construction. Your goal is to move from your start point, to the exit, which remains hidden. Important to know, is that every move uses food. if you run out of food, you start losing health. As per usual in most games, no health = death.

Some encounters require a luck-based desicion, this is represented by four different cards. in order: Huge succes, Succes, Failure and Huge failure. 4 cards are shown, with the possible outcomes for you to choose. the cards are flipped, shuffeled, and then it's up to you to choose the adventurers fate in the encounter. It's important to know that succeeding the challenge, does not always progress the encounter, nor does failure always have a bad outcome.

Sometimes, an encounter happens to be a fight. You are then taken to a scene, which has a lot of variation in both size and looks. The game then turns in a 3rd person brawler. you must beat all enemies to continue, or die trying.

The story of your character is vague at best, and it is up to you, as the player, to find out who he is. And most importantly, what happened to him as to how he got there. Do not think that the Dealer is there to help you, as he will remind you a lot of times.

I personally like the setting a lot, it's simple, yet complicated, and shrouded in mystery. The Dealer as a character is awesome, and basically creates the atmosphere of the game on his own, commenting on your choices, your succeses, and failures.

If a point of negativity is to be made, I would have liked to see some character customisation. Not that the game requires it, but it would have been nice. Also, the Dealer runs out of lines quickly, and sometimes his conversations are pretty long. Still, the story that he conveys through said dialogue is very nice.

Overall, i had a great experience with the game as a whole. the DLC that i got, added a whole lot of semi-adventures to go through. I do not value scores, since a game should be your experience. A game that people generally dislike, may be the game you love the most.

If a score is to be put up:
8.5/10.

reviewText:
A narritively driven rougelike with turn based exploration and batman arkham style combat. Take risks and cheat lady luck as you go on an adventure that has an oddly new and yet familiar aspect to it. Are these new memories or perhaps old ones retreaded? Are they even your memories at all?

Buy it full price, buy it on sale, buy the DLC, its all worth it. I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a wonderful experience, and by far my favorite game of 2015

Pros:
Unique combination of dungeon crawler and card game.

Cards have alot of variety, multiple choices, and special circumstances such as having specific items that keeps the game interesting even after multiple plays.

Combat and equipping your character is very simple and satisfying.

Very atmospheric, The Dealer does a great job of painting the world with his words, similar to a DM in DnD type games.

Unlocking new cards is very satisfying early on, unlocked cards are kept even if you fail the current mission.

Very interesting Story Mode that does a good job keeping up variety and adding new mechanics to keep things fresh.


Cons:
Monster and Equipment variety is a little lacking.

Combat could be considered overly simplistic. It boils down to attack, counter, dodge, and special move.

Unlocking new cards that are part of a series (Blood Auction, any of the Wildcard DLC, etc) can be tedious due to the luck involved.

Unlimited Mode is fun but it's just about score in the end. You can only win" the game in Story Mode

With the new free DLC
date: a challenging late game boss can appear early on in Unlimited Mode when monster difficulty is supposed to be low. Very irratating.\n\nOverall
recommended: definatly worth your time and money."

reviewText:
This is a strange little game.  It incorporates elements of cards games, rpg games, and action style games and tries to wield them all together.  It shouldn't work, but somehow it does, creating something refreshingly different.

The core of the games main story mode is that you pick a boss to go after (although you must beat each to go on to the next one) the assemble a deck of story cards and one of equipment.  The story cards are then mixed together with new cards by the mysterious Dealer and laid out to form a map.  As you move your character onto a story card, it flips over, usually resulting in a choose your own adventure style encounter, although there are also straight up combats and stores to discover.  Any equipment you find is usually drawn from your equipment deck, so what cards you put in that can be important as are what encounters you added into the mix. Some encounter cards come with tokens you can earn by achieving something during the encounter.

WIn or lose, once your run is over, any tokens you've earned unlock new eqiupment and encounter cards.  It is no coincidence that some of the most useful cards are rewards for some of the most risky encounters, so going safe is not always good for the long run.

Combat is handled with a battle system nearly identical to the Batman Arkham games.  If you enjoyed that system, you'll like this one.

All in all a very unique game that is easy to pick up for a quick 30 minute run.

reviewText:
To summarise - an atmospheric, rewarding and compelling game. There are other sources to explain how the game works so I won't re-explain that but I will highlight its key points.

You build a deck of equipment and encounters, then run the level with that deck of cards, making progress towards expanding your deck (and thus your options), and in the middle of all that you engage in short third-person fights with creatures/enemies. And in the middle of ALL of that, you are continually listening to the comments of the dealer, the writing for which is superb and the voice acting for which really sets a very mysterious and compelling tone to the game. Added to that the animation as all this takes place, the atmosphere of the game is extremely enticing, full of exploration, mystery and intrigue.

The deck building is compelling as it has a real impact on how you will play the level and has more depth that 'best equipment in, worst equipment out', actually requiring thought to get cards which may work well with your building of the encounters. Speaking of which, you also choose what the encounters are going to be during the level, mainly focusing on ones which you have not completed yet which in turn will expand your available cards. A very rewarding and compelling loop with surprising depth.

The little battles are not too long or onerous and as they are very short and there is a lot of variety (some variety in enemies and variety in how you play based on what equipment you've managed to acquire, completely changing your abilities) they do not get repetitive quickly.

The campaign is, as I have said, very atmospheric. It is all about exploring the encounters around you (as you don't know which ones they are), with success leading to rewards expanding your deck for the next run. There is a fair element of luck involved, which would be annoying if it weren't for the fact that you make permanent progress on each run even if you die, which means that you still feel like something was achieved.

Overall, these factors combine to make a very compelling and enjoyable experience which is highly recommended for just about everyone, since it isn't really just a 'brawler' or a 'card building game' or any of those, but a great hybrid which takes the best elements from everything in my opinion. Add to that the updates by the developers, it is one to pick up and keep playing. (And the DLC also comes highly recommended as it adds yet another element to this great game!)

reviewText:
9.5/10 (Only because player combat is a wee bit wonky)

Other then that, this game is AMAZING.  Ive only played 2 hours or so but honestly, theres so much luck, skill, and storyline, i found it hard to stop at the end of a level.  The player controlled combat is really well defined to the point where its actual skill (further than the extent of earlygame where you spam mouse 1) and could use a touch up on how you teleport/slide to counter enemies but great integration of 3rd person combat into a deckbuilding rougelike.

The decks you build are unique and you can partially decide your fate through random encounters.  You may start the game with the best weapon you shuffled into your weapon deck but next turn be held up by an angry mob that steals most your food, leaving you desperate to take any advance towards combat to earn gold to hopefully stumble across a shop to scrape by until you gather enough food to make it to the next shop, until fate decides you either run out of food and die, scrape by until the boss and have no weapon or skill advantage because youve spent no gold on gear, or by stroke of luck stumble into plentiful amounts of food. This game is tense sometimes and has seemingly infinite replayability due to custom deckbuilding and random level generation.

9.5/10 - would rate 8/8 but m8, it's too l8 to h8 your f8

reviewText:
Part board game, part card game, part RPG and part action game. Create two sets of cards. One set is of items to find. The other set is of encounters. Thankfully the NPC (game master?) shuffles and sorts everything out for you.
The GM places cards on the table in various configurations and you move a taoken along the cards as you would on a grid or board. Sometimes you have more than one direction from which to choose. Most often you can only more in one direction. Once chosen you reveal the card to see what you encounter. You may encounter combat, find equipment, make a choice as to your action or many others. Don't forget to stock up on food as each card your token moves to will cost one food.
After traveling awhile (down stairs to new 'floors'), you find the end boss. Use your equipment to defeat this foe the same way you beat any previous combat. Use the ASWD keys to swing your current weapon. Other items may give you other skills and will be explained as you get them. If you beat the boss, you'll unlock many new cards and can change your decks around to include them if you wish.
Tailor your decks to what you think might happen. Add more armor, a shield or even stronger weapons. There is a lot you cannot plan for, so I suggest erring on the side of caution.
You can always go into another 'dungeon' to fight a boss you have already fought. To start a game, choose the boss you want to fight then choose the difficulty for what is needed to unlock specials. No spoiler given here.

Good luck and no matter what the GM says, don't turn back

reviewText:
Decided to buy the game after I read a ton of reviews.  Most talked about how easy the game was etc, etc.  For the first 75% is it not difficult at all. Some of the tokens require some luck of the draw to get but everything is definitely doable.

The only difficult fight I found was the boss at the end but if you get a good trip to him with the right abilities you can beat him.  The heal is really needed.  However, it is pretty easy if you get the damage increase per curse as you have a lot of curses when you get there.  That makes him much easier.

After reading reviews I was skeptical, but it was fun.  The graphcis are nothing to write home to mom about, but the play through was enjoyable.  I do not think I will play through it again, but I did enjoy it.

If you catch this on sale, it is really worth a play through.  If you are looking for hack and slash or building up a character to just go one shot everything, this is not the game for you.  If you like a little strategy, luck of the dice, and some chance involved, this will keep you interested.

reviewText:
This game is super AWESOME and fun!

And it gets increasingly better value for money as time goes on!
How is that even possible? you may ask: well this already fleshed out fully immersive game, keeps having more content added into it every month or so:
I stopped playing for a couple months, come back and start playing, die in a dungeon yet again and am rewarded by unlocking 2 new DLC that got added without my knowing, Fantastic!

The narrator/dealer of the game makes it such an awesomly immersive experiance, each step has a chance to get further dialogue.

GAMEPLAY:
Before statring a run;
You have 2 decks of cards you can change up with your unlocked cards: 1st your equipment, 2nd your exploration/encounters. The dealer adds further encounter cards based on the level, of which there are 12.
3rd deck option if you paid for it (which is a must, so worth, so good): is picking a class/difficulty for you character, that can affect combat and exploration, including unlocking more encounter cards.

Each run attempt you can select different things for those 3 options, and each attempt will unlock more cards for your main 2 mentioned decks.

3 resorces that needs various degrees of management and affect you are; HEALTH, FOOD, GOLD.

Exploration:
the cards are aranged face down in a path, you move 1 card at a time, flippping it over and selecting options to get through it. could be a fight, merchant, chance, or choice based options.
The results can be anything from many of these cards, most of them have a chance to unlock further cards for future attempts, if you select correctly/choose well. Through these is the main way of drawing from your equipment deck and affecting your 3 resorces.

The whole time the dealer has awesome dialogue based on the cards and your options as well as banter, this makes the atmospher of the game awesome.

Combat:
Is fairly simple but fun and can be heavily affected by equpitment, blessings and curses you have got hold of during that run. You have attack, combo damage, block,counter, stun, dodge roll, weapon ability, artifact ability.

This from an overall perspective is a very unique and fun game, plenty of loot and replayablity, and you gain more options even on failing a run, so your time never feels completely wasted.

VERDICT:
There's nothing about the game I dislike or feel is badly done, so a full recommendation from me :)

reviewText:
Excellent game with an incredibly interesting concept, and solid execution. Cards become your gear, encounters, everything, and many of them have tokens. By succeeding at that card's encounter, you get the token, which create new cards for future games. I'm playing the Story mode, and it's fantastic. I've progressively unlocked a bunch of different new stories that I'm encountering in future games.
You choose your equipment and some of the encounter cards to build each match, and then the story setup you've selected adds cards. It's clever and works well.
Most cards are choices rather than combat, with semi-random success, others are static choices that you can learn and rely on in future games. This creates a great mix of surprise and predictability.
Combat is fairly basic but engaging - not the highlight of the game, but it doesn't hurt it either.
Story mode (Guessing 6-8 hours playtime), endless-play mode, and then modifiers that change the way some things work.

reviewText:
For those of you who would rather watch my video review, here ya go: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zcdq-eYCgXE

What this game did well was make a very replayable game with an interesting story that makes you want to keep replaying it. It does this through the side stories in the game. For a lot of cards, when you land on them they will give you a side quest that you can complete. If you do complete it then it will unlock another card that keeps driving this side story into multiple play throughs. This really helps in making the game not stagnate the more you play it, because it is constantly adding new cards for you to interact with and furthering the stories at the same time.

On the subject of RNG, this game is not always fair because a lot of it comes down to RNG. Most of the time you can handle what the game throws at you, but sometimes you will have a game where literally nothing goes your way. If you do not enjoy games that have RNG elements like this, then you will probably not enjoy this game. However, I feel like for the most part the RNG is not that bad.

The main problem that this game has is the combat. The combat is fairly simplistic, where you mainly just dodge and counter enemy attacks, similar to the Batman Arkham games, but less polished. Something about the combat just isn’t very satisfying. The enemies usually take a good bit of hits before they go down and when they do go down they don’t really have any kind of death animation, they just go full ragdoll which isn’t very gratify.

But, this game is still very enjoyable to play and I recommend checking it out.

reviewText:
This is a really, really great game. I am so happy I found it.

First of all, the dialogue is just outstanding. Not only is it well written and well spoken, it also makes the game very easy to understand. Unlike most other cards games, you don't need to learn all cards by hand, as all of these are explained in detail whenever you draw them.

Furthermore, I am deeply a fan of the rogue-like aspect, which I never thought a card game could have. The gameplay is very original; there is no other game even close to this. Everytime you draw a card, you either gain resources, equipment, or you will enter a combat. I am still astonished at how one can combine so many different gaming aspects, whilst yet creating a wonderful game.

With no doubt, from the old RTS games I've played to the FPS games that have been dominating the planet, this is one of the best single-player games ever made.

reviewText:
This game is one of the greatest I've ever played. That's not an easy thing for me to say. Everything about this game is unique. It gets a perfect score in my book. Also, it has the all time greatest boss fight at the end of the game, hands down. I love this game to death.

The gameplay is the best part of this game, the game can twist and turn any which way when your progress is lead by pure luck. The way the card system works is very simple and easy to wrap your mind around. The combat is excellent and fluid, it's awesome to watch. The combat isn't just hacking and slashing, it's about timing blocks and dodging opponents you can't fight all at once. The combat is reminscent to the first Fable, in fact, much of this game really is a Fable game without the brand name, but the combat is so much more interesting here than in any Fable.

The graphics are lush and colourful. It has that wonderful atmospheric fantasy mood that Fable set so perfectly.

The sound quality is top notch for the most part. There is a few times when the sound does cut out but a simple restart fixes that immediately. The soundtrack is awesome and really has an epic vibe to it. I was even thinking of buying it if it's sold on Steam. It's one of those soundtracks that'll take me back years from now. I love the clanging of the swords and the thumping of swords against shields. The voice actor behind the Dealer is on the same level of deep and mesmerizing as Morgan Freeman. He's like an English Morgan Freeman, I can't stress enough how good of a voice actor he is.

The story line is interesting, it's not a normal storyline. You enter at the end of the adventurer's story. This is a retelling of all his adventures. So it's a game about retrospective and reflection. The Dealer makes very interesting remarks and ponderings that make me think on a philosophical level. What kind of game does that?

I love a game that I can put hundreds and hundreds of hours into. A game that has endless replayability and isn't limited by just having a storyline. This is one of those games. It doesn't ever have to end. There's an endless mode. There's also 200+ cards to collect. Each card is an encounter. Every game randomizes these encounters and even throws in some that benefit you and some that debilitate you to a certain extent. This game definitely earns its pay and has lot of bang for very little buck.

If you're on the fence about getting it, don't be. This game isn't hard to fall in love with. I'd recommend this game to absolutely anyone.

reviewText:
A truly unique action/adventure/RPG/card game.

The main character of the game besides yourself is The Dealer. He isn't a bad guy whom wishes to see you destroyed, he is but a pawn himself, playing his role and carrying out his duties to whatever forces hold him in check. Seeing how he is the only character besides the randomly generated baddies that you encounter, I do find it beneficial to the overall quality of the game that he has a sense of mystery around him and that you experience a sort of growing give-take" relationship with him via dialogue and card plots as you play throughout the story mode. I've put over 3 hours into the game and I haven't heard the dealer repeat himself yet. This a huge plus as most games have a very shallow dialogue pool to pull from.

While I've heard others complain that the hack n' slash format of combat that you are thrown into upon landing on a card that generates baddies is boring and unrewarding-I STRONGLY disagree. The combat is fast paced and frantic

reviewText:
A narritively driven rougelike with turn based exploration and batman arkham style combat. Take risks and cheat lady luck as you go on an adventure that has an oddly new and yet familiar aspect to it. Are these new memories or perhaps old ones retreaded? Are they even your memories at all?

Then, when your luck goes sour all combat takes place in real time using the simple arkham system. Loads of encounters, enemies and equipment. Equipment effects your stats and gives you passive bonuses while you can get activatable weapon skills and artefacts. Cureses and Blessings also effect gameplay in the combat and in the adventure. Plus, its got cards and deckbuilding elements too!

Buy it full price, buy it on sale, buy the DLC, its all worth it. I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a wonderful experience, and by far my favorite game of 2015

Pros:
Unique combination of dungeon crawler and card game.

Cards have alot of variety, multiple choices, and special circumstances such as having specific items that keeps the game interesting even after multiple plays.

Combat and equipping your character is very simple and satisfying.

Very atmospheric, The Dealer does a great job of painting the world with his words, similar to a DM in DnD type games.

Unlocking new cards is very satisfying early on, unlocked cards are kept even if you fail the current mission.

Very interesting Story Mode that does a good job keeping up variety and adding new mechanics to keep things fresh.


Cons:
Monster and Equipment variety is a little lacking.

Combat could be considered overly simplistic. It boils down to attack, counter, dodge, and special move.

Unlocking new cards that are part of a series (Blood Auction, any of the Wildcard DLC, etc) can be tedious due to the luck involved.

Unlimited Mode is fun but it's just about score in the end. You can only win" the game in Story Mode

With the new free DLC
date: a challenging late game boss can appear early on in Unlimited Mode when monster difficulty is supposed to be low. Very irratating.\n\nOverall
recommended: definatly worth your time and money."

reviewText:
This is a strange little game.  It incorporates elements of cards games, rpg games, and action style games and tries to wield them all together.  It shouldn't work, but somehow it does, creating something refreshingly different.

The core of the games main story mode is that you pick a boss to go after (although you must beat each to go on to the next one) the assemble a deck of story cards and one of equipment.  The story cards are then mixed together with new cards by the mysterious Dealer and laid out to form a map.  As you move your character onto a story card, it flips over, usually resulting in a choose your own adventure style encounter, although there are also straight up combats and stores to discover.  Any equipment you find is usually drawn from your equipment deck, so what cards you put in that can be important as are what encounters you added into the mix. Some encounter cards come with tokens you can earn by achieving something during the encounter.

WIn or lose, once your run is over, any tokens you've earned unlock new eqiupment and encounter cards.  It is no coincidence that some of the most useful cards are rewards for some of the most risky encounters, so going safe is not always good for the long run.

Combat is handled with a battle system nearly identical to the Batman Arkham games.  If you enjoyed that system, you'll like this one.

All in all a very unique game that is easy to pick up for a quick 30 minute run.

reviewText:
**Note for Mac owners:
- the OS X version performs noticeably worse than the Windows version on the same machine. Recommend you Boot Camp this.
- I'm personally having problems with the controller support on OS X. They're looking into it

One of the most interesting RPGs I've played in recent years. Using cards to represent everything from encounters, monsters to equipment and stats, you start off with a limited deck but earn more cards as you beat major encounters, and can essentially customise the deck to stack encounters/drops in your favour or limit yourself for a more challenging game.

As someone who is tired of the whole roguelike trend that's swept indie games recently, Hand of Fate is surprisingly fresh and isn't difficult for difficulty's sake. There's just the right balance of randomness with a consistent, well-written RPG experience, and superb narration (probably my favourite narrator since Bastion) and attention to detail to back it up.

Very happy to see it out of Early Access. I had to stop myself from playing too much prior to launch!

reviewText:
There's a lot of content in this game. There are tons of items and events to unlock, and there's a lot of good combat. I sank over 41 hours into this game, and most of that was probably grinding for trying to unlock specific cards. But it suffers from a couple serious design flaws.

I appreciate the giant random element in the game, but when the difficulty ramps up about 7 bosses in, it makes a very large difficulty spike. Some of the dungeon curse combinations are punishingly difficult.

There are cards which are close to impossible to beat unless you beat them early enough in the game. These can include Devil's Wager and The River.

Too many of the encounters require you to either have  a ridiculous amount of gold or food, or require you to do a lengthy quest chain to unlock new cards. The random chance issues in some of these later encounters can make them ridiculously difficult to complete.

By the end of the game, pain cards can aggregate to the point where you get insta-killed from max HP if you have enough curses. It happens.

Do not ever quit the game in the middle of a run. Normally it will save your spot, but if the developers decide to patch the game, it can delete any in-progress runs you have going. The code to prevent that is simply to hard for them to implement, due to poor design choices. Just don't leave runs in-progress, as the developers should not be trusted.

The dealer is usually funny, tends to get annoying when he runs out of new things to say and just repeats himself over and over. There were also issues with prejudiced and thoughtless dialogue of his which have since been patched out.

The DLC isn't all that expensive, and it unlocks character classes for your protagonist, each which has its own quest chain, but each class has its own benefits and drawbacks. Some of the classes are ridiculously overpowered in certain fields, which kind of makes the DLC pay to win".

The graphics and controls are okay
date: usually. A couple of glitches here and there
recommended: and sometimes the controller seems unresponsive until a couple seconds after a battle has begun. That's no good.\n\nThe developers have an unfortunate habit of "rebalancing" cards
hoursPlayed: moving around their place in the unlock system or difficulty levels they show up on
voteText: and completely changing the way the later dungeons work
helpfulPercent: and not for the better. This is the sort of negative developer behavior that similarly plagued Dark Souls II.\n\nThe overall experience is marred by a couple of bad design choices."

reviewText:
This game is amazing in so many ways I cannot describe.

It gives you the freedom that you would recieve from open world games to where you can take the role of the Hero, A kind man who gives food to those who need other then worrying about yourself. The Adventure and Story is your own to decide. As if you were the one actually writing it out in a book and day by day falling head over heels for it because its such a amazing journey and the events that occur cause you to just scream in Awe"

The items you may find are pretty basic. Though I do admit some of them are quite laughable such as the RAT Cleaver. Which looks like a overgrown Butcher-Knife just waiting to cut down one of the pests you see moving around the Kitchen.

reviewText:
My review for Rogue-like: The Card Game.

The Good:

-A unique blend of 3rd Person Action RPG with a deck building card game that works incredibly well.
-The voice actor for the game master is awesome.
-Writing is great.
-Top notch visuals and the art style is very Fable-esque.
-Runs at a buttery smooth 144fps on my rig max settings, no PC problems as far as I can tell.
-Branching paths on later levels which makes for a good amount of replayability.
-Random card generation that leads to very different outcomes every time you play, you could get great card draw and have an easy ride to the boss, which leads to...

The Meh:

-Random card generation that leads to very different outcomes every time you play, you could end up with a pain card that may cause you to lose alot of heath or cripple you early on and make it very difficult to finish a run.
-Combat is Arkham-like in which you fling back and forth between enemies and all too familiar counter system, its not as good as Arkham and a bit button mashy, but it works.
-Kinda lacking in options, but hey, its a Unity game.
-Encountered a small bug in one of the merchant shops where i'd pause the game and when i came back, my cursor was gone and i couldn't select anything...luckily i fixed it by alt-tabbing.

Overall:

An Early Access success, its nice to see a game come out of that hell hole and bring something very unique and special to the table. I hope to see this gain some huge publicity and enough sales to bring it to other platforms so that everybody has a chance to play this. Support the devs, buy this game!

reviewText:
I'm going to begin by saying that this review was written after playing the first level beyond the tutorial, so I might not have a full handle of the games nuances.

First and foremost, this is a deck-building game. The cards are not just a creative way to stylize the game, they are the source of your equipment and your challenges. Before each level you assemble two sets of cards. Your equipment deck, and your encounter deck. Now, you don't start with any of these cards, these are the cards that are going to be on the board for you to gather or miss depending on chance. The Equipment is your assortment of weapons, armor, and special abilities. And the Encounter deck is your encounters in the level (duh), of scaling severity. From the farmer, to the goblins, to the hall of traps, to the ambush. While these can hurt you, they can just as easily reward you. At the end of the hall of traps, is treasure. At the end of the ambush, loot. This brings us to the core gameplay

After building your decks, you begin the game, where cards are shuffled and laid face down on the table in random assortment. This acts like a board to a tabletop game, where you can only move one space (or card) at a time, and each card is an encounter. And just because you built an encounter deck doesnt mean that's all you'll face, The Dealer (or Game Master) peppers his own cards in there as well. The encounters for me so far have either been text blocks with multiple choice answers, or action phases where you navigate hazards or fight enemies.

The combat reminds me of the Batman: Arkham series. While not reliant so heavily on combos, there is an assortment of enemy types and a dodge and counter system that is very similar, if not identical. Special abilites are earned through cards and do things like generate gold on hit or throw a fan of knives.

After winning encounters and navigating the board, you make your way to the boss, which, after the battle, you collect the tokens you've earned up to that point. These work as booster packs for your deck, giving you random equipment and encounter cards, which can be used for the levels ahead. New cards however, remain somewhat of a mystery, because while you have the name of the card like say, Scavanger's Helm, you don't know exactly what it does until you aquire during a level. (probably something involving loot)

Death is going to be common, but, much like the game Rogue Legacy, death isn't the end. It's a chance to do better next time, with the new cards you've earned from tokens during the round, and a new assortment of cards that might be more (or less) favorable to you.

During the game, The Dealer will taunt you and will make comments on the cards you draw. It can really draw you into the game and give the immersion that you're really in a card duel with a (slightly overdramatic) snarky wizard, trying to beat him at (literally) his own game.

Overall, This game has my complete approval. Being a very creative and well exicuted concept I would love to see more of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very intriguing game with solid (though not revolutionary) arena-style fighting, but with a groundbreaking kicker: it's all in the cards.

It would be interesting just to have a deck for the player, but the opponent also has a deck that makes the encounters randomized and unique. Earning cards by completing challenges helps to stack your own deck helps to maximize your fortunes. There is some chance involved with some encounters, adding to the randomness and dynamic nature of each rouguelike run.

I usually don't endorse early access, but this game seems to be heading in the right direction. I wouldn't blame some for waiting for the final release, but it's already very polished and enticing, and I'm having a blast playing it.

reviewText:
***DO NOT EXPECT TO EVER FINISH THIS GAME. STACKING PENALTIES, MULTIPLE BOSSES AT THE SAME TIME AND DECK-STACKING ARE ALWAYS AGAINST YOU***


An excellent mash-up of deck building, card-progression/upgrades through success, and timing-based combat. You find yourself in a Plutonian hall before the Dealer, the Game Master of a card game that reflects your life and memories. Will you donate blood to a vampire? Save a maiden while you are severely outnumbered? Break open sand-buried tombs for a chance at treasure or curses? It was your life, what memories of yours do the cards hold?

This rogue-like combines card game with random chance, mini-games with careful preparation, and mystery with thirsty curiosity.

You WILL be tested.
You WILL smash your keyboard at the unfairness of the decks and bosses.
You WILL face those bosses again, as they are added to the chance encounter deck as soon as they are beaten...

...and you will come back for more. Again and again you will be rebuffed, and again and again you will come crawling back to unlock more powerful cards, win at games of chance and squeeze all the efficiency out of your food (movement) and gold (money) as you can.

Thirteen Challenges await. The further you progress the smaller the arenas get, the tougher and more numerous the enemies get, and the more unfair the Dealer stacks the deck against you. What's your threshold for pain?


I hope it's high. This game is gorgeous in it's own mystery and difficulty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty good balance between combat and deck building. Bought in the Bumble Bundle and got a foil card drop from it so it essentially cost me nothing! I'm really enjoying it so would recommend.

Pros:

I like the fact that at the end of each chapter the game will re-build your deck for you with the optimium cards. For those that don't particularly want to build their own decks it means they don't get left behind.

For the pick a card shuffle rounds I really like the fact that you can actually follow the cards - I've played too many games where it's just randomised but here it's pretty simple to pay attention!

Cons: The direction keys aren't too fantastic, I find that I need to let go completely to move in a new direction as I get stuck, it doesn't flow so well but it's not that big a deal as it isn't enough of a handicap to get you killed.

Tip: Don't even bother trying to remove the curses, it's not worth the gold. Good weapons and lots of food is far more valuable. From the strange looking maiden I always go for blessings, you generally get something pretty decent and long lasting - there are plenty of other places to get gold, food and life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hand of Fate is slightly more humiliating a lot more fun than playing a children's card game.

It's a very special blend of hack and slay, card game and tabletop--and it's all very stylish. Forget leveling up and hunting for the ultimate loot au Diablo 3: There are no levels to gain, and you always start with a crappy weapon. You want a better one, you have to earn it; you can only find/buy equipment whose cards are in play so as you unlock new cards, you get to influence the type of gear you can find, and also to some extent what can happen to you.

As of now, the beta (early access) looks and plays nice--apart from the occasional out-of-sync sound effects, everything looks and feels very much worth the $$$. It will be interesting to see if it has any replay value though.

Did I mention that it runs on Linux, and flawlessly at that?

One thing though: Multiplayer. No, I don't know how that would work. Actually, scratch that, that's a stupid idea.

Wow- pretty amazing game. It's a cross between Talisman (the board game), Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, and Diablo, and it integrates all of those into a consistently fun whole. I have found myself willing to fight a hard battle before the boss (even knowing I will die at the boss if I do) because I will get a card to add to my deck. The decisions create tension.

Even the luck elements - of which there are many - feel different than a die roll because you get to choose. Yes, it's still the exact same amount of randomness, but it somehow feels like If I had only chose that one...I was going to choose that one..."

The negatives:

1) Luck can be a harsh mistress
2) On my very middle-of-the-road system
date:
the frame rate drops on complex battles to where it's almost a guaranteed fail
3) I had to go get a controller - the mouse and keyboard were just too clunky

The positives:
1) The dungeon master's voice. I usually get annoyed by voice acting
recommended: but this is masterful.\n2) In story mode
hoursPlayed: even though it's roguey
voteText: it still feels like a story\n3) Fantastic mash-up of different types of gameplay - the ability to pick the encounters I'm going to face and the range of equipment I'll have access to is brilliant.\n4) The arkham-style combat is fun
helpfulPercent: and as frustrating as it is to have goblins steal your shield (which makes counters and blocks unavailable)
votesHelpful: it emphasizes that these are not just multiple game modes strung together
votesTotal: but multiple facets of a single experience.\n\nEven though I've died a lot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not much of a reviewer but, I'll sumarise this game as best as i can. And I hope this review will help to support this game.

This game is what i would call a story telling rogue-like/lite adventure rpg card game with the Arkham Style fighting system. Seem like alot to put into game but it works well.

In this game you must traverse the card layed out by the card dealer. The cards are semi- randomised but, I'll go into more detail later. You click on the card adjacent to where you current position is and then experience the story behind that card which results in either a fight, a choice, a lucky dip or any combination of the three. Then eventually reach the end of the level.

Combat
The combat in the game seems to be solid for the most part. The way you fight is simillar if not the same to Batman games style of combat. You move with wasd"
hoursPlayed: "left click" to attack and "right click" to stun. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. With as much as I have played so far
voteText: the combat seems to be solid
helpfulPercent: it's not as smooth as it could be and seems a bit jittery
votesHelpful:
but nothing too extreme. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. I have had no problems with the combat so far.

Bosses
The bosses seem to have a bit of variation. Their mechanics are different depending on their species and the amount and way they attack differ from one to another. There are 12 bosses and so far i have beaten 3

you can still tell when you are in a boss fight and you feel satisfyed to win against them.

Enemies
There are 4 mains enemies you face against
