reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really enjoying this game. I love the card-based themes infused with simple action gameplay. I wish more games were this inventive.

My only complaint is that it doesn't run very well... Even with graphics quality set to Fastest" I was having hiccups in framerate and enough input lag to make the game nearly unplayable. I imagine this is something that will eventually get worked out. This is an early early build. Hopefully further development will improve optimization for lower-end systems like mine."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really interesting game.  The combat is very easy to learn and has all the basic mainstays you'd expect from a fighting game.

The highlight is definitely the dealer and the world of cards he builds.  Both mentor and adversary, it's like having a pocket dungeon master when you feel like going it alone.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent card game, mixed in with real-time combat.

It's funny, the style of it I always thought would suit a card game quite well. Your character collects armour and weapons and items but when you go into combat, its all equipped in a real-time action sequence.

Really great.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty good balance between combat and deck building. Bought in the Bumble Bundle and got a foil card drop from it so it essentially cost me nothing! I'm really enjoying it so would recommend.

Pros:

I like the fact that at the end of each chapter the game will re-build your deck for you with the optimium cards. For those that don't particularly want to build their own decks it means they don't get left behind.

For the pick a card shuffle rounds I really like the fact that you can actually follow the cards - I've played too many games where it's just randomised but here it's pretty simple to pay attention!

Cons: The direction keys aren't too fantastic, I find that I need to let go completely to move in a new direction as I get stuck, it doesn't flow so well but it's not that big a deal as it isn't enough of a handicap to get you killed.

Tip: Don't even bother trying to remove the curses, it's not worth the gold. Good weapons and lots of food is far more valuable. From the strange looking maiden I always go for blessings, you generally get something pretty decent and long lasting - there are plenty of other places to get gold, food and life.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hand of Fate is slightly more humiliating a lot more fun than playing a children's card game.

It's a very special blend of hack and slay, card game and tabletop--and it's all very stylish. Forget leveling up and hunting for the ultimate loot au Diablo 3: There are no levels to gain, and you always start with a crappy weapon. You want a better one, you have to earn it; you can only find/buy equipment whose cards are in play so as you unlock new cards, you get to influence the type of gear you can find, and also to some extent what can happen to you.

As of now, the beta (early access) looks and plays nice--apart from the occasional out-of-sync sound effects, everything looks and feels very much worth the $$$. It will be interesting to see if it has any replay value though.

Did I mention that it runs on Linux, and flawlessly at that?

One thing though: Multiplayer. No, I don't know how that would work. Actually, scratch that, that's a stupid idea.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a very intersting hybrid game that pretty will executes on the premise. The overarching card-game is interesting, with a large variety in cards with unique effects, and it integrates well with the actual combat. Great sense of atmosphere, with good writing and voice acting for the shadowy dealer. The combat engine could use some polish, but I'm confident that will be address, as the game does appear to be in truly active development for the Early Access period (launch is scheduled for next January).
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

I look forward to seeing how this progresses.

reviewText:
Addicting.... very VERY addicting.

I asked the forums if the game has any solid replayability and I believe it does, a lot of it actually.  But the review..

The Good:

Addicting game play, obviously I mean who doesn't like card games and rpgs and dungeon crawlers and blah blah blah you get up grades that do different things and they do them well.

The gear assortment is pretty neat, lots of different piece of gear that have little thing here and there like extra life if you heal or a sword that can shoot frost all at the touch of a button.

The random encounters are also really cool from the Elf Maiden to the Priest or perhaps A fallen hero, lots of different encounters with rewards.

there is a lot more but I have just scratched the surface.

The Bad:

Not really BAD but kinda annoying so be ready but some random encounters are BAD like falling rocks... damn rocks I mean you would figure the guy could dodge a falling rock but NOPE! you get 1 chance to succeed in this actiong to avoid the falling rocks and if you don't it hurts... A LOT.

FOOD!!!! for the love of everything everywhere bring FOOD! if you have a chance to get food some where TAKE IT omfg if you run out you are now running on Health until you die, try fighting a boss with 14 health I had to change my underwear.

On the subject of random encounter some of them have pretty bad optins as far as how much you can succeed like 1 success and three failure or even one Huge failure, it makes the game interesting but still fresh into the game it can hurt a lot.

Difficulty ramps up pretty quick.. once you get past the first gate things become more dangerous and you can die.. like dieing in a trap maze to a bush -.- yeah there is a defining moment for you you died to a damn bush a BUSH! ANY WAY...

All in all this is a GREAT game and I am REALLY REALLY glad I got it, I hope the game take off and adds more content because wow... I love it and I have like maybe a few hours at the time of writing this.  So if you have any doubts DON'T this is worth the money 100%.. now excuess me I have a bush to go take care of... giggity!.  (I mean the one in the maze >.>)

reviewText:
This game brings something new to the table that I think many people will enjoy. There are aspects of strategy, roguelike, deck building, and hack n slash. It is assembled with very appealing visuals and executes its unique style very well.

While playing there were definetly qualities that established it in my mind as similar to classic choose-your-own-adventure games, and aspects of DnD. The set up of randomized" events set up on uniquely simulated dungeon maps and illustrated through card play is spot on.

This is also one of the few games that is absolutely delightful when played in endless mode. It is almost as if the developer started out crafting a game based on endless mode

reviewText:
Alrighty, I've been playing this game for quite a while, and it's been a treat watching it develop towards launch. Now that the time is finally here, I'll try to break down what makes this game such a gem.

The premise of the game is simple; you, the player, are in a tabletop game against some random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wizard called The Dealer. That may seem harsh, but, trust me, you'll hate this guy by the time you finish story mode. He's a card sharp and a cheat, and he quite shamelessly weights the deck against you at every turn. This becomes particularly apparent towards the endgame, where you can die on the first board due to the insane limitations he can put on you in terms of both combat and curses. That doesn't make him a bad character, however. The Dealer is quite effective as an antagonist, and his growing desperation as you (whom he implies to be a meathead jock adventurer) mow down his court is somewhat reminiscent of a DM growing exasperated with a party that refuses to die.

The nature of the game is a Shoggoth monstrosity that can shift its genre at will between choose-your-own-adventure, Arkham-style brawling, tabletop RPG, and roguelike. To be honest, I could spend hours trying (and failing) to describe it in any decent fashion. Watch a video of it. Jim Sterling's Squirty Play is a good one; it's the release version, and you get to see the reaction of someone who: a) has had no exposure to it, and b) was expecting something very different.

Basically, what makes this game great isn't really the gameplay; the individual parts of it are rather bland. By itself, the combat would be mindlessly dull. By itself, the board game would be ridiculously unfair. By himself, the Dealer would still be a jerk. It's the smooth integration of all the facets of this game that make it such an amazing catch. I'm not sure it will ever be considered a great" (although one can hope)
date:
but it certainly has all the markings of a cult classic.

Pros:
+Very simple and effective gameplay
+Good voice acting (although it IS only the one voice)
+Lack of backstory allows the player's imagination to do its thing
+Although the individual sections of gameplay aren't unique
recommended: the combination certainly is\n+Will shamelessly kill you without truly punishing you\n+Doesn't interrupt gameplay; even on death
hoursPlayed:
you can immediately jump back in
+Endless mode is pretty entertaining
+No ♥♥♥♥♥♥ crafting systems

Cons:
-Combat can be a tad wonky
-The optimization is quite iffy; it will tank your CPU for no apparent reason sometimes. Seems to occur more prominently later in the game. This'll probably be fixed (and it's ALOT better than it used to be)
voteText:
but it should be noted.

Niggles:
~It feels like some of the event triggers are a tad insane
helpfulPercent: particularly the ones with multiple RNG draws. I still haven't completed the River encounter.\n~You can wind up in positions that can break the game in your favor; I've had more than 1k health at one point due to a bit of RNG luck after finding the Ring of Poverty.\n~Flame golems are ridiculous. They take a lot of hurtin' and they dish out even more. When they show up in multi-monster encounters
votesHelpful: it usually means a wipe.\n~The Dealer is an incorrigible cheat. No really
votesTotal: he's a prick.\n\nI'd give it a hearty thumbs up. Buy it."

reviewText:
This game came up in my recommendations list with a lot of positive reviews and looked interesting so I gave it a shot.  Very glad I did, this game is really good.

It's a deck builder - a card game where you gain more, better cards to add to your deck as you progress through the game.  You sit at a table facing a hooded mage who controls the cards and narrated the story.  The voice acting is very good and once you have drawn the same card a couple of times the narration for that card is muted so you don't end up running through the same dialoque game after game.  It's kind of like playing a single player RPG with the mage as DM expanding the story around the cards drawn.  The voice (and the image of the DM to a degree) put me in mind of John Hurt which is cool.

The DM deals out a number of cards in a pattern depicting the path (or paths) you have to travel before meeting the final enemy.  You can choose which way to go by which cards you turn over on the path (although some are straight so no choice) and you can be lucky and find the exit to the next level quickly meaning you can skip forward but possibly miss out on finding a shop or other useful encounter.  I prefer to take my chances of drawing a bad encounter for the benefits of potentially better equipment/more cards.

The decks consist of armour, weapons, enchantments and food as well as enounters both good and bad.  Some enounters involve a test of luck where you have to choose a 'success' card from a selection of four cards.  These are displayed before being shuffled so there is a chance you can follow the best card before they are dealt face down.  Winning encounters let you draw cards from your deck giving you the chance to upgrade your armour, weapons or giving you more food (needed to heal)

It's not just a static card game however.  The battles are actually played out as a third person skirmish with you controlling your character fighting, blocking and using any special abilities granted by your equipment.  This is the part that really marks the game out as different and deepens your sense of involvement - you're not just sat at a table playing cards, you are truly part of the story which is unfolding.

Completing the final enemy grants you additional cards for your deck and every fourth quest grants you an item from the DM levelling up both your character and the enemies you will face.

If you are unfamiliar with deckbuilding or just want to progress to the next game quickly, at the start of each quest you have the option of using a recommended deck based on y0our cards.  If you wish, you can then go in and edit the deck to your satisfaction although newly gained cards will not reveal their effects until they have been played.

There is the skill of choosing which cards you own will be best suited to the upcoming quest.  This gets more important the further you progress and the more cards you have.

Overall, a very enjoyable and quite relaxing game, definitely worth the money.

reviewText:
Only half way through the game. The bad is that the combat seems a little janky (non-smooth animation transitions) but looking past that it's really fun.

The core of the game, or at least what it is trying to accomplish, is really cool and very different then anything I am used too. The dealer interaction with you and the cards adds so much to this game. The game is mostly driven by RNG, but unless you get really unlucky things seem to be easy to accomplish if you think about what you're doing before you do it.

I regret many of my game purchases, but I do not regret this one. Good work.

reviewText:
Put your life into the hands of fate, and see what the cards hold for you;

This game is unique in every sense of the word. It balances random encounters (which by the way, you may choose and add freely), Lady fortune, an incredibly challenging gameplay that grows harder yet more fascinating the further you continue.

I consider myself bad at writing these reviews, and let me tell you words truly do fall short when playing it.
When I tried my computer specs for this game it said my graphical card was a failure (33%) on Systemrequirementlabs, YET it runs like a CHARM. did NOT even touch the specs at all, and its simply beautiful and has no FPS or anything.

Its a very addictive game, you can quit at ANY time, and continue playing just where you left off (Note : The game is played with a reset of equipment at every finish / start of the game) and you may choose which equipment you can get into your game (By fortune of course, and don't worry it's not too easy to get.)

The challenges and overcoming them is just brilliantly and incredible. The game is a gem, and sadly I havent touched wildcards yet seeing as I want to finish the story mode fully; but let me tell you that this game is really a must have in my opinion.

Not many times have I paid for a game on steam and actually thought I got my full moneys worth". I believe this game will haunt me

reviewText: Quite fun as a mix of a board game & card game in mechanics with a bit of combat thrown in. Highly addictive game where you assemble a deck of cards on what you might encounter for equipment or encounters with the stranger you are playing against has his own cards to throw against you. From there the cards you pick for encounters are put out in a path for each section where sometimes you have a choice & others it's a straight path.\n\nSometimes it's more of a 3rd person adventure style of combat against different opponents, other times with the encounters, you are given cards that have various success & failure, take your pick & your gains or losses will sometimes unlock new cards adding to the addictive nature of the game. Blessings & curses are random later on to make things quite a challenge as you gain new tactics to use or avoid to help you on your quest. From the unlocked cards, you can go back to battle old bosses with the added challenge of taking new cards in to make a familiar encounter completely new depending on the cards you get from what you picked. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Fun. Straightforward. Atmospheric. Pick up and play.
If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a card game against a mysterious wizard, then this is the game for you. Just by sitting at a table to play cards against this man, the game does a wonderful job at world building. It creates the impression you're in some sort of Arabian Nights tale, or perhaps one of the Call of Cthulhu back stories. Either way, I was quickly sucked in.

All the card game's rules are handled by your wizard friend, who is both your opponent and your friendly dealer. The learning process for this game was quick. The tutorial is a natural part of the game and a natural part of story progression, which I thought was well done.


+ The Game Itself
The wizard lays out a series of face down cards connected like a road. Your little chess hero starts at one end and has to jump from one card to the next to reach the Big Bad at the other end. Each card you land on is turned over and will result in a random event. Sometimes it will mean combat (that will take you into 3rd person combat mode) but many other times it will be games of chance, or decision making that may affect you later, or risky opportunities. In the end, you reach the Big Bad, enter combat and fight to the death. Victory means you win new cards to add to your deck and a chance to play again to fight a new Big Bad. Defeat means the wizard reshuffles and deals again. You keep your victories over the previous Big Bads though.


+ Combat
Fighting is all about building up hit streaks and finding a rhythm. Mouse and keyboard controls are slightly
'janky' but not bad enough to get in the way or make you lose a fight. There are many cards that enhance the things you can do in combat - they add weapons, equipment, spells, and so on. The combat mechanics are simple and could be improved, but the simplicity of the combat is also what allows this game to be a pick up and play" type of game. I like the starting animation when your hero enters combat and puts on his gear
date:
it's clever and it's an excellent in-game way to remind the player what cards he or she might be able to use in combat.


+ Card Collecting
Each time I won a game I unlocked new cards which I could add to my deck and play in the next game. The cards I unlocked were random
recommended:
but also related to my wins and losses to the little battles and tests of luck against the wizard during the game. It made me feel like I had earned them.


+ Deck Building
If you know that the next card game is going to focus heavily on undead
hoursPlayed: for example
voteText: then you may want to tailor your deck in that direction. The deck builder is straightforward
helpfulPercent: but if you don't want to bother building a deck
votesHelpful: the game will build it for you and it does a good job. I never unlocked too many cards per game
votesTotal: so I never felt swamped
votesFunny: so I always made my own deck. Just to add some spice
commentsCount: the game hid the precise details of new cards until I landed on them in a game
column16: so if I added them to my deck it was a gamble
column17:
but a necessary one.


+ Random Events
These cards are the bulk of the game and they are what make it so much fun. They are surpisingly varied
column18: and you can even encounter the same card you've seen before and get a totally different experience from it. These cards
column19: coupled with the dialogue from the Wizard
column20: who was talking directly to me
column21:
made the game feel personal and turned every victory or loss from these cards into a fun wager.


+ Lore & Atmosphere
There is some lore surrounding the Big Bads and there's some lore present in the description of the various characters you meet while travelling
column22: but overall it is light. All the atmospheric strength and character of this game emanates from three places: The first is the wizard and his desk. His hands and his eyes are expressive
column23:
I just dig him. The second is the Wizard's voice. I found him wry and sarcastic at times but also dark when he needed to be. And the third place is the deck of cards. I thought the art on the cards was well done and perfectly suited to this type of game.


+ Game Time
A single game might be 15 to 30 minutes. So it's perfect for that moment of downtime. I'd say that during that harder difficulties you're more likely to spend 30 minutes on a game than 15
column24: because you'll try different strategies or try for more cards

the game runs at your pace.


+ Other Thoughts
- This is a game for someone who values their time

reviewText:
This is a game I keep coming back to. As a concept it's great, building on an interesting collectable card game and adding an fun 3rd-player melee combat game on top.  It has it's flaws, like the annoying camera angle. At times it can be frustrating - but I find it's better in short doses of gameplay.

Beyond the gameplay - the art and sound in this game are great, and the voice acting from the game master fits the mood perfectly (if again a little annoying with some of the repetition).

Overall this is a 8.5/10 game.

reviewText: Alot of people talk about Rogue-likes as these hard-core, unforgiving, all-or-nothing, RNG dependant dungeon crawls... and many of them are. However, if you've played the original Rogue (or Rogue Legacy), you'll find that many game designers who classify their game as a Rogue-like" have only copied the most sadistic parts of that game and ignored some of the more interesting and rewarding parts.\n\nHand of Fate manages to replicate some of the progression aspects that the original Rogue utilized that made me actually love that game and reconsider the "Rogue-like" genre entirely. Hand of Fate
recommended: is not all-or-nothing. Rather it's a game of incrimental progress. You fight your way as far as you can

votesHelpful: those tokens reveal and add weapons

reviewText:
-Straight playthrough can probably take several hours (depending on difficulty). Even though I went through one playthrough, I was left pretty satisfied.

A pretty entertaining adventure game that involves cards and chance. You set up two decks that involve cards of scenarios you can encounter and the equipment you can receive during your adventure. As you progress through the game, you unlock more cards and can build larger decks and have a greater variety of situations and items to experience. While the game does have a diffuclty option, in a way, the way you customize your deck can add an entirely new dimension of diffuclty to the game. Personally, that mechanic is probably what stood out the most. Even if you are playing a high difficulty, you could fill your decks with scenarios that could make things a bit easier. Of course, still expect the game overall and all of its aspects to be challenging, you choose a high difficulty overall. Combat system of arena combat is a nice break from selecting and reading cards.

The game has the means to produce several playthroughs, difficulty, classes, or trying to experience all the given scenarios.

Just by sitting at a table to play cards against this man, the game does a wonderful job at world building. It creates the impression you're in some sort of Arabian Nights tale, or perhaps one of the Call of Cthulhu back stories. Either way, I was quickly sucked in.

All the card game's rules are handled by your wizard friend, who is both your opponent and your friendly dealer. The learning process for this game was quick. The tutorial is a natural part of the game and a natural part of story progression, which I thought was well done.


+ The Game Itself
The wizard lays out a series of face down cards connected like a road. Your little chess hero starts at one end and has to jump from one card to the next to reach the Big Bad at the other end. Each card you land on is turned over and will result in a random event. Sometimes it will mean combat (that will take you into 3rd person combat mode) but many other times it will be games of chance, or decision making that may affect you later, or risky opportunities. In the end, you reach the Big Bad, enter combat and fight to the death. Victory means you win new cards to add to your deck and a chance to play again to fight a new Big Bad. Defeat means the wizard reshuffles and deals again. You keep your victories over the previous Big Bads though.


+ Combat
Fighting is all about building up hit streaks and finding a rhythm. Mouse and keyboard controls are slightly
'janky' but not bad enough to get in the way or make you lose a fight. There are many cards that enhance the things you can do in combat - they add weapons, equipment, spells, and so on. The combat mechanics are simple and could be improved, but the simplicity of the combat is also what allows this game to be a pick up and play" type of game. I like the starting animation when your hero enters combat and puts on his gear
date:
it's clever and it's an excellent in-game way to remind the player what cards he or she might be able to use in combat.


+ Card Collecting
Each time I won a game I unlocked new cards which I could add to my deck and play in the next game. The cards I unlocked were random
recommended:
but also related to my wins and losses to the little battles and tests of luck against the wizard during the game. It made me feel like I had earned them.


+ Deck Building
If you know that the next card game is going to focus heavily on undead
hoursPlayed: for example
voteText: then you may want to tailor your deck in that direction. The deck builder is straightforward
helpfulPercent: but if you don't want to bother building a deck
votesHelpful: the game will build it for you and it does a good job. I never unlocked too many cards per game
votesTotal: so I never felt swamped
votesFunny: so I always made my own deck. Just to add some spice
commentsCount: the game hid the precise details of new cards until I landed on them in a game
column16: so if I added them to my deck it was a gamble
column17:
but a necessary one.


+ Random Events
These cards are the bulk of the game and they are what make it so much fun. They are surpisingly varied
column18: and you can even encounter the same card you've seen before and get a totally different experience from it. These cards
column19: coupled with the dialogue from the Wizard
column20: who was talking directly to me
column21:
made the game feel personal and turned every victory or loss from these cards into a fun wager.


+ Lore & Atmosphere
There is some lore surrounding the Big Bads and there's some lore present in the description of the various characters you meet while travelling
column22: but overall it is light. All the atmospheric strength and character of this game emanates from three places: The first is the wizard and his desk. His hands and his eyes are expressive
column23:
I just dig him. The second is the Wizard's voice. I found him wry and sarcastic at times but also dark when he needed to be. And the third place is the deck of cards. I thought the art on the cards was well done and perfectly suited to this type of game.


+ Game Time
A single game might be 15 to 30 minutes. So it's perfect for that moment of downtime. I'd say that during that harder difficulties you're more likely to spend 30 minutes on a game than 15

the game runs at your pace.


+ Other Thoughts

reviewText:
This is a game I keep coming back to. As a concept it's great, building on an interesting collectable card game and adding an fun 3rd-player melee combat game on top.  It has it's flaws, like the annoying camera angle. At times it can be frustrating - but I find it's better in short doses of gameplay.

Beyond the gameplay - the art and sound in this game are great, and the voice acting from the game master fits the mood perfectly (if again a little annoying with some of the repetition).

Overall this is a 8.5/10 game.

reviewText: Alot of people talk about Rogue-likes as these hard-core, unforgiving, all-or-nothing, RNG dependant dungeon crawls... and many of them are. However, if you've played the original Rogue (or Rogue Legacy), you'll find that many game designers who classify their game as a Rogue-like" have only copied the most sadistic parts of that game and ignored some of the more interesting and rewarding parts.\n\nHand of Fate manages to replicate some of the progression aspects that the original Rogue utilized that made me actually love that game and reconsider the "Rogue-like" genre entirely. Hand of Fate
recommended: is not all-or-nothing. Rather it's a game of incrimental progress. You fight your way as far as you can

reviewText:
-Straight playthrough can probably take several hours (depending on difficulty). Even though I went through one playthrough, I was left pretty satisfied.

A pretty entertaining adventure game that involves cards and chance. You set up two decks that involve cards of scenarios you can encounter and the equipment you can receive during your adventure. As you progress through the game, you unlock more cards and can build larger decks and have a greater variety of situations and items to experience. While the game does have a diffuclty option, in a way, the way you customize your deck can add an entirely new dimension of diffuclty to the game. Personally, that mechanic is probably what stood out the most. Even if you are playing a high difficulty, you could fill your decks with scenarios that could make things a bit easier. Of course, still expect the game overall and all of its aspects to be challenging, you choose a high difficulty overall. Combat system of arena combat is a nice break from selecting and reading cards.

The game has the means to produce several playthroughs, difficulty, classes, or trying to experience all the given scenarios.

reviewText:
It's just the game, imho.
I'm not a huge fan of D&D and I never played it (maybe because none of my friends play it) but I'm really in love with GDR, rougelike and card games so I tought that this game was perfect for me and ye it turned out to be.

I really suggest it, at least it worth a try and maybe you will find your new favourite game like I did!

I strongly recommend the game....
But my review will be about the one thing which I feel is the game's weakest point: the combat scenarios.

Each of the combat scenarios take place in a very small area... while this is clearly to heighten the tension and make it more difficult - it ends up leading every battle to be almost identical.   The fighting gets old when every battle feels the same.

reviewText:
Awesome game, one of the rare games I completed.

It's sort of like 'Binding of Isaac' for not so hardcore players.
- It has a sort of Heartstone-ish ( or Gwent from Witcher) play with the cards, deciding your adventure - depending on your choices.


It's just easy and fun. But you will die, you will die a lot. But each game is new and helps keep it fresh.
- And it's fun hunting new cards or try to unlock the token on new cards. And in the end, build your own deck - So you can remove those pesky annoying cards you dislike.


Oh, and there is Endless Mode when the campaign is done. I die so much in that mode, so I've given up on that part of the game, I just enjoy the (doable) campaign - And really would like more!
(Endless mode is a game mode where all cards are in play, and you can continue forever).

Also, the developers have made tons of updates and listen to the community, and now they work on Hand of Fate 2. Which I will buy at full price, as soon as it is out.

Pro Tip; Use it with a controller.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me set the stage: You are in a room. At least it could be a room, but it is so pitch black that you can only see the table in front of you. You are not alone by this table. Across from you sits a hooded figure. Among the various curiosities strewn on the table are sets of cards.

You do not know who this stranger is, who you are, how you got here, or even what lead to this moment. The stranger seems to have the answers to these questions, however, also seems to have no interest in telling you - Instead, he invite you to a game of cards.

From the moment he shuffles the decks of cards, you know this will be no ordenary game of Bridge. And barely has the game begun before you realize what game you are playing. The game is you. Who is this entity in front of you, with the magic to convert memories into a deck of cards? Why does he force you to EARN these memories?

With so many uncertainties, there is only one thing to do. Play.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

the art design and the ambiance are most certainly the key factors making this game shine.

Cons:
- Action sequence less original.
- Slow-pace sequences. (some transitions can be skipped)
- The "I was screwed from the beginning" feeling.

Pros:
- Very unique design direction.
- Blending of different genres.
- Ambiance well-fitted.
- Amount of content.

Hope you enjoy it as much as I am still doing.

reviewText:
Not only did I find Hand of Fate very enjoyable, I found it surprisingly challenging as well. Perhaps not entirely in the best way, but it suits the theme very well.

Hand of Fate is all about maneuvering a playing board made up with cards and going through the dangers that lie within. As you complete these challenges, you'll gain additional cards which will unlock additional treasures and additional challenges. Interestingly enough, the game remains very challenging to slightly unfair levels as time goes on. From the beginning, the first three bosses are simple and you'd be forgiven if you think Hand of Fate is an easy game. Not long afterwards more elements are introduced and older cards/challenges get refreshed to be harder so you can't as easily fall back on them for easy rewards. By the end of the game you're scrabbling for every advantage you can get and if you don't spend your time completing these challenges you're going to be absolutely decimated.

But that ends up being one of the game's major weaknesses. While the game is pretty damn strategic and has you fighting a whole lot of different elements in your quest for ultimate ambigious glory (which is told through an interesting way having the various cards represent your character's various memories and experiences), there's a heavy amount of luck involved as well. Especially late game. Smart players will start spotting good cards to stack their deck with, but there are many moments where the game just decides that you aren't going to win and pits you against a boss who makes all enemies of his faction invincible and another that attacks you relentlessly in a very small area. Meaning that if you're fortunate enough to get 200 health - somehow - you can still end up ♥♥♥♥ed by luck so hard that it'll make your head spin. Throw in a slightly slippery control scheme, enemies who love to dog pile on you, various traps that are at times hard to see or avoid (see the control scheme issue), and your victory ends up having a whole lot of luck involved. And one loss can put you back quite a way which means a lot towards the end game.

That said, from start to finish (though I'm very close to finish now, not quite there yet), Hand of Fate is very well set up and excells at telling a story that's all about the adventure. A neverending adventure really. And a whole lot of insanity that occurs along the way. Plus it's just fun, when it isn't deciding that you're not going to have fun.

voteText: and the way you are completely "unprepared" to what can really happen is great. The action sequences aren't revolutionary and really look alike some well-known attack/dodge system seen in other games. In addition to the unique blend of gameplay
helpfulPercent:
the art design and the ambiance are most certainly the key factors making this game shine.

Cons:
- Action sequence less original.
- Slow-pace sequences. (some transitions can be skipped)
- The "I was screwed from the beginning" feeling.

Pros:
- Very unique design direction.
- Blending of different genres.
- Ambiance well-fitted.
- Amount of content.

Hope you enjoy it as much as I am still doing.

Thanks

reviewText:
This is a very unique game and I recommend you play it. However be aware of the fact that it does have a few issues, despite being late after release.

For starters some cards don't trigger properly, and you might have to guess the solution yourself. For example a card may require you to pay 5 gold, but the option would be grayed out no matter how much you have. On the other hand, if you have 0 gold, you can pay the price and it will be deducted from 0.

Poor card trigger code aside, another issue with the game is the camera. At later levels you will absolutely curse it when traversing traps. What happens is that instead of maintaining a top-down angle, camera is scripted to do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ it wants and provide you with a more cinematic" viewing
recommended: you're trying not to get stabbed
hoursPlayed: shot
voteText: impaled
helpfulPercent: skewered
votesHelpful: crushed and barbequed.\n\nAlso be aware of the somewhat poorly designed combat in the game. At later stages flaws become aparent
votesTotal: such as getting stuck between a turret and the boundary collider that prevents you from falling out of the arena. The dodge is not long enough to dodge certain attacks and traps
votesFunny: and not enough time is given for a second evade in order to avoid damage.\n\nStill
commentsCount: the game is interesting enough to play. The nagging issues prevent it from being a trully entertaining piece

column23: however the lack of a health bar on enemies makes this task akin to playing the lottery.\n\nOther than that HoF provides an interesting perspecting on the roguelike genre and is definitely worth a buy at 50% discount. I recommend the full priced game only for hardcore players or TCG mega fans."

reviewText: It's a turn-based roguelike card-game with realtime combat, a tremendous amount of replayability, and a fantastic atmosphere that brilliantly mixes the creepiness of the dealer with the thrill of a fantastical adventure. The writing is wonderful, and engine updates have made the game visually excellent by most any standards. It's a brilliant game, and easily one of the best of the year.\n\nThe cherry on top? The developers are wonderful. A long time back when the game was still in early access, someone complained about a spider that would crawl around on the table at random times during play. I fired the game up recently to check out the (completely free and quite extensive) Christmas updates, scrolled through the options to see if anything was different, and noticed an option to turn the spider off. These guys are the best, and if the game interests you, they absolutely deserve your money.

reviewText: I haven't written a review for this game yet? Whaaat. Well, it's pretty ♥♥♥♥in' great. Very hard to nail down exactly how it plays, as you might imagine, but let's say it's a card-driven, sorta 80s/90s board game-styled, randomly generated action-adventure game... with combat strongly inspired by the Arkham batman titles. Recent patches and expansion content (some of it free!) have further built upon this very strong foundation by adding new cards of all types, and introducing entirely new difficulties and game modes.\n\nIf the images on the store page, and this recommendation, at all intrigue you, I'd strongly suggest taking the game for a spin. If by some unlikely chance you don't like it, there's always the refund option. But you won't need to because it's radical.

reviewText:
I would like to keep this short, so here I go:
If you are a fan of rogue-like dungeon crawls, deck-building/trading card games, strategy, sword-and-sorcery storylines, and a small dose of blind luck, then this game is for you.

I highly reccomend it for people who like such things, but if you are hesitant, maybe wait until it's on sale. It definitely isn't for everyone, but don't listen to the people who say it's all or heavily luck based, because it's not. A good strategy will win in the end (I reccomend building your own deck, not using their pre-built ones).

It has some minor glitches, so keep that in mind, but they release bug fixes periodically, which makes this okay.

This is a good game to pick up and play either casually, or to get immersed in for hours.

reviewText: This game pulls of a mix of genres so well, it's really quite refreshing. It's such a unique and refreshing twist on everything. I feel like that will lend to so much replayability. The graphics are rather impressive too. For a game just abrely out of early access (apparently) it's really well done. I can't wait to see where they go from here. (This is the first review I've ever typed too I think). 10/10 so glad I bought it.

reviewText:
I want to warn everyone who wants to have this game !
The game starts awesome yet you will stop playing it once you reach 5th or 6th deck (level).

The difficulty of the game increases immensely. Cards won't help you. You will die a lot and you will restart the deck which means you are going to kill everything that you killed previously. Then you will find yourself skipping everything (Cards ask you if you want to cross the river or not ? - Do you want the chest ? or not ?. I personally died a lot and started to click NO to every options to reach the boss fight in order to pass the level and have some other new features. Trust me it does not help !

I need to be honest. I love the atmosphere, ideas and gameplay yet the game design gets too limited when you move further in this game. You play the same fights over and over. You pick the same cards over and over. Still I liked it yet I recommend you to wait for the sale to buy it ;)
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Arkham Combat System (ACS) is the weakest part of the game and highlighted by some of the relatively small arena spaces and somewhat stiff animations. However, every other mechanic of the game makes up for the ACS.

Hand of Fate is an excellent, unique combination of gaming sytems that would best be described as the hidden mechanics of many videogame RPGs brought out and given a life via the cards and their 'choose your own adventure' dealer. The themes and art are great and the narration is fitting and well done. Aside from some personal issues with the ACS, I recommend this to anyone that is a fan of card games and Medieval-style RPGs.

reviewText: Hand of Fate is a really fun card game with beat 'em up elements. The game features two modes; Story and Endless. This will mostly be focused on Story, as I've not played Endless yet.\n\nThe game is fairly simple; the dealer will lie down cards on the table and you will move your piece onto the cards. Sometimes, this is linear, but sometimes it isn't. Some cards will activate things like visiting a shop, encountering baddies to kill, traversing a maze or coming up against a situation where, of 4 cards, you must pick the Success" card in order to win. You will have
hoursPlayed: your food & your gold. Every move consumes 1 food
voteText: but you'll restore lost health. Gold is fairly self-explanatory.\n\nWhen you get an encounter card
helpfulPercent: you are placed onto a small plot of field where you will fight against monsters
votesHelpful: ranging from goblins to skeletons
votesTotal: zombies and bandits. While variation is limited
votesFunny: it doesn't pull away from the experience. However
commentsCount: the fighting / combat is rather wonky; borrowing from the Arkham series
column16: you will basically use WASD to move around and left click to attack. You cannot hard target a specific enemy
column17: which can be a bit frustrating
column18: but again
column19: really doesn't affect the game greatly.\n\nSituation cards vary
column20: from finding a weapon in a crevasse to saving someone from being swarmed by enemies. Successfully "winning" these situations nets you a token from the dealer. At the end
column21: all of your accrued tokens are counted up and you are given specific rewards based on the tokens. For example
column22: I was tasked with defeated a knight that had been overrun by some skeletons. Once I defeated them
column23: he told me I could keep the mace I was given prior to the fight
column24: as his kingdom was flush with them. Once I completed the level
column25: his token rewarded me with 2 Mace cards.\n\nYou progress through the 'levels' by travsering through the cards
column26: finding that particular level's 'end card' and moving onto the next level. At the end of the final level
column27: you will fight a boss. Defeating the boss gives you more tokens
column28: which unlock things like weapons
column29: armor
column30: encounters and other varying cards.\n\nOne of the coolest things this game offers is the Deck Builder. On one side
column31: your deck has cards for Equipment; weapons and armor and trinkets. The other side are your encounters
column32: from visiting shops to situations. If the card has a lock icon on it
column33: that means it has a situation / encounter you've yet to face. Drawing & defeating that card will net you another token.\n\nLast but not least is the Dealer himself; an elderly mage who speaks to you throughout the game. His dialogue is superb and I found myself actively listening to what he had to say. The first level

column35: I drew the card again and

column38: but the fact he recognizes that made me smile.\n\nI know my hours played as of writing this is low (think it's barely 2 hours)

reviewText:
I want to warn everyone who wants to have this game !
The game starts awesome yet you will stop playing it once you reach 5th or 6th deck (level).

The difficulty of the game increases immensely. Cards won't help you. You will die a lot and you will restart the deck which means you are going to kill everything that you killed previously. Then you will find yourself skipping everything (Cards ask you if you want to cross the river or not ? - Do you want the chest ? or not ?. I personally died a lot and started to click NO to every options to reach the boss fight in order to pass the level and have some other new features. Trust me it does not help !

I need to be honest. I love the atmosphere, ideas and gameplay yet the game design gets too limited when you move further in this game. You play the same fights over and over. You pick the same cards over and over. Still I liked it yet I recommend you to wait for the sale to buy it ;)

reviewText:
The Arkham Combat System (ACS) is the weakest part of the game and highlighted by some of the relatively small arena spaces and somewhat stiff animations. However, every other mechanic of the game makes up for the ACS.

Hand of Fate is an excellent, unique combination of gaming sytems that would best be described as the hidden mechanics of many videogame RPGs brought out and given a life via the cards and their 'choose your own adventure' dealer. The themes and art are great and the narration is fitting and well done. Aside from some personal issues with the ACS, I recommend this to anyone that is a fan of card games and Medieval-style RPGs.

Plus the narrator/dealer has wonder dialouge and is voiced beautifully.

reviewText: This is a really fun game, it basically uses a tarot-like card system to set up randomly generated level layouts for you to traverse towards a goal. The card events add various elements of gameplay such as fighting and decision making, each done in their own way and luck is tested frequently to determine the successfulness of your choices. If you like rpgs, rogue-like and tarot cards then this game would be good for you.

reviewText:
I ONLY KIND OF RECOMMEND THIS GAME WITH THESE CAVEATS:

I do NOT recommend paying 25 dollars for it (which is the going price as of the writing of this review.)

I've put a good 30 hours into it so far, and I think after beating the final challenge, I'll be done with it until there is more DLC or a HoF2. Once you've completed the encounters, there's really only a few variants in Endless mode that are somewhat interesting, but I don't think I'll be playing through them all, as they consist of encounters I've seen a million times.

The gameplay consists of a randomly dealt and organized map of cards which you traverse. When you complete encounter cards, you get tokens, which unlock new items, encounters, and more, which pertain to the cards defeated. The difficulty of these encounters ramps up very quickly and sometimes seem impossible with their ridiculous requirements, which bank almost soley on your luck in drawing the right encounters previously.

This is a huge problem, as a lot of the encounters rely on luck rather than skill. The bigger problem is, a lot of skill portions rely on how well your luck is at picking success cards in those encounters (if you can't play Four Card Monte and follow the Success cards, you will not enjoy this game). It took me a lot of grinding to finish a lot of the encounter cards, and as of right now, I still have not beaten the main Story mode, because you are restricted by the curses you are given when you enter a level, and the last boss has ridiculously overpowered curses that make the last level about luck rather than challenge.

The combat in this game is similar to the Batman Arkham games, which is cool, and very close to as smooth as those games. But the VERY limited enemy selection and TRUE boss battles (not just better versions of main enemies) makes this tedious over time. The selection of weapons gets bigger as you finish more encounters, but as you are given them randomly during play, a perfect loadout is left to chance, which is mostly ok, considering a perfect loadout would make you practically invincible, but not ok when you end up with nothing at the end of a dungeon because of a poorly placed random chance card.

I purchased this game when it was on sale for 9.99, and I think at that price, it's worth it. If you are someone who enjoys a challenge, this is a very challenging game, but the challenge is mixed in with a fair amount of true unfairness, which I think sometimes is confused for challenge.

Just know that this will be frustrating as all get-out.

reviewText:
I recommend this game, BUT at a discount.  During a sale or something.

I think the game is pretty fun, but has a few flaws that keep it from beign significantly better.  I've never been really into Dungeons and Dragons, but I've always thought the concept was fun.  Basically, this takes some of the ideas of dungeon exploring from D&D and puts you in the place of the single player of the game, playing against the Dungeon Master.  As a genius add-on, rather than rolling dice to determine the outcome of enemy encounters, you enter a 3D action battle that plays very much like the Batman: Arkham series (which I really enjoyed).  Overall, great idea and production quality.

On the overall card/exploring portion of the game:
The idea is fun and I enjoy running into new cards and seeing the outcome and individual stories as they unfold over multiple playthroughs.   Each run plays similar to a rogue-like in that you play a ~20 minutes session where you start from scratch and progress through a dungeon, trying to become more powerful while maintaining your life, food and gold.  Here's where it takes a turn.

I enjoy hard games.  But I like to have the difficult and whether I win or not depend on my skill, not luck.  The game has multiple difficulty settings, but I feel like it either needs more (preferred choice) or needs to balance them better.  I find normal mode to be incredibly easy, where hard mode is too hard.  I play a run on normal mode and come out with far more life and strength than I went in with, rarely even being hit by enemies, or play hard mode and only make it half-way through the run.  Well, get better!  This is part of it, but often times, as mentioned by other reviewers, you run into an unlucky location and  half of your max life, most of your food, etc...   I would say that combat is about 4x harder on hard mode than on normal mode because: 1. The enemies are stronger. 2. There are twice as many of them.  It would be nice to be able to balance the difficulty with a mode between normal and hard. Maybe where there are twice as many of them, but they aren't stronger.

All-in-all I think the dungeon portion of the game is fun, but can be frustrating when everything goes down the tube over the course of 3 steps.

As far as teh combat:
I really enjoy  the combat style and feel that it complements the game well.  That being said, it could use quite a bit of polish.  After having played the first two Batman: Arkham games on hard mode and mastering the challenges, I feel that I am pretty good at the combat.  That carries over to some degree here.  The Batman games  (at least on hard mode) are heavily combo focused and require you to keep an eye on your enemies, the combo counter and plan your next move carefully.  Trying to attack an enemy that is down or trying to counter when an enemy has not begun an attack ruins your combo.  This is all the same in Hand of Fate BUT it is not nearly as clear what is happening.  When you finish an enemy on Batman, you hear a Whoosh" sound.  You know he is down.  As crazy as it may get sometimes
date: you have all of the indicators to know exactly what is happening with each enemy on the battlefield at all times.  In Hand of Fate
hoursPlayed: it can be hard to tell who is dead and who is not and counters seem to misfire fairly often.  It's pretty regular to attack an enemy you didn't mean to.  With the challenges of hard mode I would feel prepared to take it on if I had better control and awareness in battle.\n\nOverall
voteText: I think it is a fun game.  Take the great parts of the rogue-like genre

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a good game, the simple brawler mechnics of the combat sequences are fun and challenging enough, like a slightly harder version of the Arkham/Batman games with far fewer variables or moves.  The narrator is amusing, the graphics cartoonish in a lovely way that pops on the screen totally appropriate for a game that is within a game.

The basic conciet of the game though is pretty briulliant - the player is playing cards against the enigmatic narrator who is some sort of dyspeptic frog voiced oracle or wizard. He's fun enough and he has new quips for most new cards, but I could I can see a DLC with a different dealer being profoundly satisfying - say a urbane devil, petulant child or defeatist death.  The card came is itself an adventure, with the randomly selected (you can build the decks though - within certian limits) card laid down and most cards offering a garphic of a charming woodblock image, a paragraph and a choice.  most selections lead to a pick and choose mechnic where four cards representing degrees of success and failure are shuffled monty style and the player picks one.  Other cards lead to combat.  In general when the player is successful with a card they gain a token that's convereted to another card at the end of each game.  Thus as one plays more and more choices are added.  It's fun, and for an unlock" method of providing content feels very natural.

Despite that praise
date: I almost gave this gave a thumbs down because even now
recommended: long after release (and to the developers' credit the seem to keep adding cards and content) the game seems to suffer from technical issues.  It lags
hoursPlayed: it slows and it crashes with alarming regularity on my laptop - which while no gaming machine is well above the minimum specs.  This isn't a general set of errors
voteText: more a steady degradation of capability culminating in multi minute load times for combat sequences or simply sudden crashes in the combat engine.  Whatever the cause these errors
helpfulPercent: they make the game frustratingly unplayable - becauase I want to play it and it's a good game.\n\nI'm still giving it a positive rating here because when it does work (and sometimes it's fine) it's a very fun

reviewText:
Think DnD mixed with RPG combat style and some rougelike elements and you have a basic idea what this game is.

The idea is creative, the graphics are very well done and it works suprisingly smoothly.

The game itself has some elements I was looking for in MMORPG games for far too long, like ministories that reveal themselves only when you successfully beat something that has nothing to do with the main story (or anything, really) and it is great to see a game that uses these mechanics so well.

To me it is a surprise that virtual card games can be so engaging. Only problem with the game is that sometimes when entering a battle the crashes, but even that is not such a big deal since the progress is saved for every card you complete.

I would totally buy a set of these cards in real life. With some dice and small changes like not saying the same text every time you get the same card this would make a great bored game.

reviewText:
The game is definitely worth the price.
Everything looks exetremely well done: starting from the SUPERB voice of the Deckmaster to the well polished mechanics and brawl combat style (Shadow of Mordor/Batman) to the great variety of the cards and deck customization.
The game feels a bit easy at the very start but after you've faced and defeated the Jack of Skulls you realize that the game is not a walk in the park (especially if played hard mode)
I'm still playing with the suggested decks for each mission, as it's the fastest way to learn the newly unlocked cards... but I'll start fiddling with my deck as soon as possible to test new combinations and different playthru
Highly recommended!
Defintely a hidden shiny jewel!

reviewText:
overall - great game, But do not buy it as a hack n' slash game.

hand of fate offers a pretty unique experience, melding cards, adventure, combat, and a bit of role-playing. This game does not do one of those things terribly well, my opinion, some may argue. What it does do well is make the whole situation work, all of these elements together, how random and unsyncable they may seem, come together to make a really interesting experience.

I would compare hand of fate to a very simple table top game, munchkin perhaps. You get a map made up of cards, which are adventures, meetings, shops, curses, and eventually - an exit from the current map. Each game has a certain amount of maps, and then you get to the end, where instead of an exit, you get a boss. So far, the boss has been an upgraded version of one of the vanilla enemies, with a twist. The combat is boring at best, but this is coming from someone who has difficulty capped 2 souls games.

Honestly, I give the game about a 8 right now with the boring combat. The narrative of each game makes up for it, I would really almost prefer a table top combat to the hack n' slash that they have. more strategic, maybe involve rolls - but that might ruin the balance they got going, so i dunno.

One thing it does need is a workshop for endless customizability. Also, I would be over the friggin moon if they figured out a way to make multiplayer work.

reviewText:
The Dealer is what makes this game. Considering you spend 95% of your time interacting with him and listening to him, if he was in anyway written terribly, or voiced terribly, then it would kill the game for you because otherwise, all you had was some fun quests and mediocre Arkham combat.

Thankfully, the Dealer is engaging, hardly ever repeats his lines, and even then, his delivery is so snarky and full of personality and flavor, you don't mind occasionally hearing the same line again. He will have up to 3, perhaps even more, different lines for the same card, or same kind of card (like the Helpful Priest line of cards, where he shows his disdain of the clergy).

The Dealer's performance is what sells and buoys this game, especially as the rest of its features and mechanics, while serviceable, really aren't much to talk about. Specifically, the combat is closer I think to Assassin's Creed, where sitting and waiting on the counter indicator to appear is the best way to go, especially if you put it on Hard Mode from the outset (which I recommend, as otherwise the combat pace is even slower and easier).

I would recommend buying this game on sale. I got mind for $10 during 2015's Holiday Sale, and it's completely worth the $10. At its full price, I would have hoped that the combat mechanics be more polished, as they do bring down the whole package and presentation of the game.

reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a good game, the simple brawler mechnics of the combat sequences are fun and challenging enough, like a slightly harder version of the Arkham/Batman games with far fewer variables or moves.  The narrator is amusing, the graphics cartoonish in a lovely way that pops on the screen totally appropriate for a game that is within a game.

The basic conciet of the game though is pretty briulliant - the player is playing cards against the enigmatic narrator who is some sort of dyspeptic frog voiced oracle or wizard. He's fun enough and he has new quips for most new cards, but I could I can see a DLC with a different dealer being profoundly satisfying - say a urbane devil, petulant child or defeatist death.  The card came is itself an adventure, with the randomly selected (you can build the decks though - within certian limits) card laid down and most cards offering a garphic of a charming woodblock image, a paragraph and a choice.  most selections lead to a pick and choose mechnic where four cards representing degrees of success and failure are shuffled monty style and the player picks one.  Other cards lead to combat.  In general when the player is successful with a card they gain a token that's convereted to another card at the end of each game.  Thus as one plays more and more choices are added.  It's fun, and for an unlock" method of providing content feels very natural.

Despite that praise
date: I almost gave this gave a thumbs down because even now
recommended: long after release (and to the developers' credit the seem to keep adding cards and content) the game seems to suffer from technical issues.  It lags
hoursPlayed: it slows and it crashes with alarming regularity on my laptop - which while no gaming machine is well above the minimum specs.  This isn't a general set of errors
voteText: more a steady degradation of capability culminating in multi minute load times for combat sequences or simply sudden crashes in the combat engine.  Whatever the cause these errors
helpfulPercent: they make the game frustratingly unplayable - becauase I want to play it and it's a good game.\n\nI'm still giving it a positive rating here because when it does work (and sometimes it's fine) it's a very fun

reviewText:
Think DnD mixed with RPG combat style and some rougelike elements and you have a basic idea what this game is.

The idea is creative, the graphics are very well done and it works suprisingly smoothly.

The game itself has some elements I was looking for in MMORPG games for far too long, like ministories that reveal themselves only when you successfully beat something that has nothing to do with the main story (or anything, really) and it is great to see a game that uses these mechanics so well.

To me it is a surprise that virtual card games can be so engaging. Only problem with the game is that sometimes when entering a battle the crashes, but even that is not such a big deal since the progress is saved for every card you complete.

I would totally buy a set of these cards in real life. With some dice and small changes like not saying the same text every time you get the same card this would make a great bored game.

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME! It's a new take on an RPG that I've never experienced, that and the create your own adventure part of it brings back memories of the books I read as a child. It mixes RPG/Card Game/Create Your Own Adventure so well, I am about half way through the story mode, have yet to touch the Endless Mode but I definitely will after I finish the story. I couldn't stop playing, I put 8 plus hours in straight, minus roughly 1 hour for a break I took to eat and watch a show.

Basically how this game goes (its awesome) is you sit face to face with the guy who created the game essentially at a table, he opens his cabinet of boss enemies and you must take one boss out at a time. So each journey you unlock cards, weapons, armor, blessings etc etc that become part of your deck. You can build your deck between journies. One boss takes you through a journey where you'll face numerous enemies, mazes of death, merchants, people that need help, all kinds of things. You get a choice to whether or not you are good or bad or you will help or you won't. You'll be rewarded in some way, either way whether that's good or bad. That's the create your own adventure part, gives you control of what choices you make in the game and the consequences of those choices. It's very cool.

What is also REALLY awesome is you actually do battle yourself when you come across enemies or a boss etc, the cards dont just animate the fight, you'll take control of your character and have to take on all the enemies yourself, it's really fun. So the character (which you can look at anytime in the inventory along with your other goodies/curses/blessings etc) will change his appearance based on what armor or weapons you have equipped. You can counter enemies when wielding a shield and get various items that do different things, different weapons, helmets, armor, braces etc that have different properties, it's quite cool.

This game is worth every penny, I can't say enough about it, one of the best games I've played in a long while. I'm glad a friend of mine told me about it.

reviewText:
The Dealer is what makes this game. Considering you spend 95% of your time interacting with him and listening to him, if he was in anyway written terribly, or voiced terribly, then it would kill the game for you because otherwise, all you had was some fun quests and mediocre Arkham combat.

Thankfully, the Dealer is engaging, hardly ever repeats his lines, and even then, his delivery is so snarky and full of personality and flavor, you don't mind occasionally hearing the same line again. He will have up to 3, perhaps even more, different lines for the same card, or same kind of card (like the Helpful Priest line of cards, where he shows his disdain of the clergy).

The Dealer's performance is what sells and buoys this game, especially as the rest of its features and mechanics, while serviceable, really aren't much to talk about. Specifically, the combat is closer I think to Assassin's Creed, where sitting and waiting on the counter indicator to appear is the best way to go, especially if you put it on Hard Mode from the outset (which I recommend, as otherwise the combat pace is even slower and easier).

I would recommend buying this game on sale. I got mind for $10 during 2015's Holiday Sale, and it's completely worth the $10. At its full price, I would have hoped that the combat mechanics be more polished, as they do bring down the whole package and presentation of the game.

reviewText:
Overall a very enjoyable experience.
The story unfolds through the cards, giving little glimpses of a plot that the game leaves to your interpretation.
The combat in itself is pretty basic, but then again, there sholdn't even be action combat in this kind of game, so it comes off as a very nice breath of fresh air from the standard rogue-like game.
The soundtrack is pretty sweet, the sound effects are never exxagerated or annoying and the dealer's voice is just perfect.
The only really bad side of this game is in the last 2-3 story runs:
While the game ups its difficulty by adding new cards and mechanics and presenting you with choices for its full (very enjoyable) duration, the last runs, especially the final run, is completely based on RNG and there is absolutely nothing you can do about it. You try and die countless times until you finally get that perfect run where everything just runs smoothly.

However, that is only true for the last story run, the whole game is really enjoyable and the Endless Mode gives some pretty nice replayability.

[Possible Spoilers Do not read further]
The game ends in the most abrupt manner.
You beat the Dealer, screen goes black, you're back at the starting screen.
No cheeky comment, no ending, no nothing.
It ends so badly that i actually thought i experienced a glitch, that some cutscene of some sort just got jumped for some reason, but that doesn't seem to be the case.
And honestly after the phisical torture that is the last Story Run, i at least wanted some insight on the Dealer, the Player, the game, something, ANYTHING, but it just didn't happen and it tastes so bitter.

reviewText: Very unique, and interesting game and most importantly a lot of fun! If you like gamebooks (esp. fighting fantasy series), you will like this game, and if you enjoy RPGs I highly suggest giving this game a chance. You play as an adventurer who has to defeat a set of bosses that are like tiers of each other, but not really in a way making it repetetive. You collect cards that make up the game and put them in the main playing deck and basically yours are meant to better your chances, and the dealer puts in cards to make it more challenging. Its amazingly fun collecting the cards to unlock new encounters and the dlc is actually a rare dlc that does in fact give you something new, it adds cards that change the rules from the start which makes it a LOT more replayable.The artwork is GREAT, like I mean really, really good and the fights sequences gain a lot from that. I esp. like the tomb/crypt area when you fight undead. The real only negatives are that the fights can get a bit boring, but not really such a big deal....another thing is a pretty annoying bug that causes background card shuffle noises (pls fix!!!!) that drives you mad if you don´t restart the game lol. All in all great, unique title worth its money with innovative ideas and solid gameplay I rate 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is brilliant and I beleive it's only just began to scratch the surface of it's true potential.

It's basically fable meets D&D meets a card game!

The story is played out as different cards are placed onto the table, the further through the game you progress and the more cards you get the more random and wide spread the events will become, coming across less of the same card events in each playthough.

I would hope that the game developers would put a 2 player co-op into the game which would be fun to play with friends. But this is not exactly a deal breaker.

A workshop for this game with card creators for quest and dungeons would also be Great!

Although the combat is slightly clunky the game is a very enjoyable experience.

I would recommend buying this game even in it's Early access state, it's just good fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very unique card game that transports you from the table into adventures/battles that are somewhat randomly generated by the cards that are dealt. The game itself oozes style and originality and is executed very well. I felt myself helplessly and gladly being drawn in by the great atmosphere, music, and voice acting that is top notch and very appropriate for the game.

I've only came across minor bugs as one would expect in an early release that were admittedly annoying at times. The game in its current state has an unrelenting learning curve that comes out of nowhere after the first few bosses. I also felt the combat tutorial was somewhat lacking as it didn’t explain everything you can do such as ground executions.

Other than these minor qualms I highly recommend buying it. I was very pleasantly surprised by how fun this game is to play and I look forward to future releases.

reviewText:
Updated: 7th July, 2015

I love this game and want to have the Australian developers' kangaroo babies.

The game mechanics are difficult to explain, since I've never seen any game like this. You get to pick half of the cards that will appear in the game ( your favourite weapons, armour and positive encounters ), the computer picks the other half ( rusty weapons, monsters, curses and negative encounters ).

The computer shuffles your deck with his deck, this creates true procedural generation. No two games will ever be the same. The cards are placed, so as to simulate floors in a building and corridors.

This is Kenuty's excellent Early Access gamplay video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRc6O9HeP6w

The combat for the first few quests consisted of simple attack and parry but scaled up to God of War 1" meets "Golden Axe" with: tumble
recommended:
magical weapons and magical artifacts.

There are 12 different quests. It took me 20 hours to finish three quarters of the game ( at which point I had only unlocked a little over half of the equipment cards and half of the encounter cards ie. the game is massive ). It took me another 20 hours to finish the last three missions because they are brutal. I highly recommend this game to hardcore gamers!

If you want to make the game easier or harder
hoursPlayed:
there is a "Wildcards" expansion that will do that:

http://store.steampowered.com/app/350460/

The voice narration is eloquent. I thought that it was narrated by Jeremy Irons but it was voiced by Anthony Skordi. The dialogue is immersive and teaches you the game mechanics on the fly
voteText:
as you encounter the different cards.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pLSEOkX83yE"

reviewText:
I don't write reviews often, but i started writing this for my friends on facebook and accidently reviewed it.
So here is my very positive review.

Guys, If you ever wanted a game that supports Australia in the game development industry. I cant stress this enough.
GET HAND OF FATE.
This game is amazing.
Created by Defiant Development, this game mixs a table top card game with a top down action rpg.
After the tutorial, you have to edit your deck (or use a reccomended preset) and in doing this you choose what encounters, shops, weapons, armor and enchantments will be randomly drawn throughout the game.
These items get reset every game, but you add to the total cards in the deck. Which means you have wider variety to build a play deck with.
Each floor consists of face down cards. These are encounters. You have to move your token across these, one after another, down the depths to find the boss at the end of the dungeon.
This part is similar to Nethack.
Each time you touch a new card, you have to decide how to deal with it.
Be it scaling down a cliffside to reach a weapon or an angry mob wanting to steal your food.
Resources!
In this you have 3 resources.
First, obviously, is your health. This is gained each time you move or take a heal action through an encounter. Maximum health can be gained or lost through different successes or failures. Lose all of this and you have lost the game.
Second. Food.
Food is used to move. Consuming 1 food per movement. There are events in this where you can lose or gain food, sometimes lose all of it too, very harsh as i learned.
If your food has fallen to 0 then every movement will cost -10 health.
Food is gained through combat, gain cards or shops.
Third. Gold.
What dungeon crawler would exist without the treasure?
Gold is used to shop with, buy off bribes or charity through events.
Gold can be stolen from you and you can also gain it through events or combat.
Now, this gets better. because you have a full inventory.
Head, Armour, Hands, Weapon, Shield, Trinkets.
Lots of combos that do lots of things.
Some weapons have elemental damage that do extra to different creatures, or less!.
This can be found in treasure chests through events, given to you, bought, sold.
These items are preset into the deck by the deck builder, but you dont just get them, you need to EARN them in the game.
Combat is simple and short, but enjoyable.
The dealer will select monster cards (or you do, depending on the event)
These monster cards will say things like Four of Skulls or 3 of Dust.
The 4 of Skulls will summon 4 Skeletons. 3 of Dust will summon 3 bandits.
The combat now moves into a character control, no longer a card game but a top down action rpg, think of Diablo and you will be getting close.
Combat is a little clunky, but nothing to make this game anything of any sort of shabby.
Some weapons have abilities like exploding, gaining damage through combos, do more damage the less health you have, that sort of thing.
Some shields can reflect range damage back and some trinkets will do things like throw 8 daggers around you, some will activate and give you gold-per-hit and some will give you temp poison.
The goal of this is to kill all 12 bosses in the story mode, all with a varying range of tactics.
So once again, Want to support Australian developers and get something worth while out of it?
Hand of Fate.
