reviewText:
Hand of Fate is a game I've been seeing around lately, hearing a lot of solid words from trusted sources and fellow gamers, and of course some harsh criticisms, which is to be expected, but the one theme that keeps popping up is that it is addicting as hell. Combining elements from card games such as Hearthstone and Magic the Gathering, board games like Dungeons and Dragons, as well as RPGs like Skyrim, Diablo, and The Witcher, this game has all the elements to be the meth of gaming, a blend of a lot of different things making for a hell of a drug, but is it fun? Let's find out, shall we?



Gameplay: 93/100 A-

As I mentioned in the intro, Hand of Fate is a mix of a lot of different things, taking the best aspects of each and nearly seamlessly melding them into one, a feat that is hard enough to do separately, let alone flowing from one to another, but it is an achievement that Defiant have successfully done. Playing through the cards and planning ahead with equipment, magic, traps, all the standards that you can find in other card games, but then the RPG side comes in a bit as you can trade with caravans, should you draw that card, and finally landing on the combat, which is fairly simple to get used to. Attack, blocking, countering, all can be done and the game does flow like water over river stones in the spring time.


Audio: 94/100 A-

The sound effects and music is also done very well. It was never intrusive or overwhelming, Calm when it needed to be and action packed elsewhere. The voice acting has to be the crowning jewel here, where listening to your trainer" felt real. For example
date: leave the game playing during a turn or when picking cards
recommended: he may start babbling or criticizing you for taking too much time. It's an organic feel that I really welcomed and made me chuckle a few times. The combat sounds and ambience is also very well produced
hoursPlayed:
a solid effort on this end.


Visuals: 94/100 A-

Hand of Fate is good to look at
voteText: even at the lowest settings. There is of course clipping issues here and there
helpfulPercent: but I feel like that's going to be an issue in gaming for at least another generation and a half. Anyways
votesHelpful: the colors are all done well and placed in logical locations
votesTotal: things look like they belong as well as drawing inspirations from all the genres that are mashed together in the game: medieval fantasy
votesFunny: gothic dark ages
commentsCount: D&D
column16: it all comes together quite nicely
column17:
giving Hand of Fate a distinct style.


Content: 95/100 A

There are a LOT of cards to play with here
column18: easily competing with other big dogs in the market
column19: both old and new
column20: couple that with the other elements of the game and you're into a lot of replayability
column21: but with that also comes some repetitiveness
column22: and while the latter is annoying
column23: it is also expecting in a game that uses themes from other games which rely on such a large selection of options and randomness. But the game works well together
column24:
keeping me interested even when things became repetitive. It is something you come back just in case that awesome moment happens this time around and you get that ultra rare thing you've always wanted.


Design: 96/100 A+

Like I said
column25: the game flows very well together. Everything is done in moderation and not one aspect of the game overwhelms or overpowers another and I think that is the key to Hand of Fate's popularity
column26:
despite the often complicated genres that it takes inspiration from. A testament to Defiant's understanding of the multiple elements they've taken from.


Performance: 80/100 B-

Now we get into the issues I ran into. While the game itself is brilliant in combining everything together

column36:
so I just learned to ignore them and kept going.


Verdict: 93/100 A-

At the end of it all

column38: where they would be most effective and instead of falling flat

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A weird combination of Arkham-like brawling gameplay, the randomness of the old D&D's Fortune cards and Choose-your-own-Adventure gamebooks with a bit of Roguelike elements thrown into it.

Turns out it's actually quite good.

While the combat gameplay can get a bit stale, the number of encounters and the ambiance can really get you into it, the artstyle serves the game astoundingly well and the game combines a whole lot of well designed mechanics.

If you like western fantasy, old gamebooks and pen & paper RPGs, you'll probably like it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very nice and original gameplay. Very promising game, gamepad requires some fixing.

The game is very original and interesting. A combination of card games, where what you get is determined by what is in your deck and action RPG fights. It feels like a playing a Lone Wolf gamebook where your choices dictate few outcomes biased by your luck (damn!).
At the same time, you do feel like you are just a pawn into the Dealer's hand and the lore is very appealing.

I personally had to play with mouse and keyboard though the game is designed for gamepad: I still don't understand if the gamepad commands are laggy or if just don't activate in menus and fight.
Fights and map loadings feel a bit laggy too.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFloor 3, do I chose to run from the angry mob and chance keeping all my remaing food but risk losing it all and thus succum to the subseqent inevitable starvation? Do I risk searching the remaining cards on a floor in hope of finding better equipment but risk losing everything trying to cross a river, leaving myself bare of armour and weilding only a rusty axe when it comes to challenging the deck boss? These are just some of the many difficult decisions you will face in Hand of Fate. Gripping dialogue and voice acting straight from the off. (The voice actor of the dealer is superb). Immense replayability and customisation through the use of the randomising deck system. Challenging bosses, enemies, events and decision making. I have not seen a game that can blend card based gameplay, with RPG elements such as your equipment, curses and 'artefacts', and actual in game combat. (One criticsm would be the combat system is a bit, well lots of rolling around randomly dodging enemies whilst mashing the LMB...But theres potential for a more substantial combat system in the future, furthermore this is only a minute criticsm in my opinion and should not overshadow the vast quality and diversity this game offers). Icant wait to see what the developers include in later patches and updates, perhaps character facial customisation? Some sort of tech-tree or research tree to go alongside the RPG aspect of the game? Hope everyone, developers included if you are reading this, found this a useful and honest review. Definately recommend getting your hands on this game!

reviewText:
E aê, pessoal!!! Beleza???
Vamos ver um pouco do que é Hand of Fate?
Esse é um jogo que mistura deckbuilder e tabletop card game com ação em terceira pessoa, RPG roguelikish e pouquinho de sobrevivência.
A apresentação do jogo e animações são elegantes e fluídas, e apesar de o gráfico não ser top, é melhor que qualquer coisa que já vi na engine Unity.
A trilha sonora também é maravilhosa e esses 2 elementos provocam uma incrível imersão no jogo e no mundo criado pelo jogo.
A variedade de cartas parece bem grande e interessante.
A geração do ambiente de jogo é baseada nas cartas escolhidas pelo usuário mais as adicionadas pelo... cigano ou sei lá... mas o posicionamento aleatório faz com que cada partida seja única.
O jogo mistura sorte e habilidade de uma maneira bem cativante.
A parte de combate do jogo é um pouco fraquinha, com animações meio lerdas e pouca dinamicidade, mas a aleatoriedade do jogo acaba por adicionar um pouquinho ao combate com skills de armas e artefatos, além de efeitos passivos do equipamento.

reviewText: Fun concept, horrible execution. Game is interesting and enjoyable for about an hour or two but once you're past the first few bosses every run turns into a slow and tedious slog as each one adds more and more events that are basically just boring static debuffs that you don't get any opportunity to mitigate or avoid. Every time you finish or fail a run it sends you all the way back to what is essentially the title screen and you have to sit through a million unskippable animations and spam through a million clunky menus to start the next run. The dealer's voice acting is good and enjoyable until hour two when you realize you've heard the exact same lines twenty times already and you're sick of constantly being forced to wait to make actions until he finishes saying the entirety of his 15 second tangent about fate which wasn't even interesting the first time.\n\nThe combat just gets worse and worse as the game goes too, they throw more and more guys in but the arenas are all tiny and there camera is fixed so you get tons of guys attacking you from onscreen and all the enemy types and especially the later ones have terrible animations that all look the same but are randomly unblockable. There's also really inconsistent bullet time slowdown to try and make your attacks look cool but it just makes your character look like an idiot as he slowly floats through the air swinging his axe while enemies just walk around and set up attacks at normal speed in the background. The combat system is standard Arkham-style Simon Says stuff but it's the clunkiest version of any game to use it and nothing about it feels good or consistent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine Hearthstone, Batman AA, D&D, Darkest Dungeon, and Gauntlet had a baby...that baby's name is Hand of Fate. Then add a card dealer that actually feels like a real person is playing cards with you....I just cant say enough good about this game but I'm going to try.

This game is unbelievably good. The voice acting is literally perfect. It is so immersive watching all of the little animations that the  dealer uses and his comments are so on point that it is akin to psycho mantis from mgs. I really get the sense that I am playing cards with a powerful, mysterious and devious being and he is talking to ME! His covered face was a brilliant idea to add to the sense of mistrust.

This is truly a seamles mashup of several components. TCG, action, RPG, strategy. While Hand of Fate isn't a complete experience in any of the forementioned genres there is enough of each one that somehow when combined...is so throughly entertaining and enthralling I simply cannot put it down. The concept is so simple yet so brilliant it's a wonder noone has made a game like this years ago. The gameplay is so fun that I played the game for 7.4 hours straight the same night I purchased it. It is realy a unique experience. What a gem! I really cant say enough about the dealer's character he makes every single moment of this game feel meaningful and the absolutely nailed the atmosphere. The presentation is top notch. there are so many wonderful details such as the way the candle burns down as the game goes on and as such the room becomes darker.

I was so filled with wonder, excitement, terror, joy and anger while playing this game. The games difficulty seems to ramp up nicely. I am not even half way done with this game yet but I am so looking forward to the bosses and cards that I will unlock next but most of all I am looking forward to unraveling the mystereis behind the dealer and what this game is all about.

Fascinatingly there is no tutorial you are simply thrust into the game and yet I can tell that this is not an oversight, it is deliberate and the dealer makes mention of it several times. If you've ever played a videogame before you will figure it out and the gameply is so intuitive that to my surprise, no tutorial is necessary! He will wager some precious artifacts if you win you earn them if you lose you will have to roll your deck again and he will deal the dungeons from the beginning.

I took a chance on this game because I really like TCG and the way that this suppossedly had an action elemant sounded interesting and unique and I am so glad I did. Now that I know how good this game is I would have gladly spent twice the price I paid. Unless you are some sort of gibbering idiot who only plays madden games you will definitely love this game. I seriously cannot imagine anyone not liking this game; it is straight up fun! The game really put a smile on my face very quickly and then gradually became very challanging. I really love Hand of Fate. I give HOF my highest reccomendation and I would place this game among my top favorite games of all time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a person who like procedurally generated games, this of course immediately got me interested when I saw it.
At it's base this game is a part RPG, part action combat game, slight part deckbuilding game.

The game is broken into adventures which get longer as you progress and unluck the next adventure. Before embarking you can put the cards you have into the encounter and equipment decks which will be used during the run. Some cards are locked for the specific adventure, some cards you may not know the effect of until you've encountered them in game at least once. For some adventures there are special circumstances like more damage from projectiles or taking damage if you carry too much gold at a time.

Once you've started the game, the narrator will deal out cards to form the dungeon floor you're on. Either your target is on this floor, or there's a stairwell to go deeper. You move one card at a time either horizontally or vertically using food as you go. Each card is an event, some with just text, others with battles. It does lend a good feeling to this being an adaptation of a card game and you're playing against the deck out to kill you.

If you enter battle, the world changes into 3D for a battle sequence flowing a bit like the Batman games or Asassins creed, though without the vertical element to it. Initially the combat feels clunky, maybe it was just the state I played it in, or maybe it owes to the fact that I didn't get a shield until later and didn't realise there was a dodge roll button either. The combat can be a bit tricky to see at times, but otherwise feels very satisfying connecting with your mace or warhammer.

In all this is a nice game with a bit of randomization. It carries the atmosphere of playing an engrossing cardgame quite well, and breaks up the text events with a robust battle system. It gets rather tense when you're down to one food hoping you'll run into a merchant or a treasure chest with food in it, and it can really ruin your run when you have little health left and run into a tough battle you were hoping to avoid till you'd regained more health.

As for negatives: There is some text to read in this game, so if you dislike reading, skip it. Maybe down the line it'll all be narrated, but for now it isn't.
Also you will encounter the same card and thus even several times over your playthrough. If you're the person who want new stuff constantly, this might put you off. As it is, once you know an event by heart you can usually click past it and get the effect you'd like. And of course you can alter the frequency by removing some of them from your deck if you so desire.
The camera can be a bit tricky in the action sequences. I only found it got in the way of fighting once or twice, but if you're the kind of person who demands manual camera control or perfect viewing angles, this is not the case here.

Lastly: I played this game using an XBox 360 controller, it works quite well. I don't know how well a keyboard and mouse setup would fare, but so far I've not found any ranged weapons so the 8-directional movement afforded by Keyboard should be sufficient if done well. Just know I have not tested this.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's an interesting mix of deckbuilding, exploration, and action.  Build your equipment and encounter decks, then explore the randomly dealt map of encounter cards you put together, hope to earn equipment from the equipment deck you built, and use it all to hack'n'slash your way through baddies and bosses to unlock more cards! reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI usually avoid Early Access games because I'd rather make sure I'm getting a whole game and to avoid spoiling anything. I picked this up as part of a bundle because Extra Credits said it was worth the look for its uniqueness alone. Boy were they right. What they left off was how delightfully fun it is. It takes what could be a boring basic premise and dresses it up in just the right way to make it fresh and engaging. The voice acting (and the writing) is nigh flawless. The visual design is never stunning, but always full of loving detail. The setting sits right between being broad enough to feel deep and repetitive enough to feel symbolic. What's more it's always explored indirectly as a side benefit of progressing through the game mechanics itself. Rich with theme, a pleasure to explore, and with more to come, you'd be hard pressed to find a better choice for that distraction game you've been needing.

reviewText:
Mixing cards, D&D setting and Arkham Asylum-like combat couldn't go wrong now, could it?
Short answer: Yeah, it can.

Long answer:
You get to build a deck of cards: Encounters, shopkeepers, stuff, curses, blessings and such.
I really wanted to like this game. And I definitely did. And still sometimes do. But there are far too many things that keep me from fully recommending this to you. So, good things first, the setting is part of what I liked. The ambience the game sets is pretty cool and involving, while not too extravagant. The game master's taunts and comments might be redundant in the long run, but they're still well made and help the player get into the game a bit more. The way you unlock new cards and encounters with tokens, pretty cool too, makes you want to play more and more to unlock more cards and move deeper into the different storylines. The game system, nothing complicated, but making it simple is what makes it work : You move from encounter to encounter, spending one food at a time, healing a bit while doing so. As I said, it's simple, yet allows you a bit of planning when you look at which way you'll go.

What could go wrong then?

First, the encounter themselves: While having them randomly placed on the map makes sense and allows for replayability [GOOD RNG], most of them involve luck way too heavily to be amusing. You just pick a card and see if it's a success or failure, which can lead to frustrating events (looking at you there, devil's carnival) at worst and not so involving at best [BAD RNG]. I understand the need of randomness in such a game, but I wish I could have a heavier impact on it.
And then the combat, oh my the combat. Arkham Asylum wasn't incredible and definitely was too easy, but it was nervous, fast paced, and pretty to look at (most of the time) because of its dynamic nature. Hand of Fate's one is just plain boring. At first it might seem enjoyable, because of the equipment possibilities and monsters that you imagine will come against you, but after two hours you've seen most of it. It's bland, slow-paced, not hard by any mean, unless the game's RNG decided to ♥♥♥♥ you up and stack everything against you (curses, loss of equipment...). Seeing that it's supposed to be an important part of the game, it's sad to see it fail to convey the atmosphere of epicness the games tries so hard to set.
That being said, understand that this game is fun, but that you won't have fun for more than a few hours at best, therefore I don't recommend you buying it at full price. Wait for a sale, don't pay more than 10 bucks for this, really.


tl;dr : Yes, I'd recommend this game, but for no more than a few bucks.

reviewText: Great idea for a game, but unfortunately, the more you play, the more frustrating little things that didn't seem too terrible at the beginning become.  The biggest failure is the combat system.  Being able to use your mouse to control the direction you move would be great, but instead you're limited to A,W,S,D as though you're just a piece on a chessboard.  That doesn't work so well when you're surrounded by bosses and add ons in a tight space.  I saw some of the unlockable achievements being to fight X number of battles without taking any damage.  Yeah, right.  I'm all for things being more difficult the more I progress, but as others have commented, the difficulty spike soon makes the frustration outweigh the enjoyability factor far too quickly.  I've tried to love it, but the more I play, and the further I move along, the more likely I am to delete this game, count my blessings I got it on sale, and find other, more enjoyable games to play.  Hopefully the developers will read through some of the negatve reviews and continue to revamp the game.  Great idea for a game, but still needs a lot of work to deservite its Mostly Positive" rating it currently has."

reviewText:
Would you like a game that combines deck building like Magic and hack and slash like diablo meets streets of rage?  Well so would I and this game falls far short of the mark.  The deck building is pretty pointless as there seems to be no strategy to it at all.  There are no synergies to be exploited so what's the point?  All it does is give you the space on the board to play and some equipment that the RNG will deem fit to annoint you with or screw you with.

Then you have encounter cards that have you picking between four cards with success or failure.  This is such a lame feature I have no idea how it got into the final game.  Maybe somebody is a big 3 card monte fan or played persona 3 too much.

Then you have the combat which basically entails whacking a couple guys, some dodge rolling and the occaisional counter telegraphed by the giant green symbol above the enemies head.  Wow.  Excitement it is not.  They try to spice it up with throwing some traps in the levels but all that does is make the combat even more tedious.  I beat some boss called the Queen of Dust with a rusty axe  (thanks RNG) by just running around in circles and then just whacking her after her unblockable attack.  It makes fighting the lamest enemies in Dark Souls seem like Swan Lake in comparison.

So let's say you die during a level.  Well you get to keep any cards you get and then try it all over again.   Great.  It's a grindy game as well.  Sorry guys, the actually combat portion of the event is not fun enough to warrant any sort of grind.  Maybe if you made the levels bigger and it were more like a streets of rage type level (waves of enemies) instead of an arena level based upon a whack and roll mechanic it may have been more fun.


tl/dr  Not all new ideas are good.   The equivalent of a deep fried salad.

reviewText:
I wanted to really love this game, but I feel like there is some big room for improvement.

First, I must say that the concept is great. It makes for interesting and variable playthrough. I think with a few improvements this could easily turn into one of my favourite games.

So the big problem I had is that the combat became very dull and one dimensional about halfway through the game. I felt like as soon once the number on enemies faced in each combat scenario got high enough I ended up just tapping the counter key constantly and could not do much else, and without a shield the was no hope of completing more than a couple of combat scenarios.

The deck also started to feel unbalanced partway through the game, which I suppose added to the difficulty, but it seemed like too many cards had a 75% failure or epic failure chance with signifcant consequences and samll chance of reqrd, which was frustrating at times.

I think encorporating a bit of dungeon crawling could really liven things up as well. Rather than just being thrust into an arena for each combat, creating a larger level where you could approach the enemies and the combat situation in multiple ways would really improve the gameplay.

I am a bit torn about recommending or not recommending this game; I still think it is an interesting concept and worth a playthrough, but there is definitely a lot of room for improvement.

reviewText:
This game was almost good.

I understand that this is not a AAA game. Last boss 1 shot insta fail QTE from 90 hp with heavy armor. ♥♥♥♥ off. reviewText:
Unfortunately I have to give this game a thumbs down, for now.

tl;dr - It does a lot of things well, and starts off fun, but the difficulty gets extreme enough to make the game unplayable as anything but a suicide simulator.

It frustrates me that I have to give a negative review to this game, because it was really fun when I started playing.  The animations were nice, combat was fun, the voice acting was great.  It was a really well polished random adventure generator game.

The basic mechanic of the game is that encountering cards generates an encounter, whether combat, puzzle, story, what-have-you, and completing the card will unlock that card's token, which will in turn unlock more cards to add to future decks.  It gives a good incentive to try to encounter many cards and figure out how to unlock more.  Quite cool.

As you progress in the game, unlocking more cards, you will also encounter bosses.  Beating them unlocks the next boss card, and after you beat enough bosses you will unlock an artifact that gives you some bonuses but will also make the game harder.

This is the point where the game goes wrong for me.  The difficulty increases introduced by the artifacts make the game virtually impossible by the end.  It was not unusual for me to start a game and the very first card would be a combat against a prior boss, 9 of their minions, on a trapped battlefield with an accompanying totem.  There were so many high powered threats my brand new out of the box adventurer had no chance to win.

What makes it worse is that there's no going back.  Once those difficulty spikes are unlocked, they affect the whole game, retroactively.  If I go back to the very first boss of the game, my first encounter on that level might be the aforementioned impossible fight (and was, the time I tried).  The fun of the game, of running around kicking bandits in the face and solving problems for townsfolk became overshadowed by a constant string of deaths brought on by unwinnable fights.

There's an easy mode that gives the player some benefits, but activating it disables achievements (gotta punish those filthy casuals) and you can't access any of the other character archetypes in the game, which locks out almost all of the games replayability.

Currently the only solution to get rid of the difficulty spikes is to use the 'Erase Progress' feature, which you don't realize until it's too late.  Now, after playing for 12 hours, I'm forced to decide to either erase everything I've accomplished or give up because the game is unplayable.

Neither of those choices make any sense, and are a big part of the reason I can't recommend this game.  There's a great premise here, and the underlying system is really, really cool, but it becomes difficult to the point of impossibility and I've got better things to spend my gaming time on than dying forever.

Should the devs put in a way to disable the artifacts, or otherwise customize the difficulty of the game in a way that doesn't lock out every other character option, I will revisit this review and hopefully change it to a positive.

reviewText:
The artwork is very pretty.  That's about the only positive thing I have to say about this game.

It is *intensely* boring.  If you want to make a card game, make a card game.  If you want to make an action combat game, then do that.  What you have here is a very mediocre card game and an extremely mediocre action combat game put together.  If they had given up one concept they might have had enough resources to devote to the other to make it good.

Here's how it works, you build a deck of equipment, bonus cards and encounters.  And then the game master lays some encounters on the table face down and your game piece walks" across them
date: you pick the next card to walk on
recommended: and frequently you have only one choice.  Each encounter is either a choose-your-own adventure style multiple-choice question with a bit of random chance thrown in

The mechanics are stunningly bad and you can't even rotate the camera which is very annoying because some of your opponents will run off camera where you can't see them.\n\nThat's pretty much it.  Card after card after card

reviewText:
This game is good...not great. Hopefully with some dev tweaks - it could be really excellent.

It's very innovative and well done. Graphics are pleasant, the concept is refreshing and the execution is...well...it's ok.

Some of the positives:
1) Great concept. This is a card game and a button masher. It's not an RPG. There's no levelling of your character, no stats to decide in which to invest, no classes, no abilities.  It's a card game that unfolds into button mashing sequences based on the cards that are randomly drawn. The mix of card and action elements combined with a fantasy/D&D type setting are neat and are done well.
2) The game is polished. The graphics are nice, the voice acting is very good, the presentation of the encounters are well done, etc. It's a well put together game with nice artwork, GUI, sounds, etc.

Some of the negatives:
1) The cards PART 1. For me , I dislike the card designs greatly. The devs chose to go with a basic brown card with black text - and it's drab. The rest of the game is graphically very colorful and interesting. I realize the card design is going for an old parchment feel - but it just seems uninteresting to me. I could have done with some interesting edge work, slight color tints, or edging...something. There are tons of card games out there and the cards themselves are always something of great time and effort in the design , sometimes even with collector editions, gold versions , etc.
2) The cards PART 2. For some reason, the devs thought it would be interesting to lock" cards. When you get them
date: you don't know what they do until you come across them in your journey. This makes the whole part where you get cards at the end of your journey nearly pointless. When you complete a card/journey
hoursPlayed: and at the conclusion of a journey your tokens are exchanged for cards. The cards turn over on your screen and all you can do is look at the title and picture and wonder what they do....unless it's something you already unlocked. Perhaps this is fun to others and not to me

reviewText:
Original concept, but too many flaws.

The camera point of view is absolutely horrible, up to the point of being unplayable sometimes, especially in the trap maze and with large enemies.
The game's difficulty curve is broken. The first 3 tiers are extremely easy, the last tier is suddenly hard. One wrong curse card can nearly instantly kill you.
Too many encounters are based on luck, instead of skill. Not quite like rolling the dice, but close to it.
Certain playthroughs become impossible to complete because of the above. Nothing you can do about it, except retrying and hoping for better luck.
Equipment is not balanced. The most important piece is the weapon. Almost more important than the other equipment pieces added together. Also, most of the blessings are of little use.

reviewText: If you want to play a game with the worst camera controls for the PC, by all means play this one. reviewText:
Other reviews are more in depth and they echo my thoughts, so I'll be consise

The atmosphere is 100% perfect. It draws you into the world magnificently. The dealer is perfect.. however that's not the whole game. What destroys this atmosphere is the gameplay..

Once you're about 2/3rds into the game you'll realize why people left negetive reviews. The combat remains simple and unrewarding, however the monster HP goes up as you get better items to your deck. However you don't start with those items, you have to be lucky enough to find them. So monsters are now punching bags, and every time you run into a combat card you sigh from exhaustion. The end game is just brainless masochism (and I've beaten the castlevania, ninja gaiden, and Ghouls n Ghosts trilogies). You lose because of dice rolls, and the odds aren't in your favor. The final battle is depressingly boring- just a repeat of old bosses and the final boss is just a QTE.

I gave the developers months to change it, but they haven't. I recommended this game to many of my friends and I honestly regret it once I saw the full game.

reviewText: A great idea ruined by frequent, lifeless, repetitive, and bland combat, ripped directly out of action games such as Batman. I'm actually disappointed, as the card generated gameplay and deck building features are unequivocally unique. If they could change up the combat so it feels as unique as the rest of the game, or better yet remove it altogether, I'd recommend this. Buy it on sale for <$5 so you can experience such an entertaining concept, without ending up disappointed that it fell so flat.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to playing Hand of Fate after reading some of the reviews. This wasn't a gameplay style I'd really indulged in before and when people have a lot of love for a game I'm immediately drawn to a title; unfortunately after a short dabble I was feeling left out of the group of people who seem to have nothing but positive feedback to add to a list of admirable blurbs.

It may be one of those things where I just don't enjoy or even get the style and my intention isn’t to deride the reviews of people who seem to adore Hand of Fate. Unfortunately I was left with a feeling of dull disappointment and a small hole in my pocket after just over an hour of learning the mechanics. Don't get me wrong I'd happily pay my last cent for something enjoyable and the concept is refreshing but everything else was just overwhelmingly average.

Gameplay was OK

Atmosphere was OK

It looks OK

Controls were OK (if not a little clunky)
The music and narration are well put together with the aid of a great fantasy style voice actor but even after just over an hour play time the gameplay quickly became repetitive and irritating. I so wanted to love this game; generally if I’m excited by something I’ll be anxious to return to it or navigating obsession but the idea of having to return to this does feel like a bit of a chore.

reviewText:
Quite a fun little mismash of genres - Up to a point. Hand of Fate lays deckbuilding card games, roguelikes, action brawlers and choose-your-own-adventure books onto the table and shuffles. The end result feels surprisingly fresh and innovative, even though none of the individual components would really stand on their own.

Initially, the game works wonderfully because of its brisk pace and laidback feel - There seems to always be something new around the corner and the game is just a joy to play. However, as the end draws close, the difficulty is suddenly amped to eleven and the game turns into a grind. During the last few rounds the deck is so stacked against you that even with immaculate play, you can still lose terribly.

Yes, I understand that the game is a roguelike and you're supposed to die a bit, but going from not dying at all for 90% of the game to losing twenty times in a row is just poor balancing and design. A shame really, since with a bit less punishing difficulty curve Hand of Fate would've been a surefire recommendation. It delivers innovation, fun and respectable production values, but eventually turns into a plain old Three-card Monte.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of good ideas and some really good implementation, and up until you beat the Jack of Plague you will be having a great time. It only goes downhill from there. Mages that block indefinitely, ranged attacks that are impossible to avoid, and prepare your butt for the Blacksmith card which contains two boss level monsters that spawn together with 4 enemies each, which do around a sixth of your life in damage with each attack.

This game needs a LOT more balancing before it's ready for public consumption. I too was fooled by the idea and flowery reviews. Turns out I don't have the stomach for overpowered enemies and unbalanced messes.

reviewText:
I really want to give this game a positive recommendation. Its innovative card / action battle structure has all the makings of a totally addictive and fun experience. I want more cards, want to find out what they do, and am on the edge of my seat with every move forward onto the next encounter.

But there are two really big flaws, which I suspect will limit how much time I put into the game. The first is a clunky and sometimes non-intuitive interface, with lots of unnecessary and repetitive micro-pauses. Every time you hit a merchant, you have to wait for a few seconds as the game transitions to the same 3D rendering of the merchant cart, before you are allowed to get on with the transaction. Fine the first time, really annoying by the 20th time. Ditto with shuffling the cards before making one of the game's very frequent 4-hidden-card choice routines.

The second big flaw is the tactical combat. It just feels fuzzy, with a lack of precise control over your character that it already turning me off. It's not like Diablo 3, with it's crisp and immediately responsive controls. It's more like playing Diablo 3 drunk while wearing ski mittens. I would have preferred a crisp isometric 2D action sequence, or even a turn-based battle approach, rather than the sluggish and woozy 3D battles here.

Maybe some fine tuning is all that's needed to turn this into a very fun game. For now, though, it's not going to be on my play a lot list.

reviewText:
This is a case of a great idea with a poor execution. In general, the cards seem to be poorly planned for how they will actually affect the player - but that is the least of this games problem. The one, huge, fatal flaw of this game is the combat. It is the worst combat/action of any game I've played in a good while, and for a game that seemingly without rest throws combat at you all the time, this isn't good. This isn't good at all.

It's a matter of 'press Q to block', and 'left click to attack', without the ability to use the mouse to choose directions - yes, they didn't even manage to implement something as simple as that. The camera is also set, so you can't really turn the angles to get whatever perspective you want.

Though to be fair, the game isn't exactly terrible... I'm just... Dissapointed. I read the warnings, I ignored them because it looked interesting, and I paid the price.

reviewText:
Cool concept; limited entertainment value.

I purchased this game after reading a number of positive reviews because I was intrigued by the concept. I enjoyed playing it for approximately one hour, at which point the novelty wore off. The game became extremely repetitive and offered few, if any, chances for succeeding because of strategy. Combat is a little clunkly and not enjoyable. I found myself getting agitated every time I encountered a combat situation not because it was difficult and I didn't know if I was going to survive, but because I had no desire to endure yet another few minutes of spamming the left mouse button, q key, and space bar.

Quite frankly, there's not much left to say other than after your 60 minutes of enjoyment you will experience a prolonged bout of depression stemming from the money you just wasted on this game.

reviewText:
Made it all the way to the last *stage* so to speak, and I'm never playing this game again.

Why? Completely unbalanced random BS utterly destroys any momentum you can build on your own. Too much the game is bogged down with random curse cards that leave the outcome entirely up to chance. Too often I have a good run going, then randomly I get attacked with three curses that destroy my health or give me a stupid handicap like making it so everytime I block I use up food (WHAT!?).

And the combat, ugh the combat. First of all, it's basic Batman combat, but it's done rather poorly. Many times (EVERY BATTLE IN THE END GAME) I'll be evading one attack only to have another enemy attack me mid-evade, which I cannot avoid. Screwing me over. And the arenas are so small that in many cases divide and conquer is impossible.

Oh, I'm pretty sure this game would be impossible to play if you're red/green colorblind. So keep that in mind.

A great idea destroyed by lazy design. Avoid.
voteText: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Almost but not quite.

While the metagame is quite fun at first, it quickly grows wearying. First off, there's a big RNG element in the sense that you often get 'encounters' that are decided from 4 cards, some of which may be 'successes' and some of which may be 'failures.' The cards shuffle and then you pick one. However it's not *really* RNG as you can follow the shuffling of the cards with your eye. I found this pretty onerous: I would have much rather it just be true RNG because it becomes quite tiresome to closely watch cards that you can sometimes follow but just as often not.

Furthermore, the core aspect of the game - the combat - failed to satisfy. There's a lot of minor annoyances that serve to break up the flow of the combat. For example, you can knock enemies prone and then repeatedly hit them over and over. Seems reasonable enough but it really breaks up the free-flowing feel of the combat (which is heavily reminscent of the Batman Arkham games). The ratmen emit poison when they fall and countering the scales messes up your combo counter. EDIT NOTE: Patches appear to be improving some of my complaints with combat flow.

I really could go on and on for minor issues. There are too many button pushes and after any lengthy period of time playing you start to rapidly push buttons out of impatience.

One of the bigger issues is the promise of 'deck building.' Technically, yes you build a deck. In application, not so much. Mostly you'll want to slot new cards in order to unlock their 'token' which unlocks further new cards. I did this thinking I'd be able to build a deck once I finished the story mode and started endless mode. Nope. I beat the story mode (in ~8 hours or so) and loaded up endless mode, only to discover you don't get to build a deck at all. It's random. Well that's disappointing.

In short, Hand of Fate is a fun imaginative game that, for me at least, failed to deliver deep satisfaction.

reviewText:
TL;DR:
Hand of Fate is two repetitive, hardly innovative, unfortunately vague, sometimes-working games stuck together in a way that's at least pretty. Don't buy it without doing your homework.

FULL REVIEW:
Hand of Fate boasts an aesthetically gripping melding of two unlike games into a single experience that varies from unplayable to underwhelming. On their own, each of the ‘games’ of Hand of Fate fall far from being worthwhile. Together, the card game and the three-dimensional fighting game intermingle in a way that works just enough to keep players invested in a fairly transparent skinner box.

Players are subjected to a deck-building card game that rewards repetitive play with a larger card base and challenges players through proper resource management. Game-to-game rewards are meted out through a shell game that is either too easy or too hard, an aspect that belies the RNG nature of the card game. Overarching rewards are given after successfully completing ‘token’ cards, which have a variety of conditions to complete (some of which are obvious, some obscure, almost all of them lacking explanation). Common issues of RNG exist and are easy to overlook, but there are some more severe instances such as stumbling upon very difficult encounters too early on that force a player have to quit a run of the game or even completely reset their progression overall. Card balance is a huge issue, with several cards being outright stronger than others regardless of situation. Furthermore, the encounter deck that the player must create is a vague collection—there are no indicators of what the encounters do, and some encounters seem variable in their options and outcomes. This makes constructing an encounter deck a chore of either looking up each card online or simply not knowing what each encounter brings in terms of challenge and reward unless the player has drawn that encounter several times. Hand of Fate seems to beckon players to experiment to discover what works and what doesn’t, while punishing players every time that it does not work out both in their current game played and across multiple future games.

The fighting game, unfortunately, has even more severe issues. Combat is without weight, several mechanics of the system go unexplained, difficulty of encounters has to be inferred, some arenas are far too unforgiving, and so on. There is a simple system of click-to-attack, click-to-counter incoming moves that’s been popularly attributed to the Arkham series of games. Here, it barely works, as most encounters find the player vastly outnumbered by enemies that constantly attack. It is often difficult to even land two attacks in a row on an enemy without being interrupted in some way, giving combat a hectic and choppy flow. Camera angles can be a detriment to properly positioning the character, especially as some arenas feature traps and enemies can attack the player from off-screen. There’s a rolling maneuver that the player is intended to use to avoid several of the heavier attacks in the game, but the roll often comes out too late and does not offer much in terms of defense thanks to aforementioned issues along with painfully awkward hitboxes. Enemies take far too many hits, with the exception of when the player has specifically itemized to defeat an enemy type, and then combat becomes laughably easy against said enemies. There simply is no middle-ground, though. To further frustrate things, rewards are tied to number of monster cards drawn rather than individual monster difficulty--sometimes beating four skeletons can be just as fruitful as overcoming ten skeletons and a boss you fought before. Overall, combat is a mess, ranging from repetitive and easy to punishingly difficult thanks to a culmination of issues that are out of the player’s hands.

Throughout the whole of the game, there simply is a lack of clarity—how much damage am I actually doing? How much damage does my gear reduce? What does an ice-cone attack even do? Is holy damage only extra-effective against undead? Who are these various characters? What does this encounter card even do? What is the purpose? Too many aspects are left to be inferred, both in terms of narrative and mechanics (an appendix would help, even). Oft-times, I find myself recursively fighting through boring encounters, hoping that I actually win the shell games this time around, so that I can unlock more shell games and progress to just being done. There isn’t a gripping narrative arc that makes me want to continue to play to the end. The gameplay from moment to moment is droll and forgettable. There’s nothing that stands out.

This all goes without mentioning the several issues the game has just running. It outright crashes on startup, it crashes when loading some encounters, it sees framerate dips on some machines; so on and so forth. Thankfully, the support team for the game has been working on patching out and addressing these issues, mostly via their forums.
This isn’t to say it’s all bad. I’d be kidding myself if I said the style of the game and the goals it sets out for aren’t awesome. There’s a very strong aesthetic that permeates the game just as there’s something refreshing about having these two genres put together in such a way that one doesn’t get too boring before the other takes over. Sure, dialogue gets repetitive and lore is a bit sparse at times and obfuscated at times, but it’s charming and interesting when it isn’t.

All in all, Hand of Fate is promising, but lacks polish. There are plenty of options that can be fixed, plenty that can be clarified, and several aspects that can be advanced. Sadly, it seems that a complete overhaul would need to be done to each of the games that exist within Hand of Fate for them to work on their own. If you’d like to pick up two flawed, repetitive games that can distract from their flaws and repetition by means of alternation, go for it. If you’re a sucker for how a game looks rather than how it plays, buy the game like I did. If you want a worthwhile playing experience that’s rewarding outside of just earning more stuff in the game, though? Look to spend your money elsewhere.
